DEBATE.TITLE: EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate without requests.
Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian housing industry has been subjected to four years of Labor's stop-start policies. Now it is faced with added uncertainty following the share market crash. The Australian housing market is a fragile one. To be vigorous and healthy, housing requires a climate of economic stability and certainty. These ingredients have been lacking under this Government. As a result, the housing industry has been on a roller-coaster ride of exaggerated booms and busts.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past four years this big spending Hawke-Keating Government has accumulated deficits of $23,000m with borrowing and interest payments to match. Because the Government has been the biggest single borrower in the market-place, crowding out the smaller borrowers, interest rates have reached and remained at record high levels. These record high interest rates are the biggest single factor keeping tens of thousands of Australian families from achieving their dream of home ownership. There is no doubt about the unsatisfied demand for new houses-the August 1986 and August 1987 reports of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry put the demand for new houses at 30,000 and 40,000 respectively above projected new housing commencements. But year after year this demand for new houses remains unfulfilled.

After a sustained period of record high interest rates in the last month or so we began to see a slight easing in rates. At the end of September this resulted in an enthusiastic response from a pent-up market waiting for the first signs of just such a reduction. For a brief period in some States we experienced a boom in housing sales both in terms of volume and prices. Traditional indicators such as loans for owner occupancy and housing starts were up. Much of the activity in this mini-boom was in the upper end of the market with little help for the first home buyer population where there is the majority of the unmet new housing demand.

Then came the events of 27 October which have launched us into uncharted economic waters. Initially there was the stock market crash and then, with growing concern about our economy and no action from the Government to restore confidence, the selloff of Australian shares and concerns about commodity prices has led to a selloff of our currency which has forced the Australian dollar down to an 18-month low of under US67c against indeed a much weakened American dollar.

While the depreciation of the Australian dollar may help our balance of trade and current account deficits because of our reliance on commodity exports, the cause of the decrease in the dollar's value will not help the housing industry. If overseas money continues to be withdrawn from the Australian economy there will be more upward pressure placed on interest rates. In addition, Reserve Bank of Australia action to hold the Australian dollar will lead to higher rates. It is all very well for Mr White of the Westpac Banking Corporation to say that the banks are awash with money from the share selloff but this is now being counterbalanced by the flight of capital overseas and the demand the Reserve Bank is making on money markets. If Mr White is right, why have short term interest rates such as the 90 day bill rate gone from 12.56 per cent after the Budget to 13.59 per cent today-a rise of over one per cent.

The lessons from the past are all too clear. Australian home buyers just cannot afford high interest rates. Growth in the housing industry will not be sustainable if interest rates begin to rise again. Any upward movement in interest rates will certainly put a rapid end to the recent short-lived mini-boom in housing sales. As long as our high level of overseas debt remains, interest rates and the Australian housing industry will continue to remain the whipping boy of the Australian economy. The housing industry and the home buyer are paying the penalty for the extravagance of this big spending, big taxing Labor Government.

Housing in Australia is at its worst in the nation's history and the record of the Hawke-Keating Government is clear: a record number of over 160,000 applicants waiting for public housing; a record number of over 64,000 applicants waiting for home purchase assistance under State programs; a cut of $648m to States for public housing and capital grants in this the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless; record high home mortgage interest rates in 1986-87; one of the worst years on record for housing starts with 1986-87 demand exceeding starts by 30,000; housing demand in 1987-88 is expected to outstrip starts by up to 42,000; and home owners are paying up to 17 per cent more of their income on mortgage repayments than they were a decade ago.

The Bill before us provides no solutions for the problems this Government has created. It simply provides more of the same, with tighter controls and less money. The revised Commonwealth State Housing Agreement (CSHA) referenced in this Bill takes us further down the road of Commonwealth intervention in State housing policy matters with the resultant duplication at Commonwealth and State levels. For example, the revised agreement specifies that the level of spending for rental accommodation by the States shall not be less than 50 per cent of total CSHA funds-that is $700m for each of the next three years; it shall not be less than 50 per cent of total Loan Council borrowing program moneys nominated for housing; and it shall not be less than 50 per cent of total State matching funds. Additionally, the agreement encourages States to put money from the proceeds of the sale of public housing into rental accommodation.

The States are in a much better position than the Commonwealth to assess the housing needs of their own communities, and they are therefore in a more favourable position to determine how State housing dollars should be allocated. These provisions of the new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement are simply extensions of the Labor Government's housing policy which proposed to double the proportion of housing stock in public tenure by 1992. This would mean that one in every ten Australian families would be paying rent to a government landlord.

This is a policy which has failed, and which, in part, has brought the housing industry to its current crisis. Experience over the years has shown that there is a direct correlation between the volume of public housing stock and the number of people waiting for public housing. The more people are encouraged to rely on public housing and the more public housing stock is built or acquired, the longer the waiting lists for public housing have become. The ranking of States in order of the length of waiting lists for public housing is exactly the same as the ranking of the States in order of public housing stock available, and this list in no way corresponds to a ranking in terms of population, employment or other socio-economic indicators.

The States with the longest queues are the States with the largest number of public housing units. This is so regardless of the population of the State. For example, as at June 1986 Victoria, with a population of just over four million, had 51,000 public housing units and 28,700 on public housing queues. South Australia, with a third of the population of Victoria, had 56,000 public housing units-5,000 more than Victoria-but the South Australian queue was 39,600. That is 11,000 more people in the queue than in Victoria. New South Wales has a population that is around 25 per cent greater than that of Victoria. It has double the number of public housing units, yet it has double the public housing queue of Victoria. Victoria, with 51,000 public rental units, has 28,700 waiting. New South Wales, with 102,000 public housing units, has 57,400 waiting. TALK.START.PARA: —The simple fact is, the more public housing a State has, the longer its waiting list for public housing, and the same is true of the nation. The more public rental housing we provide, the longer become the waiting lists for that public housing. In addition to the encouragement the Government has provided for people to rely on public housing which leads to this demand, another reason for this phenomenon is that the more money available for housing spent on providing rental accommodation, the less money is available for providing home purchase assistance. What more proof could we want of the failed housing policy of this Government? And yet the Bill before us locks us into more of the same policy, with even greater emphasis on public rental accommodation. This policy will perpetuate the deterioration in the level of home ownership, resulting in more public renters and long queues. The Bill provides no incentive for self-provision and home ownership and instead encourages reliance on totally government funded housing. This is the sharp end of this Government's socialist philosophy: undermine home ownership and foster reliance on the State. Whilst there should be some provision for public housing, we need to address the current imbalance and provide greater incentives for home ownership. Clearly, to oppose this Bill thereby cutting off some $700m in Commonwealth funding for the States would not be responsible and therefore I move as an amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the provisions of this Bill, the House:
(1) condemns the Government for its further intrusion into State housing programs involving more administrative duplication and waste; and
(2) believes greater responsibility for the provision of housing should rest with the States who are in the best position to address their communities' needs'.

Under this Government, Australia's once proud record of being a world leader in the level of home owner occupancy is slipping and the dream of home ownership is souring. Home owner occupancy in Australia used to be among the highest in the world at 72.5 per cent but it has fallen to 69.1 per cent and continues to fall. The path ahead for us is clear. If we are to raise ourselves from this Labor inspired malaise, the nation must make a new commitment to home ownership in the conviction that home ownership not just represents a dream for all families, but is a positive and sound contribution to this nation's economy, its recovery, and to the future security of all Australians.

There are those who would argue that investment in the family home is not a productive investment when compared with investment in the industrial infrastructure, for example. On the contrary, the family home is essentially linked to family stability, strength and security and the family is the nation's greatest resource. Additionally, in an aging society such as Australia, the provision of retirement security represents an actuarial economic commitment of staggering proportions. Social security payments are growing at an alarming rate each year. I submit that the family home has an essential link with the retirement security of Australians. A mortgage free home in retirement provides not only the essential commodity of housing but a ready source of capital should circumstances indicate that an alternative living arrangement is appropriate. Further, the effects of housing construction as an economic and employment stimulator have long since been established and accepted. It is estimated that $100m spent in housing results in another $140m income in the rest of the economy and that each on-site job in home building generates another job in the rest of the economy.

Finally, the simple fact remains that each year we are in need of more housing. In the coming year the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry has predicted a demand for 160,000 to 170,000 new houses. If the individual does not invest in home ownership who will? The Government? The private landlord? Clearly, the only option for meeting the housing needs of the nation rests with the individual home buyers. Any other alternative would change the existing time-honoured and acceptable face of Australian society regarding tenure homes.

The challenge of the housing crisis to the Government is two-fold. The Government must first establish and maintain sound policies which provide a stable and certain economic environment in which the housing industry can flourish. Primary in the tasks needed to accomplish this is the control over government debt and borrowing. Additionally, the Government must respond to the needs of home buyers and home owners with commitments which assist and encourage those who undertake to invest in a private home.

A variety of alternatives to the current arrangements have been voiced and put forward by various industry groups with an interest in home owner occupancy in Australia. My goal over the next few months is to review those alternatives with a view to presenting a new approach. The clearest message that any government can send to the nation regarding a commitment to home owner occupancy is that home ownership in the eyes of the Government counted for something. My goal will be to make that objective more attainable for those who are currently excluded by reason of high mortgage interest rates and lack of financial incentive. I exhort the Government to do likewise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the Opposition addresses the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill, which deals with the provision of money for public housing, by talking mainly about home ownership in Australia. Many people will remember that, before the last election, the Opposition actually had as one of its policies the abolition of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, which shows the extent to which Opposition members ignore the need for the provision of public housing. I remind the Opposition shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), that in 1983 this Government introduced the first home owners scheme. We not only realise and implement the Government's responsibilities towards helping people get their own homes but also regard as a very serious responsibility the provision of public housing.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to authorise an appropriation for the provision of financial assistance for public housing for the years 1988-89 and 1989-90 and to authorise the Commonwealth Minister to reallocate specific housing assistance grants between States. This Bill seeks to extend the existing funding arrangements by providing that a guaranteed annual base level grant funding of $700m be provided in 1988-89 and 1989-90. From this amount of $700m a guaranteed annual base of $11m is specified for the local government and community housing program and $14m is specified for the crisis accommodation program components of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

Our responsibilities in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement extend to areas which the Opposition does not seem to realise exist. For instance, in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement specific purpose programs, we attend to the needs of many people who will never be buying their own homes. This assistance is provided through the rental housing assistance for pensioners program, the rental housing assistance for Aboriginals program, the crisis accommodation program, the mortgage and rent relief scheme and the local government and community housing program. As I have said, this Bill supplies a guaranteed annual base of $11m for that latter program to which I wish to direct my attention this morning.

The local government and community housing program is designed to encourage alternative forms of public housing tenure and greater tenant participation in the management of these dwellings. Funds go to local governments and community groups to provide and manage low cost rental housing, boarding housing and hostel accommodation. Organisations are expected to make contributions, wherever possible, in the form of funds, dwellings, land, expertise, knowledge or whatever is appropriate. This is one of the most innovative programs of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and it is having a growing success. There is need for innovation in public housing. There are two very comprehensive articles in the magazine Australian Society which I hope the shadow spokesperson, the honourable member for Barker, will read, because they will reveal to him many of the problems that are facing both public and private housing in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. It seems that the Opposition is unaware that many people in Australia need public housing and are not in the market for private housing. One of the articles points out:

Homeless people form only the tip of the iceberg of housing problems in Australia. Hidden from the public gaze are hundreds of thousands of people condemned through low income, discrimination or disability to live in inadequate housing, overcrowded, substandard, poorly located, high cost or insecure (and often a combination of these factors).
People living in the private rental sector continue to experience the highest incidence of housing-related poverty, with 20 per cent living below the poverty line . . .

Single parents are worst off, with 40 per cent living in poverty after housing, and an alarming 62 per cent of single parents in private rental in poverty after housing. The second most vulnerable group are young single people. Over one-fifth of singles between 15 and 24 are in poverty after housing.

In general, elderly people experience a relatively low incidence of after-housing poverty (3.9 per cent of couples and 5.2 per cent of singles), mainly because people in this age group who own homes have generally paid them off. But poverty is prevalent among old people who rent privately. Of all elderly couples and single people renting from private landlords, one-quarter live in poverty after paying rent.

An article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald points out that figures issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that one in four families in New South Wales have an income of below $290 a week. The historic family package introduced by this Government will give much needed financial assistance to families in poverty. The package includes an increase of 50 per cent in rent assistance. I remind the Opposition again that poor people do not buy houses; they rent or they live in caravans. The supply of private rental accommodation, as we all know, has decreased recently at an alarming rate.

All sorts of things have been blamed for that decrease in the level of private rental accommodation available, including taxation measures such as the quarantining of negative gearing. I am of the view that that has occurred because of a decrease in the private rental market throughout the world. It is not as a result of specific taxation measures brought in by this Government. We have reintroduced negative gearing, which may or may not lead to an increase in supply in private rental accommodation. But you can bet your life that rents will still be spiralling, even if the supply increases. I hope that the supply will increase. The availability of affordable housing is a key to social justice. Virginia Creaser pointed out in the article in Australian Society that public housing needs to be increased to provide decent long term, secure, affordable housing. She said:

Public housing can have `a profound impact' in stabilising the lives of people in crisis. High cost, substandard or overcrowded accommodation can turn able people into homelessness by triggering marriage break-up or overuse of credit, or by eroding self-esteem leading to an inability to gain employment. Such negative attributes are generally the lot of low income people who are forced, through lack of housing choice, into the private rental market.

Housing related poverty in Australia is placing enormous pressures on government at all levels. The Government realises those responsibilities. Commonwealth, State and local government must take up the challenge, and this legislation gives an opportunity for State and local government to become involved in more innovative and diverse housing projects. Positive changes are occurring already. New public housing has greatly improved its image, its diversity and its quality. Large housing estates are no longer the norm; they are being replaced by unstigmatised public housing in scattered, smaller and better located areas.

Local government is beginning to add to its traditional role an involvement in public housing. Joint venture participation by local government and community groups has already been encouraged through this Government's local government community housing program. Many useful and innovative developments, including common equity rental co-operatives, have been launched from this base. Program funds are limited, but $11m is guaranteed this year. These funds are meant for program development; they are really seeding funds. There is considerable potential for extending joint venture arrangements well beyond the confines of this Budget. Once a common set of guidelines has been established, the marketing of opportunities for joint venture participation can be expected to encourage significant interest.

The reason I am so aware of this program is that the very model for it began in a local government area within my own electorate. Some years ago the local council in Waverley, under the mayoralty of my State colleague Ernie Page, began a wide range of social welfare reforms, including community welfare and housing reforms. Those programs took shape under that council. It proved that local government has a very important role to play in the development of public housing for its own area. Local government, logically, is suited to that involvement; it knows its own area best. The programs initiated by the Waverley Council at that time-including the appointment of a housing officer, the first in Australia-were taken up by local government areas all over Australia. They were used as a model, and they were used as a model for this legislation.

I think most people here know that the Australian Labor Party lost control of that excellent council in 1983, and immediately thereafter the Liberal controlled local government of that area began to dismantle every one of those programs. I have spoken in great detail on that in the past. I have said it was to be hoped that Labor would regain control of the Waverley Council and begin to reinstitute the programs. That has just happened. Labor is again in control of the Waverley Council. It will reinstate the position of housing officer in the new year, and it has already agreed in principle to just the type of venture that is encouraged by this legislation. It has agreed in principle to a joint venture with the Eastern Suburbs Rental Housing Association to purchase a property, perhaps a block of six to eight flats. It will be a shared equity arrangement to protect the venture in the future so that even if the Council does change hands the program will not be got rid of, as has happened in the past. The joint venture accommodation will be managed by the Eastern Suburbs Rental Housing Association, with support from the Council, and this legislation which we are amending today gives these organisations the encouragement and the ability to undertake such a program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current Government has had a regime for home buyers which has put most homes out of the reach of the average Australian. Having done that by high interest rates policies, which have been a positive feature of the Government's economic policies, the Government has proceeded to reduce the amount of funds available for the ever-increasing number of people who cannot afford to buy a home and who are seeking some relief by approaching governments for government assisted housing. The proportion in real terms of assistance provided by this Government to other governments for housing has declined in the last two years; the Government is now providing the lowest level in real terms for many years of assistance to other governments for housing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, having encouraged an economic climate in which the affordability of homes has become more and more difficult, has proceeded to cut the ability of people to get into government housing. It is wrong in every way. The stability of our community, the capacity of people to establish shelter for themselves and for their families, has been seriously cut by this Government. It is an unfeeling, unsympathetic and un-Australian approach to the problems of people establishing their own homes.

I notice that in this Budget the greatest increase in any sector of the whole housing portfolio went to the administration of housing grants. It is a condemnation of the Government that a proportionately greater amount of money will be taken up in the administration of the Government's housing assistance schemes while there has been a major cut of 18 per cent on the level of government provided housing assistance last year. So here we have the Government of equity, the Government of compassion, the Government seeking to be all things to all people, not helping those in greatest need-home buyers and those seeking to establish a home. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) can wander the world-many Ministers can wander the world-discussing with international bankers his image and his prestige, but at home we see a different story. Back in Australia we see just what the Government's real intention is towards the Australian community. The Government has entered into this regime of high interest rates by borrowing more money than it should have borrowed, thereby inflating our position compared with the rest of the world. The Government has not seen fit to adopt an attitude of moderation when times such as we are in demand it. Rather, it has felt that it must listen to the trade unions of Australia and follow their policies rather than take initiatives of its own.

An indication of the degree of affordability of housing loans can be gained by comparing median weekly family income and average monthly loan repayments for new loan approvals. This relationship recognises that a family generally can afford to allocate approximately one-quarter of its gross income to meet its shelter needs. During the March quarter of 1987, all States exhibited a decline in home loan affordability compared with the March quarter of 1986. Only Western Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory remained below the 25 per cent benchmark. The Australian figure increased over that yearly period from 21.3 per cent in the March quarter of 1986 to 27.4 per cent in the March quarter just concluded; that is, 6 per cent more was being outlaid by families of their average weekly incomes towards purchasing their homes. It shows a massive reduction in the living standards of all Australians, and the Government has embarked on this policy knowing that by retaining high interest rates in Australia it will attract the capital inflow which will continue falsely to boost the economy.

That capital inflow based on high interest rates is a false economy because it is a speculative inflow of funds rather than solid investment in capital and fields where there will be job creation and further opportunities for an expanding economy. It has been a conscious decision to balance the books by having high interest rates. The Reserve Bank of Australia has been in on it; the Government has been in on it. What has been the result? The result is massively declining home approvals over the last 12 months; massively declining opportunities for people to purchase their own homes.

If one looks back over the last couple of years, one will notice that in 1985 housing approvals dropped 4 per cent compared with the previous year. In 1986 they dropped 17 per cent, and in July this year they dropped another one per cent-a cumulative impact of a 22 per cent drop in housing approvals. Over that two-year period, from July to July, there was a 22 per cent drop in home approvals. The pattern goes on but it gets worse in many instances. If we add the month of August, we see a total impact of 24 per cent. The approval rate keeps falling, even though the comparable figures for the previous year themselves represented a fall.

Over that period the Government has adopted high interest policies for its own benefit, but it is ruining the lives of many Australians. The Budget figures indicate that a low level of housing assistance is being provided to State governments, which are anxious to provide welfare housing. Whether it be assistance to first home buyers or assistance under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the Government has not seen fit to respond to the needs of the Australian community. That is a tragedy, because this Government proclaims itself as a government that understands the needs of average Australians.

I believe that Australians deserve and want to own their own homes. Any survey in any suburb of any city would show that 90 to 98 per cent of Australians wish to own their own homes, and they make it a direct goal. We hear from the Government that there is an increasing demand for rental accommodation. There is, but it is a narrow market. The real option that Australians want to exercise is to purchase their own homes. No people are more anxious to purchase their homes than the migrants. In fact, the migrant community has the top home ownership rate of any group in Australia. The score for Australian born home owners is higher than for other English speaking groups. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which recently conducted a household expenditure survey, 84 per cent of foreign born non-English speaking home holders owned or were buying their own homes, and the Australian born average was 71.8 per cent. That is what migrants want; they want a stake in Australia, and they are not being allowed to have it.

The high interest regime that this Government has adopted to suit its own international image has created grave difficulties for many Australians wanting to purchase their own homes. It is no good for the Government to say, in regard to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill, `We're propping up the welfare systems of the States by providing a little money to the State governments'. It is providing less and less. It is walking away from the clients that it claims to support. The Italian born community has the highest rate of home ownership in our community-92 per cent. That is a massive figure, and should give the Government an idea of how important a stake in Australia migrants have. Of all Greek born people, 88.7 per cent own homes or are buying them. The figure for the Dutch is 83 per cent; Yugoslavs, 79 per cent; Germans, 76 per cent; and the average figure for Australians born here is 71 per cent. The British and Irish scored 69 per cent and New Zealanders 51 per cent. So the non-English speaking community wants to invest in Australia, and it is being denied that opportunity.

Newspaper headlines show that the writing was on the wall many years ago. In 1984 a headline by Ross Gittins read, `Hawke's home subsidy ingenious but still not foolproof'. We have seen that. In 1986 a headline in the Canberra Times read: `Wran attacks government on housing'. Eighteen months ago the former Premier of New South Wales saw what was going to happen and saw this Government's paltry, inadequate response. Successive articles have been headed, `home loans deregulated'. They deregulated into high interest rates. That was the regime at the time. It is a continuing regime. Another headline in the Sun-Herald read, `Funds for home loans drying up'. That article contained a chart showing how it is almost impossible for average Australians to buy their own homes.

One would have thought that that was enough punishment. One would have thought that the Government had done enough to destroy the dreams of Australians, particularly those of a non-English speaking background. Let us look at what the Government is considering now. Since coming to office in 1983 the Labor Government has imposed measures such as the assets test and the capital gains tax and has partly wiped the negative gearing provisions. It has continued its march towards a wealth tax. One only has to look at the quotes of the past few weeks to see what is in store for home owners. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said:
A wealth tax would have to be imposed on the family home if it was to be effective.

One of the Government's Ministers is saying that the Government will make it impossible for people to buy homes because of high interest rates; it is not going to provide funds for the States at the level it has previously and then it wants a wealth tax for those lucky enough to own their own homes. The Melbourne Sun of 21 October reported Senator Walsh as saying:
If a wealth tax was to raise enough money and be economically feasible it would have to be applied to the middle level not just the top end.

I assume by that he meant income earners. Senator Walsh is saying, `Let us get the lot. Let us grab all Australians in our net'. Even the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) was reported in the Australian on 20 October as saying:

I think there is a very strong case for assessing what the distribution of wealth is in our community and the level of that wealth. It seem to me there are powerful arguments for some exploration of opportunity for redistribution to benefit those less fortunate in our society.
The article went on:
Mr Hayden said there were extraordinary displays of conspicuous consumption going on in this community cheek by jowl with some awful poverty.

There is no doubt that there is that awful poverty. What is the Government doing about poverty and the need for people to provide shelter for themselves? It has brought in high interest rates and increased those interest rates. Even the Real Estate Institute of Australia, which is oriented to selling homes, as the House would understand, has made statements about the drop in interest rates. It says in one of its bulletins:

Despite the fall in prime interest rates, mortgage rates remained stable but high, with only a 0.5 per cent fall being recorded at the end of July. Obviously, further falls are needed to bring potential buyers into the market. Further falls will remain dependent upon significant and sustained declines in market interest rates.

Although the community can read about what is happening to bond rates and fancy money rates, it knows jolly well that mortgage rates have not moved. They have been held consistently high. People in the community know they are paying out a greater and greater proportion of their monthly incomes to stay in their homes. They only have to do the family budget each week to know they are paying more and more under this Government that proclaims itself the custodian of those who are not well off.

I will run through the figures because they are interesting. In the housing assistance to other governments category there will be a drop of 16.8 per cent-this is for people who need Housing Commission homes. There will be a drop of 51 per cent for defence service homes. There will be a drop of 45 per cent for housing in the Australian Capital Territory. For housing in the other category there will be a drop of 76 per cent. There will be an increase in administration of 11 per cent and there will be a welcome increase in assistance, although from a low base, to first home owners of 10 per cent. So the Government has ignored the poor and made it impossible for other people to purchase their own homes. What sort of Government is this? It walks away from its responsibilities to those people who have a great commitment to buying their own homes.

The Aussies in those electorates, whether or not they are from migrant backgrounds, have an overwhelming commitment to owning their own homes. The Government has walked away from that responsibility. Each day we hear the Treasurer talking about world affairs and how he is regarded in Geneva and Washington but never how he is regarded in his own electorate where people turned out to vote against him because of the regime that he has put on Aussies to pay more and more to own their own homes. He is making it impossible for increasing numbers of people to enter into a home purchase.

Then, there was the ultimate disregard of the Australian community-cutting assistance to housing commissions around Australia. Ultimately, the Government walked away from the really poor. The Government says that they will manage. It says, `We will give them a little bit more money in the pocket'. That is an illusory little bit more money in the pocket because it does not compensate. The Government says, `Go out and buy your own homes'. Those people cannot do that. The Government is wrong and deserves to be condemned. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures contained in the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 are in keeping with the traditional concern of Labor governments for public housing. In April 1943 it was the Curtin Government that established the Commonwealth Housing Commission to study the housing needs in each State. In 1945 it was the Chifley Government that negotiated the first Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. It was the Whitlam Government that revived the role of Federal Government in housing after years of neglect from conservative governments. Under Whitlam, expenditure on public housing rose from 2.2 per cent of total public investment in 1972-73 to 5.1 per cent in 1975-76. Adequate and affordable housing was one of the commitments on which the Hawke Government was elected in 1983. In the 1984 Housing Assistance Act the Government honoured its commitment to restructure housing policy and assistance in Australia. This landmark of social legislation was a recognition that affordable and secure housing is essential for the well-being of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this Act, the 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement was negotiated with the State governments. In the 1984 agreement, for the first time, clear and positive statements were made about the need to assess the quality of housing provided, and the need for public housing to reflect the diverse range of targeted tenants. The Bill before the House continues the Government's commitment to provide a guaranteed high level of base funding for the next triennium. Funding for the States and the Northern Territory will be guaranteed at a base level of $700m for 1988-89 and 1989-90. As the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) pointed out in his second reading speech, this is $200m more than the record base funding provided in the first triennium and 3 1/2 times the base level provided for in the previous Government's 1981 agreement.

It is worth recalling that during the election campaign those opposite were committed to a policy of terminating the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and despite the review of many of their policies that seems to be taking place, from today's debate it seems that they stick by this policy. They want to wash their hands of any responsibility in this area. We hear no talk about any commitment on levels of funding, even in the eventuality that they would be returned to power and scrap the Agreement and their involvement.

The Commonwealth has a role in public housing and this Government has played a very constructive role in this area. The new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has been strengthened to ensure that the States meet their responsibility for public housing. Of the 126,000 to 130,000 housing starts this year, 1987-88, some 25,000 will be public housing stock. In my home State of Victoria, the Commonwealth Government's aims in housing are shared by the Cain Government. The Victorian State Labor Government sees secure, affordable housing as fundamental to everybody's well-being. Housing is one of that Government's major priorities within its social justice strategy. Enshrined in the 1983 Victorian Housing Act is a commitment to ensure that, to quote from the legislation:

Every person in Victoria has adequate and appropriate housing at a price within his or her means by encouraging 1) the provision of well maintained public housing of suitable quality and location, 2) the distribution, according to need, of Government housing financial assistance.

Despite the efforts of the Commonwealth Government, there is increasing evidence that poverty, after housing costs have been taken into account, is on the increase. A recent study by the Victorian Ministry of Housing shows that housing related poverty has almost doubled in the last decade, most markedly for those in private sector accommodation. In Victoria, 40 per cent of people living below the poverty line, as assessed taking into account housing costs, are in the private rental sector. This has impacted most severely on single people. Single people in the 25 to 64 age group endure an above-average incidence of poverty related to housing costs. This Government has at least recognised this as a problem and has taken a series of measures to help to alleviate the problem. For instance, social security beneficiaries and low income working families under Labor have seen increases in rent assistance, the extension of rent assistance to those on unemployment benefit and more liberalised tests on rent assistance, and they will see the extension of the rent assistance to low income families receiving the family allowance supplement and to unemployed families from December 1987. This will be the first time that direct Federal Government assistance has been provided to low income families as part of the family package.

This Government has also sponsored the very successful first home owners scheme. This has helped to reduce pressure on the low cost end of the private rental market. As a result of a measure that was announced in this Budget it is hoped that the removal of the quarantining of negative gearing may have the effect of boosting the stock of private rental accommodation and helping to stabilise rents. The private rental market has not demonstrated the capacity to respond to this situation in terms of both cost and availability.

Let us look at costs. In March 1987 the median cost of a one-bedroom flat in Melbourne was $70 per week. That is approximately 70 per cent of the adult unemployment rate. As for availability, in January 1987 the vacancy rate in Melbourne was 1.7 per cent. As the Ministry of Housing study shows, this is well below the three per cent often quoted by the industry as providing a reasonable balance between supply and demand. Whilst dwelling on the private sector, may I reflect on something that I hope is atypical of some entrepreneurial developers in Australia. In last weekend's Weekend Australian, in a glossy advertising supplement, I was somewhat shocked and dismayed to read this statement:
The streets these days are full of cockroaches, and most of them are human.
Every man has a right to protect his family, himself and his possessions. To live in peace and safety.
Sanctuary Cove is an island of civilisation in a violent world, and we have taken steps to ensure it remains so.
The author of those words is Michael Gore, a famous figure in the so-called white-shoe brigade of Queensland politics. He used these words in advertising a housing estate where:
You may now buy your Patio Home. Priced at $825,000.
How obscene! How sick for somebody to use those words in the promotion of such a scheme! The advertising leaflet continues:
Welcome to Civilisation.
The residential area of Sanctuary Cove is unashamedly elitist.
It is a place where successful people will live in a community of their peers. An environment protected by its own Act of Parliament.

Let us just dwell on that. One of the great deregulators, the Queensland Government, is protecting its friends by Acts of Parliament. The whole thing sickens me. The project is sponsored by Ariadne Australia Ltd. Let us reflect on that company's social responsibility. The Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday outlined a study commissioned by that paper, prepared by the stock exchange research service Statex. The study looked at tax paid as a percentage of pre-tax profits for Australia's top 150 companies. Let us have a look at the list of the lowest tax paying companies. Ninth on the list is Ariadne, which paid 8.16c in the dollar. Here we have Mike Gore talking about cockroaches in the streets and civilisation. It is a great and gross obscenity. No wonder there are Australians that are concerned by conspicuous consumption; no wonder there are people that are querying what is happening to the distribution of wealth in Australia. Let it not be said that this is based on some sort of politics of envy, because it is something that should be of great concern. A development such as this is being promoted in this absurd and obscene way in a State with the lowest public housing stock per head of population. It is shameful. The coalition parties want to wipe their hands of any involvement in public housing.

In short, the demands for adequate and affordable public housing are growing. In Victoria as at 30 June 1987 there were approximately 30,000 applicants on the public rental housing waiting lists. I think we should look at some of the reasons for this. By widening the eligibility, a number of single people who previously were ineligible in some States are now eligible. The Victorian situation has been affected by that Government's attempts and policy to deinstitutionalise a number of our aged and disabled people. Let us not be too glib in the way we look at the reasons for the increase in the housing waiting lists. Unfortunately, single parents and single adults without dependants are joining families and the elderly on low incomes as those in need of public housing.

At the same time, another discussion paper of the Victorian Minister of Housing shows that approximately one-third of the State public housing stock is run down and inadequate. This discussion paper identified the elderly as the worst affected, due to the problems of heating, noise and access. Fortunately, in recognition of this problem, the Victorian Government will spend $31.6m this year on improvements to housing stock. Priority areas include Broadmeadows in my electorate and I welcome these initiatives by the Victorian Government.

The increasing demand for new public housing, taken together with the need to upgrade existing stock, amounts to a problem of increasing magnitude that must be tackled with renewed vigour. As I stated at the outset, adequate housing is one of the basic criteria for the well-being of all Australians. It is appropriate that, in this International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, which has as its objectives `to develop strategies to improve the shelter and neighbourhoods of the poor and disadvantaged towards the year 2000', the Government's ongoing commitment to the provision of public housing is highlighted and reinforced by the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an admirer of the mother and father of the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), I can readily understand how pleased they would be to receive a copy of his speech. I do not happen to agree with all that is contained in his speech but I think he expressed his point of view with logic and sincerity and obviously he has a feeling for the poor section of the community. I just know that his mother and father will be thrilled when they receive a copy of his speech. I remind the honourable member that it is not always the case that all the good players are in one team or on one side of politics. On occasions we, on this side of the Parliament, have a right and legitimate grievance when things are sometimes misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member and to other Government members that the first home owners scheme was not introduced in Australia by either the Hawke Administration or the Whitlam Administration; I think it was introduced a long time previously, in the Menzies era. So, technically, the first home owners scheme was sponsored by a conservative government. One of the great pleasures that I had as a Minister for Housing and Construction was to broaden the concept of the first home owners scheme and include a special allocation of finance on a family basis. It is the practice of members of the Australian Labor Party to get up in this House and try to lay claim to the fact that they are the people who introduced the first home owners scheme. I just point out to the honourable member that that is incorrect and I know that he will accept, in the spirit in which I offer it, that slight correction to his speech.

It is with a feeling of regret that we, in this lucky country, are currently bearing witness to such tremendous poverty being suffered by a great many of our compatriots. Therefore, I rise to commend the Government for seeking to implement measures to counteract this crippling problem, through the medium of its Housing Assistance Amendment Bill. The Government has heralded this Bill as the significant breakthrough needed to help ameliorate the problems of poverty and subsequent homelessness. However, I question whether it fulfils these objectives.

I would like now to juxtapose these problems with the Government's proposed solution in order to see how far it actually goes towards counteracting these problems. Since 1981, the number of Australians involved in the process of purchasing a home has risen marginally. We are now looking at a national figure of around 72 per cent of people who are either home owners or purchasers. However, the past decade, corresponding with this period, has seen these people paying up to 17 per cent more of their incomes on mortgage repayments. In Brisbane, this figure now stands at 27 per cent, which is dwarfed by the staggering 45 per cent currently being paid by some home buyers in Sydney. This burden has been further exacerbated by a 5.5 per cent rise in interest rates since 1979, coupled with, roughly, a 20 per cent increase in the cost of housing in the last five years. In sum, therefore, Australians are now being forced to pay higher prices for homes, which they can ill-afford to do in the current economic climate.

This theory is supported by the bankruptcy figures for the July-September quarter issued recently by the Attorney-General's Department. The figures show that bankruptcy currently is at an all-time high. The record massive bankruptcy figure of 560 in New South Wales for the three-month period directly reflects the aforementioned high costs of mortgage repayments in that State. According to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, by the end of the 1985-86 financial year, one-half of one per cent of total loans were in arrears. This represents a massive $7.2m in repayments that home buyers simply could not afford to meet. So we see how low income families are forced to become the servile adjuncts entrapped in a reified world of poverty.

This crisis situation further serves to cripple those poorer households which are experiencing increased difficulty coping with rent repayments, let alone finding enough money for a deposit. Among the poorer households we see evidence of higher levels of unemployment and dependency on pensions and benefits. These unfortunate people, therefore, are forced to rely on rental housing provision. Whilst the more fortunate members of this impoverished group may gain access to public or other forms of non-profit housing, others will continue to rely on private rental housing or pursue less satisfactory options, such as long term caravan living, sharing or delayed housing formation.

Multiple occupation, overcrowding and homelessness, particularly among the young, are widespread. Many low income tenants often have to choose whether to feed their children adequately or keep up with their rental payments. For those who simply cannot keep up with rental payments, long term caravan living has become the normal way of life. Regrettably, these people now total between 250,000 and 300,000 of our fellow Australians. Last year in Queensland, 56,000 people were forced to exist and bring up families in caravan parks. New South Wales had a figure of 43,000; Western Australia, 26,000 and Victoria, 18,000. In addition, a further 5,000 people have been forced to seek alternative means of accommodation, such as caravans in the backyards of other people's homes, tents and houseboats moored on the banks of rivers. Another 2,000 people exist in impoverished dwellings, usually constructed from scrap materials and refuse that they manage to scavenge. Such is the depressing picture of poverty which, although significant to most Australians, is not always apparent.

On current trends and on reasonable expectations for the future, it is clearly of great importance that a viable pool of rental housing is retained. Indeed, the roots of the current crisis lie in overall shortages. There is an overriding need to expand supply to cater for present shortages and an inevitable growth in need.

How far do the measures sought to be implemented by the Government through the amendment to the Housing Assistance Act go towards rectifying this crisis situation? I applaud the Commonwealth Government for its decision to increase the base level of its funding to the States by $200m for the next two years of this triennium. Of course, given the high inflation rate, the real value in the third year will be less. Obviously, the Government has acknowledged the fact that if this problem of housing-related poverty has any chance of being alleviated, financial assistance must be given specifically to public housing programs. The Government seeks to do this by making available to the States $11m for the purpose of the local government and community assistance program and $14m for the crisis accommodation program. These facts of life are to be regretted. I wonder whether, in positive circles, we are doing enough in terms of the record number of marriage breakups and the increased breakdown of family life. Maybe we are not doing enough by way of marriage guidance; we are not doing enough to educate people that marriage is a partnership and that it requires sacrifice by both people. We will not rectify these problems overnight, and it is good for the Government to be seen to be putting these amounts of money into what we term crisis situations. I just wish there were no crisis situations, but I commend the Government for its action.

I do not see any mileage, political or otherwise, in forever criticising a government. I think this is a good move, and I congratulate the Government. I just hope that in the future the need for this allocation decreases, but if it continues I hope the Government might see fit to increase these amounts, notwithstanding the pledges it has made in this legislation. Maybe there could be an increase in the next two years of the triennium. I am fully aware, as all honourable members would be through their association with local government, the Salvation Army and the St Vincent de Paul Society, that a real need does exist. In a spirit of bipartisanship I just want to say that as far as I am concerned and as far as the Opposition is concerned we not only support the Government but also compliment it for taking this measure.

I think all of us would admit, from the knowledge we have of our own constituencies, that the amount provided is not enough to eradicate the problem completely; however, it does provide a springboard from which the States may propel themselves into useful aid programs for the homeless and poverty stricken. I hope that the example set by the Government may be a trigger which will encourage private people to donate to and help rectify what I believe is a very serious problem nationally, and a problem which obviously is of great importance in a personal sense. Further, the legislation functions as an incentive for the States to increases their own housing expenditure in these areas.

A significant aspect of this amendment, too, is the decision of the Federal Government to allow the States to nominate up to 100 per cent of the loan component of their State government borrowing program for public housing in 1987-88. This is a direct departure from the previous practice of the Federal Government to impose ceilings on the percentage of the Commonwealth grant to be used within the spheres of these two schemes. In the last financial year Queensland was restricted to using a mere 33 1/3 per cent of its grant for crisis housing. This was a reduction of the previous year's limit of 50 per cent. It is indeed imperative that the States be afforded this opportunity to nominate the relevant percentage of their grants that they deem necessary to cover their individual needs for public housing. This should be allowed in order to reflect the priorities and differing requirements of each State.

At this juncture I should also like to record my support for the measures the Government proposes to take which will effectively ensure that 50 per cent of the total funds will be directed toward public rental assistance, specifically, to make provision for the supply of affordable rental housing for those lower income families to whom I referred earlier. The Federal Government has also seen fit to take the responsible step of reviewing the income of the recipients of these benefits at regular intervals. This will ensure that those who are genuinely floundering in the mire of poverty are the ones being tossed the rope and dragged from almost certain annihilation.

Whilst this level of Federal Government intervention into State matters is indeed favourable, our major concern about this amendment Bill, as previous speakers from this side have suggested, focuses primarily on the power of the Federal Government to dictate the strategies that may be employed by State governments in the provision of specific housing assistance schemes. The power of the appropriate Federal Minister to reallocate grants from one State to another, or even back to the Commonwealth, should the Federal Government not agree with the procedures adopted by the State Government with respect to special purpose schemes, is a smack at State autonomy.

As I illustrated earlier in this speech, the housing poverty crisis varies from State to State. Therefore, a State Minister is the best person to have knowledge of these problems and take the appropriate measures to deal with them, rather than someone in a centralised bureaucracy in Canberra.

This broad brush treatment by the Federal Government of the States as a whole is ineffectual when seeking to fight the serious problems of poverty. If one maintains this metaphor of painting, the following argument clearly emerges: In art, it is the artist who is the only one possessing an intimate knowledge of his or her own work. While this does not preclude the art critic from passing judgment, the artist does, however, remain the only true authority on the work because of this close affiliation the artist has with the work. So too, the individual State governments possess this intimate knowledge of the areas of poverty and homelessness within their respective States and how best to tackle this problem. The Federal Government cannot hope to have the same intimate knowledge of each of the six States and the Northern Territory. Therefore, it should not have the power to make such autocratic decisions which ultimately determine the direction that financial assistance will take. On the basis of this argument then, the power of the Federal Government to interfere in State issues should be limited. And subsequently, State governments should be given more power so that they have the opportunity properly to govern the States.

As a final remark, I once again commend the Federal Government on recognising the plight of the low income families in their bid to secure a roof over their head and offer my support of the Government's move to provide assistance to this impoverished group. I do, however, suggest that the Government play down its Big Brother role in order to establish more of a partnership with respect to the States if they are to succeed in helping the homeless and poverty-stricken to escape from the concrete gaol of a modern megalopolis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Housing is a basic requirement of all members of our society. Sadly, it is not one which is universally met, even with the comprehensive programs which our Government has introduced. However, we are doing everything possible to ensure that shelter is provided to all categories of people, including those in crisis and without means. Amongst the general population there are many families who are unable to afford to buy a house or even to rent a home on the private rental market. For this reason and to help these people, the Hawke Labor Government has provided unprecedented levels of funding for public housing construction in conjunction with State governments, and I welcome that initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: While consistently working to reduce interest rates so that housing purchase would be more affordable, we have endeavoured to make available more public housing across Australia. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has also tackled the overheating of residential property purchase in major State capitals by clamping down on foreign investment in residential real estate. This initiative has been applauded by some honourable members opposite. The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has been a great success. Its triennial evaluation in 1986 concluded that public housing programs are generally efficient, effective and well targeted. The $700m guaranteed to State governments for the provision of public housing is $200m more than the base funding provided in the first triennium and 3 1/2 times more than the base level provided for in the Howard-Fraser Liberal Government's agreement in 1981.

The tortuous logic of the Opposition housing spokesman is beyond belief. He draws attention to the fact that the States with the largest amount of public housing are those with the longest queues. This phenomenon can be explained by the fact that the Labor States are much more likely to be flexible in their rules on eligibility for public housing. The increases have resulted from an increase in the number of people eligible-it is as simple as that-and those people include young single people who were previously ineligible in some States. Furthermore, increased awareness of available assistance and the deinstitutionalisation of aged and disabled people would certainly have lengthened the waiting lists.

I can distinctly recall some honourable members opposite calling for more public housing, often in the context of the home ownership debate. I am not quite sure whether their intention is to exclude poorer people from home ownership. In saying that, I exclude the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh).

Secure, affordable housing is what people require. Where the needy are concerned the private sector does not provide this except in rare circumstances. Even people on relatively high incomes would be nervous if they had to rely on the exigencies of the private rental market for tenure and stability in housing. This is not to say that private landlords are heartless; far from it. But their perspective is not that which places a priority on housing provision. Rather, they have invested in rental property and their primary concern is either profit or loss, depending on their taxation situation.

The honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) put her finger on the right point when she referred to the reduction in stigma attached to public housing. The better the quality and positioning of public housing, the more likely it is that low income families will seek to access it. For instance, if public housing is ghettoised and/or concentrated on the outskirts of cities away from centres of employment, people who need work will not be able to utilise it. The time it takes to commute to work will be too long or make it too difficult, given that public transport is often less than satisfactory in such areas.

The initiatives taken in the public housing and home ownership areas are excellent in the Labor States. The Commonwealth Government has also wholeheartedly supported the ambitions of Australians who want to buy a home through the assistance of the first home owners scheme. It is a nonsense for the Opposition to claim that the increased demand for public housing results necessarily from an increase in the inability of people to purchase a home. Where there is no hope of obtaining public housing, people will stop applying for it. They will resign themselves to high private rentals, or live at home with their extended family, with overcrowding resulting. The growth of available public housing encourages such people to register for accommodation.

Innovative schemes exist in States like Western Australia which protect public housing tenants and allow them securely to contemplate the extension of their position into home purchase. The first home owners grant can be used as a deposit or as mortgage repayment assistance for people in such circumstances. The Federal Government's initiative of the family package will combine with the first home owners scheme to lift the income of pensioners and low income working families to the point where they can realistically contemplate home ownership. Alternatively, they will be able to access rental assistance which can be offset against the cost of private rental. Such steps address the difficulties of pensioners and low income earners in a compassionate and realistic way.

Honourable members opposite bleat about the poor and people who cannot afford a home. They had their opportunity when they were in government, and they failed dismally. The people of Australia know that this Labor Government is committed to programs which provide housing for people in all walks of life when assistance of some type is required. We have tackled the problem of high interest rates inherited from those opposite. We have introduced and expanded the first home owners scheme, with 250,000 families being helped through its auspices. The income eligibility ceiling now takes account of the number of children in a family. This was an excellent initiative which I applauded at the time, as did many members on this side of the House. Private rental assistance is now provided to families in need and affordable public housing is available throughout the nation. Crisis accommodation is provided in as many areas as possible, as is local government and community housing.

The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement will be amended to ensure that all State matching contributions for home purchase assistance, and Loan Council nominated funds used for home purchase assistance, are channelled through the home purchase assistance account. The Government's intention to vet schemes that States bring into effect is very important. Although some of these schemes have existed in Western Australia for some time and have operated very well, it is important that the Commonwealth have an overview of them. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) referred to the Curtin, Chifley and Whitlam governments' commitment to public housing. This Housing Assistance Amendment Bill continues the Hawke Labor Government's commitment in the same area. I commend the Bill to the House. (Quorum formed)

That is $200m more than the base rate in 1984 when the previous triennium housing program was set up. It is 3 1/2 times more than the 1981 triennium housing program. Instead of restricting the States, the Government is opening up the rights of the States. Clearly there has to be some control if States are not adhering the the guidelines or if they are not going along with the special programs.

This legislation will guarantee that the Commonwealth can intervene, that it can retain or redirect that money, but it is giving the States the right to nominate up to 100 per cent of the loan component of their State government borrowing programs for public housing over the present financial year. The Government has worked out an agreement with the States that is economically realistic, that is realistic in terms of demand and that is addressing existing problems.

This Government introduced the local government and community housing program. I think in the first three years of that program $27m was made available. In the first year, $7m was provided because it was only part of a year, and $10m was made available in each of the following two years. Now, $11m is set aside in the 1988-89 and the 1989-90 period. Another $14m has been set aside for crisis accommodation. I do not believe the Commonwealth needs to hand over these projects to the States. We have seen what happened under the local government and community housing program in my own region of Mount Morgan. I welcome the changes to the Act the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) is bringing forward. I welcome the changes that will ensure action will be taken to make sure our rental stock is not depleted by sales. If something is sold it must be sold at or near replacement cost. I welcome also the fact that young people will be given access to public housing. I understand there has been an enormous demand. Problems have arisen when families have grown up in a public home and the husband has died. An elderly woman may be left in a three-bedroom home. In such cases there needs to be a relocation, a change in the approach that is taken at present. But we have to ensure that those in need are given access to public housing. That is what this legislation is about. The amendment brought forward by the Opposition is pathetic. Members opposite are grasping at straws.

It is quite amazing to attack this Government on its record on public housing. I suggest that the Opposition look at-I ask the Minister to look at this also-other areas that affect our people. Certainly, these problem areas are not ones resulting from this Government's policy on public housing. There are problems resulting from the loan arrangements in the private housing sector-a sector on which the honourable member for Barker seems to place all his reliance. For instance, in my State of Queensland a personal loan for a home can be taken out at 21 per cent but the moment the borrower defaults by one day on that payment under the loan agreement the interest rate rises to 31 per cent. It stays at 31 per cent. There is nothing we can do about that legally because the money lenders legislation in Queensland means nothing. The State Government has walked away from its responsibilities in that area.

I suggest also that this Government, whether it be by way of some sort of committee or simply through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, have a hard look at the deposit arrangements-the no deposit arrangements-into which some building societies are getting. I refer to the situation that occurred during the recent election campaign when one of my opponents was accused-there are statutory declarations to back this up-of putting people into housing by using a falsified deposit document. It said on the building society document that there was a 5 per cent deposit. However, the people concerned said that in fact they paid no deposit. What was happening was that $7,000 or $8,000 was being added to the house price. This was then being subtracted as the alleged deposit.

I suggest also that we undertake some sort of program, particularly in the private purchase area, to convince people and to educate people about the money they can save by restructuring their repayment programs, particularly by restructuring them on a fortnightly basis. I also believe that we ought to have a hard look at the situation whereby people buying a home can be forced into using a particular solicitor. I suggest that needs to be referred to the Trade Practices Commission because I believe that that is a restrictive trade practice. The same sorts of rules prevent people from doing their own conveyancing. I question whether that should be so. Finally, I refer to the way in which the banks hold up the interest on loans that people take out. It is strange that whenever there is an economic problem the banks are quick to force up interest rates but when things are on the way down they hold existing rates as long as they can. They make many millions of dollars because of that.

Setting aside those matters, it is clear that this Government has taken the initiative to overcome the problems in the housing industry. This is the Government that has recognised the long waiting lists for housing. This is the Government that has made available money to the States to allow them to get at that problem, because these matters are best dealt with from a State administrative point of view. However, the funding has to come from the Commonwealth. Again, this is the Government that has made sure that that funding is available. I believe that the Minister and the Government should be commended for their initiatives. I find it rather strange that the Opposition should bring forward such a pathetic amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 October, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
