TALK.START.PARA: —The Management and Investment Companies Legislation Bill before the House is not opposed by the Opposition. Indeed, the management and investment company (MIC) program was introduced as an initiative by the former Government. David Thomson, who was the Minister for Science at the time, was responsible for putting together the Espie High Technology Financing Committee which ultimately reported to the new government, and the bipartisan approach was continued with the establishment of the MIC program. It is a refreshing adventure into the business world and has been one of the success stories of a bipartisan approach in which some common understanding of the rather poor levels of venture capital and high technology development in this nation was addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refresh honourable members' memories of what the MIC program is about. The MIC program was directed to promote the establishment and development of a private sector venture capital market in Australia and to encourage management and financial support for the start-up and early growth of Australian based enterprises which had the potential to grow rapidly into substantial businesses, were export oriented and used innovative technology. A venture capital company under the MIC program must be staffed by a multi-disciplinary team of professionals possessing management, financial, marketing and technical skills. A venture capital company-this is always a loosely defined and thrown around term-must provide patient, professional equity investment in a portfolio of potentially high growth businesses, add value through management participation and seek high capital gains on disinvestment. These terms were applied as part of the criteria by the Licensing Board which was established so that those corporations which sought to be included under this program could apply and be judged on their merits.

The MIC Licensing Board was established by the Commonwealth Parliament to administer the program within the terms of the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983. The licensing of MICs was to raise an approved level of tax deductible capital. A tax incentive-a deduction of 100 per cent of the amount invested-was offered to subscribers to new shares in MIC. The investment by MICs in businesses was certified by the Licensing Board against the criteria set out in the legislation. MICs invest in businesses as wide ranging as biotechnology, communications and other major areas of advancement. Any potential investee business must possess the following significant features: firstly, the use of innovative technology; secondly, an export orientation; thirdly, international competitiveness; fourthly, the potential for rapid growth; and, finally, the potential for creating skilled employment in Australia. There are no restrictions on who may actually invest in MICs.

To date 11 companies are licensed under the Act. All these companies have participated in the four capital raisings of $40m as determined by the MIC Licensing Board. Up to 31 May 1987, which is the last figure I have, some $176m had been raised. In the main that has been done by the division of $40m per year by four. Additional subscriptions have been raised, primarily by CP Ventures Ltd from non-taxpaying institutions, to top this up.

The legislation before the House gives rise to two significant changes. Firstly, it allows any of the 11 existing companies under the MIC scheme to withdraw from the scheme without affecting their tax position under the scheme. However, as honourable members would be aware, the clawback provision allows any member that subscribes for capital under this scheme under the licensed $40m per year to claim the whole amount as a tax deduction in the year of subscription. If a member seeks to sell shares before the four-year period elapses, the clawback provision enables the Australian Taxation Office to disallow past deductions, depending on whether it is the first, second, third or fourth year.

Under this legislation the taxation provisions still apply to the investor but the company is able to move out of the scheme and, by doing so, is able to raise capital beyond that which is set down to it under the licensing provision. Currently, MICs may raise from their investors only the amount of the $40m a year that is allotted to them by the Licensing Board. Let us assume that the 11 companies are limited to $4m each per year. They may not go to the public to raise capital beyond that amount. Under reasonable market conditions, in a successful mode companies could be expected to raise a lot more than that-that is, their licensing entitlement plus what they could raise from the market-place. However, CP Ventures and one or two others have been able to raise additional money from non-taxpaying institutions.

This Bill enables companies to go beyond the set amount and raise additional money. This would have been far more applicable under reasonable market conditions, but today share prices are down so low that very few of the 11 MICs are selling above par. As a consequence, the ability to act under this provision is now extremely limited. It is regrettable that this provision was not implemented a year ago when the MICs started pressuring for it. This would have enabled companies under very optimistic market circumstances to raise a substantial amount of money to help carry through their programs. It would have put them in a funded position for many years to come. Under this Bill they are now allowed to go beyond the $40m entitlement per year to spread the deduction; in other words, the amount of money that was first contributed to that company is allowed as a deduction and all sums after that are purely capital subscribed. The beauty of this provision is that it will enable some companies to carry on. It certainly will be of benefit to corporations in the very difficult conditions that confront the share market today and will continue to confront the share markets of the world for some time to come. Under those circumstances, I think the action taken in this Bill is correct, though late.

The whole basis of the MIC scheme was to encourage investment in companies meeting the criteria I mentioned: use of innovation technology; export orientation; competitiveness; rapid growth; and the creation of skilled employment in Australia. It is not possible to establish those sorts of investments quickly. It will take one or two years to identify the areas of investment and to put together the team of management that is necessary to handle the diversity of the investments, to see the companies through the establishment period and to make the capital investment and management decisions that are required in these companies. There have been some very notable successes, but they have taken time to mature. I refer here to some of the investee companies that Techniche Ltd has been able to partake in. One is the Agen Co. which recently made a significant breakthrough in the area of blood testing by developing a simple device which I think will make a major contribution to the diagnosis of certain major ailments these days and will also lend itself to international sales.

Other developments through the range of these companies will inevitably flow on, in the areas of high tech computers and transport. But there have been some notable failures. One of the most amusing MIC investee companies is none other than Amann Aviation Pty Ltd which we have heard so much about in recent times. It certainly must have missed the bus for management techniques and a few of the other qualifying factors for an MIC company, but it certainly got some innovative thinking going at the former Department of Aviation even if it did not get any out of the MIC scheme.

At the moment there is a crisis within the capital markets of the world. Any innovative company is undoubtedly, a risk taker. When people invest in risk companies they are very aware that not only are they placing their moneys behind a venture which may or may not succeed, but also they are placing themselves in an area of international competition which, at present, is subject to all sorts of vagaries; in other words, government protections, currency movements and commodity price movements.

Because of that we, in Australia, found in the lead up to the events in October a very rapid development of corporations, not only those companies that took advantage of the MIC scheme but also the many companies that joined the second boards of the Australian stock exchanges. That innovation was not in place two years ago. Those companies which came on to the boards with a lesser capital requirement than the stock exchanges needed and, in some cases, with a Country Party voting system to enable them to protect themselves against unwanted predators, were looking for extra venture money to support programs which certainly carried many question marks. They varied from fish ventures to building materials, boating ventures, holiday and leisure activities, some manufacturing ventures and a wide range of others.

As a consequence of the recent stock market crash a lot of those companies will not succeed as the capital will not be available to them. As they disappear from the boards, the strength of this program will be seen for what it is. People will not go into those areas of investment. Areas that offer a tax deduction, some proven track record and some sense of real performance will be taken up by investors and the remainder will feel the pinch of a declining entrepreneurial spirit and a declining inclination by investors to participate in the market-place because of the many problems that undoubtedly will be with us over the coming years.

I would now like to draw attention to the conflicting points of view put forward by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It is well known that the Treasurer tried to put this scheme to bed or, more appropriately, send it to the cemetery some time ago. But to the everlasting credit of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, it will survive until at least 30 June 1989. Finally we are seeing some recognition of the fact that the sorts of investments that have gone on through the MIC scheme are very much in the national interest. What can be done is shown by the establishment work of the Management Investment Companies Licensing Board, the sorts of people to whom it has granted licences and the direction in which the 11 companies which have undertaken the scheme have applied themselves.

I hope that the review of corporate tax, to which this scheme will be subject, recognises the enormous amount of work that has gone into it. I am also hopeful that the Government will not move hastily to chop it off. Investment over a period of three to four years will not allow maturity in a business or in a company without appropriate support. It is also worth noting that the Chairman of the Licensing Board, Mr Ward-Ambler, wrote to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce concerning a report relating to the MIC scheme by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) within that Department. The letter states:

The Board has concluded the BIE report is flawed . . . The conclusions, recommendations and executive summary by no means fully accord with much of the factual and evidential material elsewhere in the report.

Since the release of that report it has been impossible for those involved with the MICs to develop any long term plan for company development. Only recently Senator Button was able to hold the position of the MICs until next year. Undoubtedly the forthcoming corporate tax review had a great deal to do with the decision to extend that position for only one year. But for the tax review it is certain that Senator Button would have won from the Cabinet an extension of the life of the scheme, at least for another two years. By doing that he would have assured the success of many of the very small embryo research-based corporations that have begun to spring up.

In short, at a time of great uncertainty in the share market, at a time when capital raising will be extraordinarily hard to meet and at a time when a scheme has been in place for four years and has proven successful, it would be a great pity indeed to see shortcomings of misjudgment by the Treasurer and bickerings between him and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce allowed to proceed at the expense of what I regard as a great innovation in this area by both the former Government and the current Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I can tell, the Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill, which is before the House, is fairly non-controversial. I believe that it is supported by the Opposition and, as I understand it, it is supported by and large by the participants in the venture capital market. I have had an opportunity to speak to a number of participants in the management investment companies (MIC) program and the legislation seems to be regarded as something which is necessary and desirable to make it possible for MICs to exit the program in a reasonably orderly fashion. The legislation itself aims to amend the Management and Investment Companies Act and also the Income Tax Assessment Act in order to:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) permit a MIC to raise non-tax concessional capital in conjunction with tax concessional capital; and
(ii) enable a MIC to exit the program without triggering the tax clawback arrangements by surrendering its licence.

I do not think there is any great argument about those provisions. They were part of a package of decisions with regard to the future of the program that were announced by the Government on 6 October. Those announcements included a decision to extend the program until 30 June 1989. Thereafter the future of the program is to be considered under the auspices of the Review of Business Taxation which is taking place at the moment. There is also to be a continuation of the upper limit of $20m per annum in revenue forgone. That was the Government's position as at 6 October 1987. At this stage we do not have a firm decision in regard to the future of the program after 1989.

The MIC program was an attempt to address certain deficiencies in the functioning of the Australian capital market, particularly as it affects the so-called venture capital market which, prior to the introduction of the MIC program, was virtually non-existent, the point being that there was a need for entities that could provide risk capital for ventures, particularly in high technology and export oriented areas. There was a perceived lack of managerial expertise in many of those new ventures and it was felt that there was a need for a new type of structure in the capital market which could address those problems.

I guess it would have to be said that the MIC program was not envisaged as having a permanent life; it was seen as something that would provide a catalytic role and lead to the creation of a venture capital market which would exist, to a large degree, outside the MIC program. There is a fair amount of evidence to suggest that that has started to occur. The figure on the growth of the venture capital market-there is a bit of argument about how one defines that term-was $2m as at 30 June 1983 and, as at 31 March 1987, it had expanded to $310m. Over that period it has gone from virtual non-existence to being something reasonably substantial. Undoubtedly, the management and investment company program has been a major element in that growth. The figures are set out in the report entitled Review of venture capital in Australia and the MIC Program, which was prepared by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE). The projection for the year ending 31 March 1988 is for a venture capital market of some $570m. Obviously, in the light of the subsequent stock market collapse, the figure will need to be revised. I do not think that anybody disputes that the management investment company program has contributed to the development of the venture capital market in a major and substantial way.

One important feature of the program is the limitation in the revenue loss that can arise from the 100 per cent tax concession for investment in management and investment companies. A maximum limit of $20m per annum is set. There has been a cumulative revenue cost to government of some $60m since the program was first introduced. The future of the program was addressed in the report which was presented by the BIE in July this year. The report was fairly extensive although, as I understand it, it was prepared within a fairly short period. The Bureau ended up recommending two possible options as to the future of the program. One was the effective ending of the program in mid-1988 and the second was the ending of the program in mid-1990.

Obviously, those recommendations are controversial. The various arms of government and the various departments have different views about the issue. The MIC Licensing Board has its own views and those are set out in the report. It is clear that there is a fair diversity of views on the future of the program. That is something we need to address. Now that the future of the program is to be placed under the broad heading of the review of business taxation, which is overwhelmingly a Treasury exercise with, as I understand it, very little input from other departments, there is a legitimate concern, I feel, about whether we will get an adequate consideration of the issues concerned. The Treasury's view is set out on page 120 of the report. I quote one sentence:

The Treasury submission takes the view that the emergence of Second Board markets and non-MIC equity investment companies suggests that there is no longer any significant gap in venture capital markets.

That is an immensely controversial proposition which is disputed by the Licensing Board. It is disputed strongly by participants in the venture capital market. The fact that, apparently, the program is to be considered almost solely by Treasury, in terms of the preparation of recommendations to government, is a major potential area of concern.

A number of things have emerged regarding the nature of the venture capital market and these are set out in the BIE's report. One of the arguments used by those who believe that the need for the MIC program has diminished significantly is that the MIC share of the total venture capital market has fallen reasonably consistently. It is still very substantial, but now slightly less than half of the venture capital market is accounted for by MICs.

Another feature of the program that has emerged is that it remains the case that individuals are the main sources of capital for MICs. There is still relatively little support from institutions. Although there is evidence of increasing support from institutions, it is still small. That remains a concern. There is also some interesting information about the respective role of the MIC and non-MIC components of the venture capital market. It is clear that the MICs play a large role in the start-up phase of ventures and their early development. In so doing, they clearly address a deficiency which existed previously in the market. The MICs have also tended to place a greater emphasis on the provision of management support in the venture capital market than have non-MIC participants. Those are some of the features of the role of the MICs which indicate that they have helped to fill a significant gap in the Australian capital market.

The key question concerns the appropriateness of terminating the program. The Bureau of Industry Economics, in its review, essentially came down in favour of terminating it. The program was envisaged, at its inception, as not having a permanent life. However, I guess it is a question of when the program is terminated. The BIE wants to terminate it in the relatively short term. It gave the options of mid-1988 or mid-1990. The Bureau referred to rapid expansion and the availability of venture capital both inside and outside the MIC program, the argument being that the evidence of a so-called venture capital gap is diminishing strongly.

To put this into perspective, it is important to compare Australia with the United States of America. According to the report's figures, we were looking at a venture capital market of some $300m as at March this year. The United States has a venture capital market of the order of $27 billion. If that comparison has any validity, even taking account of the great difference in the size of the respective economies, it seems to suggest that in Australia there is still a much smaller venture capital market than one could regard as optimal. It is also worth noting that with the stock market downturn, the fairly optimistic prediction of the size of the venture capital market next year will have to be revised. The estimate in the Bureau's report was $570m. Of course, since the stock market collapse there has been an enormous change. I will quote briefly from an article which appeared on page 38 of yesterday's Australian Financial Review under the heading `Venture capital drought will hurt hi-tech sector':
High technology companies are set to be the hardest hit in the current stock market crisis as venture capital dries up and investors pull out of high risk enterprises.
Already, numerous high technology floats have been aborted and the share price of many listed technology companies has plummeted.
Observers are forecasting the failure of a number of the more blue-sky ventures.
The second board is now no longer an option for those companies and sources of potential finance are dwindling fast.

So it does seem that the stock market crash has had a significant impact on the venture capital market, the long term implications of which are not clear at the moment. Nonetheless, it does seem to suggest that there is a need to look at this issue anew. I refer also to a report of the Bureau of Industry Economics which, on page 72, makes reference to the possibility of a bad turn in the stock market:

A downturn in the share market could lead to a loss of interest by investors in such companies as well as in young high-risk businesses. Some businesses interviewed felt that, in these circumstances, the availability of equity capital from the MICs would be vital to the development of young companies.

I understand I have to finish now, but I really do think that the future of the program needs to be looked at very carefully. Given the Treasury's well-known prejudices, or views, on the matter, it is of some concern that it will have almost exclusive carriage of the preparation of recommendations to the Government on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill follows consideration by the Government of a review of the management and investment companies (MIC) program by the Bureau of Industry Economics. As the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) suggested, the Opposition does support the Bill. The particular thrust of the Bill is, since the program has always been seen as a seeding or kick-starting measure, to provide a suitable phasing out mechanism to allow a management and investment company to leave the program-stand on its own feet, without benefit of the tax concession in its raising of capital-in an orderly and non-prejudicial fashion. The amendments in the Bill to promote this are essentially to permit management and investment companies to raise non-tax concessional capital, and to enable them to exit the program without their investors losing the benefit of their initial tax concession.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has supported this program since its inception. It sprang originally from an initiative of the Minister for Science in the Fraser Government, the Hon. David Thompson, who commissioned the report of the High Technology and Financing Committee, under the chairmanship of Sir Frank Espie of CRA Ltd, who headed up a committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences. The report was completed and presented in the context of the 1983 election campaign, and the Hawke Government, on its accession to office, finally picked it up and legislated for the establishment of these management and investment companies in late 1983. The complementary tax measure was enacted in the nick of time, in June 1984, so that the program really got going in 1983-84.

The purpose of the program, as the honourable member for Sydney and others have said, was to promote the establishment and development of a private sector venture capital market in Australia. Its centrepiece was the formation of management and investment companies, called MICs, and that was to be fostered by the provision of a tax incentive to encourage investors to subscribe capital in them. The incentive was that such subscriptions were 100 per cent tax deductible in the year that the capital was subscribed. In turn, the role of management and investment companies was to invest in new, fledgling, high technology, export-oriented and potentially fast growing businesses. I take this opportunity to stress that the selecting of investments and decisions on risk taking, the picking of winners and losers in this area, frequently a high technology area, are thus matters for the private sector and the market-place, where they properly belong.

The role of these management and investment companies is also to afford new businesses-the honourable member for Sydney also stressed this-not only finance but also management, technological and marketing assistance. Provision was made for a board to license management and investment companies as part of a mechanism for limiting the cost of the tax concession to the Government. Still, that board's role is minimal in the whole scheme of things, and so it has been virtually a 100 per cent private sector operation-as was originally intended. Within this framework the quantum of tax deductible capital subscribed has been limited to the order of $40m each year, at a cost to the Government in tax forgone of the order of $20m a year. To date some 11 companies have been licensed. There are some well known names amongst them, including BT Innovation Ltd, Continental Venture Capital Ltd, Western Pacific Investment Co. Ltd, and so on.

In recent times the program has been under something of a cloud, with threats to terminate it. The Government decision reflected in this legislation to continue the program at least to 30 June 1989 is welcomed by the Opposition. That decision-I go back to the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) when introducing the Bill-reflects the Government's view that while the program has stimulated an increased availability of venture capital, to quote the Minister:
. . . the Government remains unconvinced as to the durability of the venture capital market if the MIC program were to be terminated at this time . . .
The Minister went on to refer to three factors that the Government took into consideration when reaching its decision. They are, again to quote the Minister:

. . . firstly, many of the new non-MICs are still a good deal smaller than the MICs and with only a limited amount of capital available; secondly, the MICs, unlike the non-MICs, focus their investments primarily at the more risky start-up and early growth stages of business development, with emphasis upon technology-based and export-oriented industries-
I will come back to that in a moment-
thirdly, MICs appear to devote more time towards providing management support than the non-MICs.

This was a part of the whole concept. I want to return to that statement of the Minister that the management and investment companies focus their investments primarily on the more risky start-up and early growth phase. There is out there in the market-place a widespread perception that in fact even though the management and investment companies enjoy this considerable tax concession in raising capital, they are not giving sufficient support to the really risky end of the operation. The Minister went on in his speech to say:

. . . while financial deregulation had resulted in greater flexibility and competition within the financial system, this had not yet, to any great extent, flowed over into the high risk venture capital market, but had mainly benefited the more traditional areas of financial activity.

That reflects the perception I referred to a moment ago that the management and investment program itself, while commendable and something which, as I say, the Opposition supports and welcomes the continuation of, is perhaps not adequately catering for the very high risk end of the market. When speaking recently to the chairman of a merchant banking group the question was put, `Why are you fellows not doing more of what you are supposed to do, which is supporting the high risk projects?'. The answer that was given by that gentleman was, `Well, we had to be in this program, but our reputation is so high we cannot afford a failure'. I do not contend that that necessarily reflects the attitude of principals associated with all management and investment companies but to the extent that it is representative of the situation it certainly is not good enough. I simply report this perception that is in the community to some extent and trust that the more risky end will be better catered for. The Minister went on to state:
The Government believes that the key to the long term viability of the venture capital market lies with its ability to attract funds from the major financial institutions.
The institutions have begun to show an increased interest in venture capital but it is still very tentative.

It is even more tentative now because today we are debating this measure in the context of the current stock exchange downturn. An alternative to venture capital provided by an institution-management and investment company, or otherwise-which has boomed in recent times in the context of the bull share market, has been listing on the second board. But with this historic stock exchange downturn it is now well-nigh impossible to find an underwriter for an issue, a float, on the second board, or indeed on the first board for that matter, and most such floats that were in the pipeline have been aborted. This greatly increases direct pressure on the management and investment companies and the particular sources of venture capital. I do not refer only to demands from entirely new projects but also to those from existing enterprises which have received initial funding and which now need further support for expansion.

The fact is that the availability of the second board has virtually dried up. One can only lament that the excesses of the `casino economy'-I do not often appropriate a term of the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions but I think this one has some merit-that the excesses of the recent bull run on the world stock exchanges and the suddenness and magnitude of the inevitable reaction, probably not fully played out yet, should have such an inhibiting and indeed disastrous effect on this sector of the real economy: the small, new, often high technology, export oriented, and employment creating businesses struggling to get established and to expand. I have some very close associations with a number of them. It is a sector which doubtless includes companies which will be among Australia's large, front rank, export-oriented manufacturing companies of the future.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I conclude by saying that I commend the Government for extending the scheme. It is regrettable that notwithstanding the ravages of inflation, the funding of the program-namely, $20m per annum in revenue forgone-has remained the same since its inception in the 1983-84 financial year. Nevertheless, it was never intended as other than a seeding program to encourage the development of a private sector venture capital market. That is happening -though, on the basis of my direct experience and the anecdotal evidence, not to the extent that one would have hoped for. Nevertheless in all the circumstances the Opposition supports this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The author of that article has written a number of fallacious articles about the tax performance of companies. They are fallacious, to the extent that their implications are fallacious, not the record. There is this immature view, which comes from a lack of understanding of the tax system and is obviously widespread, that the 49 per cent company rate is paid on the gross company income of companies. It is not. It is paid on the balance that is left after legitimate allowances are made for depreciation, cost depreciation and any other provisions of the tax law that apply. That 49 per cent, which applies on the net, may then be calculated to seem to be 26 per cent or so on the gross, but the fact is that it is the appropriate rate of tax. It is that issue which the Government is currently looking at in the business tax review-that is, whether or not Australia would benefit from the trade-off in having fewer deductions but a lower company tax rate.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that corporate tax has risen substantially under this Government, because of the fact that there has been more activity and higher profits and we have broadened the tax base. The other hare which the author of the article set running a year or so ago, which is essentially the same hare, is that if a company owned nothing other than, say, Australian blue-chip shares and its income was exclusively dividend income, it would pay no tax. Its tax would be zero because it gets its section 46 rebate. I thought that the honourable member for Reid would understand that, because I have made that point to him on a number of occasions. Perhaps he is interested in educating coalition members on the point. Let me continue educating them.

Many of the entrepreneurial companies own mostly shares in other companies. Therefore, much of their earnings, being dividends, are protected against further tax-that is, they are not taxed again and, if they pass to another company, again. If they were taxed at 49 per cent once and then passed to a company and taxed at 49 per cent again, and then to another company and taxed at 49 per cent, in the end there would be nothing. There is a thing called a section 46 rebate, so that once the primary company tax is paid, that rebate is carried through to other companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are taxed too much.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar may not interject at will. All interjections are out of order, and continued interjections are disorderly.

—Some of the entrepreneurial companies own operating companies in their own right. The fact is that the tax which is payable is the tax payable on that part of the company's earnings which come from the operating business that it has.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, there are all sorts of issues through which one cannot peer, such as debt and prior operating losses, and all of these other things are bound up; but the fact of the matter is that the Australian corporate tax base is tighter, better protected and stronger now than it ever has been. That is why, if one adjusts the tax paid on the gross operating surplus and adjusts it for interest rates and depreciation, and for the heightened interest rates through the late 1970s and the early 1980s, one will find that, on an adjusted basis, the tax on company income in gross domestic product is rising and has been rising since 1983.

I have published a paper by the Treasury on this subject, which anyone in the House is welcome to. That is the position. It is a very poor form of journalism to lay an issue like this out-to throw the dead cat on the road and not explain why the section 46 rebate operates, and how it is entirely possible to have a company which owns a dividend stream from a public company which should pay no tax whatsoever; that the tax rate should be zero for a company which owns nothing but dividend income. TALK.START.PARA: —Just to keep him alert, I direct my question also to the Treasurer. How does he reconcile his warm endorsement of this New South Wales Budget with the need to restrain public sector demand and release resources for use in the private sector in today's uncertain economic climate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is old fiscal rectitude himself. This is the crowd who, 12 weeks ago, were running for the lick of their lives to the electoral wire with $6 billion of unfunded tax cuts flitting around the landscape, and saying `The balanced budget? Don't worry about that'. I remember the debates in here when the Prime Minister told the Leader of the Opposition that we would fight the election on tax, and the Leader of the Opposition said, `We'll see who will fight the election on tax'. Then we asked what the Opposition's tax policy was and were told that we would find out at the right moment. The right moment was, in typical Ash Street style, three weeks before the end of a campaign in which the Leader of the Opposition thought that he could dodge every journalist asking sensible questions about how it would be funded. He thought that a bit of slick gab and slick talk and dodging the questions would get him to the electoral wire and that as Prime Minister he would simply say--

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker, concerning section 145, which deals with relevance. The question quite clearly referred to the problems facing Australia related to the New South Wales Budget. We have not heard one word about that, and the Treasurer does not want to talk about it.
—I am sure that you will.

—We have got to the stage where the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party of Australia have to be protected from answers by the honourable member for O'Connor. If that is their position, fine.
—I just want you to answer the question.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—The Opposition made a dash to the electoral wire with an irresponsible policy which would have destroyed all confidence in our financial markets. When a poll in the middle of the election campaign showed some movement to the coalition, the exchange rate moved rapidly down and everyone on the market was saying that that was the reason. It was obvious to all and sundry that such a policy would have destroyed much of the adjustment process that the Government had undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: It is against that background that the right honourable member for New England has had the hide to put this question. Let me make this point, which I made yesterday and will make again. This has been the first government to pull the States back into line. In taking the brunt of the burden of the fall in the public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR) by cutting our own expenditure in unprecedented ways, we have also urged the States to cut theirs and to cut their borrowings. We took a $1,000m cut off the States at the Premiers Conference, a cut of 21 per cent in their borrowings. Their borrowing program went back by 21.4 per cent. Let me record again that in 1982-83, the State's public sector borrowing requirement was 3.6 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). In other words, in the last year of the last Government, of which the right honourable member for New England and the honourable member for Bennelong were leading members, the PSBR on the States' account was 3.6 per cent of GDP. In 1987-88, we expect that to be 1.8 per cent or, in terms of net PSBR, just over 2 per cent, now that all the State budgets have been presented. On the recurrent side, there is a cut of $1,000m on the part of the Commonwealth to the States recurrent budgets.

New South Wales has borne that. New South Wales has complied happily with those changes. It complied with the changes to borrowings, the cuts to Commonwealth outlays to the States and $300m of specific purpose payments as well. All of a sudden its Budget is supposed to become an issue, according to the people who vandalised Australian public policy and would have done so again given the opportunity in July.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support to inform the House as to what steps are being taken by the Government to facilitate radio services for the massive influx of Japanese tourists into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question.
—What about radio services for outback Australia?
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.
—He should be doing something about television for outback Australia.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will not argue with the Chair. He has been interjecting ad nauseam. We will not have any more.

—I am pleased to be able to advise the house that the Government has today issued a licence to enable a personalised radio service aimed specifically at Japanese tourists to be operated in this country. It will be a Japanese language service carrying news and information about tourist activities, Australian history, customs, lifestyle, music and human interest material to Japanese tourists. It will also be a commercial outfit which will broadcast advertisements enabling Australian manufacturers and suppliers to target Japanese tourist customers more specifically than occurs at present. The service is to be operated by a firm called Fidelity Communications Corporation Ltd and is part of the video and audio entertainment and information services system which is being developed by the Department of Transport and Communications.

ANSWER.PARA: More than 300,000 Japanese people are expected to visit Australia in 1988. Currently, I understand, Australia services about 35 per cent of the world Japanese tourist market, which is a pretty significant sector of that market. The new service is intended to ensure that we can promote tourism by Japanese in this country. I am sure that this development will be an important contribution to ensuring that we can facilitate that tourist boom. As well as enabling our Japanese visitors to appreciate better their stay in Australia, it must also be remembered that the so-called Travrad service will have a significantly beneficial impact upon our balance of trade situation through its support of the Australian tourist and retail sectors. I think this is an important initiative. It is one that should be welcomed by all members of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support acknowledge that the aviation route distance limitations he tabled yesterday confirm the monopoly created to and from Christmas Island for the Ansett Airlines and Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd BAE146s, a monopoly defended in another place on allegedly technical grounds by Senator Evans? Would the Minister now specifically indicate what other available civil aircraft types can supposedly fly the route as suggested in this House by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy?

—Not everybody has the same sort of attitude to the world as the honourable member, who seems to see a conspiracy coming around every corner. The situation is quite simple. Those air navigation regulations are not new regulations, as the honourable member knows. They were not--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. At no point did I suggest that they are new regulations. I simply pointed out that they confirm a monopoly.
—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member should not raise frivolous points of order.

—The implication in the honourable member's question was that in some way the air navigation regulation had been made in some strange way to meet the situation at Christmas Island, which is an utter fabrication. The situation, quite simply, is that the agreement that has been made was made in accordance with the Air Navigation Regulations, the safety regulations, that have applied long term in this country. If we had stepped in any way outside those regulations, then the Opposition would have been down on us like a ton of bricks. We have not done that. We have complied with them properly. The agreement that was reached was reached with the intention, quite specifically, of upholding those regulations. That is what we have done and, while I am the Minister, that is what we will continue to do. We will uphold the air navigation safety regulations in this nation.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Standing Orders require, clearly, that an answer shall be relevant. The Minister still has not answered what other types of aircraft can fly on the route.
—Order! The Minister has answered the question. The honourable member has no point of order.

—Is the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel aware that probably for the first time in its history the Royal Australian Navy has appointed a woman as an executive officer at an operational base? Can the Minister advise the House of opportunities available for the employment and promotion of women in the Australian Defence Force?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I congratulate one of his constituents, Lieutenant-Commander Sandra Coulson, who I understand is being promoted to the rank of commander at the end of this year and will be second in charge of HMAS Platypus. She is a very good example of the sort of encouragement that women in the Services receive in aspiring to higher positions. The Government is committed to expanding opportunities and career prospects for women. We have seen an increase in the numbers of women in the Australian Defence Force over the last few years. For example, from July 1984 to July 1987 the figures have gone from 4,673 to 6,239. Promotional opportunities are open for women for the position of brigadier and equivalent and 35 per cent of officer positions are open to women. In fact, from July 1984 to October 1987 we have seen an increase of 50 per cent in the number of women officers in the Australian Defence Force and the positions of major equivalent and above have increased by 60 per cent in that period. Women in the Services are making a very important contribution. Their services are valued and we look forward to giving them many opportunities in the future to play an increasing role. Women in the Services have a greater opportunity to do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support and is supplementary to the question asked by the honourable member for Bruce. If in fact the reason for the documents being drawn as they were is the reason stated by the Minister, why was it that in order to comply with the Air Navigation Regulations the document simply did not state a maximum weight and associated specifications requirement rather than specifically naming a particular aircraft? If the former course had been followed it would have been possible for any aircraft to have complied with those requirements.

—All I can answer for is the advice that my Department gave, which is all honourable members could expect me to do. The situation is that the Air Navigation Regulations are quite clear on this matter. It is quite clear that aircraft such as 737s do not comply with the Air Navigation Regulations. It is quite clear that aircraft such as F28s do not comply directly with the Air Navigation Regulations. In those circumstances, my understanding of the situation is that the aircraft which was discussed and which did comply was the aircraft that was named in the agreement. The agreement provides for an aircraft which complies with the Air Navigation Regulations.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of reports in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald that Inspector Noel Dwyer, a former head of the Queensland Police Licensing Branch, stated in evidence given to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct that he believed that telephone calls to the office of the former Police Commissioner, Sir Terence Lewis, were taped `mainly for accuracy'? Will the Attorney-General ask the Australian Federal Police to contact the Acting Queensland Police Commissioner and Sir Terence Lewis to ensure that these claims that Federal law on telephone interceptions has been breached are thoroughly investigated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements which are alleged to have been made before the Fitzgerald inquiry. Allegations were made and it does not necessarily follow that there is direct evidence that what was alleged did in fact happen. The law provides that, if there is an interception of a telephone communication, it is an offence. The other point is that it is also an offence to record a conversation unless the person at the other end is aware that it is being recorded. Honourable members would be aware that I would not express any other opinion on this matter. But if there is any suggestion of further investigation that would be a matter for the Australian Federal Police to look at.

ANSWER.PARA: This gives me the opportunity to mention another matter. Recently we passed an amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to provide that, in future, illegal interceptions would not be admitted in evidence. In our original submission to the Parliament proposed section 64 provided that, where current proceedings were in place, we would still allow the existing law to apply. That is deemed to be the law, as in Hilton v. Wells, where the court would have a discretion as to whether it would admit illegal evidence. It now transpires that some matters that are pending are in jeopardy because, at that time, the Opposition felt--

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Some matters are in jeopardy because proposed section 64 was objected to. I know that the Opposition does not think that is the position but it is clear that the section 64 we had in place would have allowed the prosecutions to continue. These matters are in jeopardy now and we have not really proclaimed the Act on the basis that we think current criminal proceedings ought to be the subject of further prosecution. We will rely on that law again being amended. I understand that the Opposition is prepared to reconsider its position. If so, I would be anxious to introduce a further amendment so that those matters would be able to proceed.
—Our policy is unchanged.
—The Opposition's policy was very clear. It did not understand the point, to the extent--
—Yes, we did.
—The Opposition objected to proposed section 64.
—No.
—I would welcome the opportunity now to know whether the Opposition will co-operate with what we originally intended. That is the position.
—You have a talk with him.

—I do not need to talk to the honourable member for Flinders because the matter was debated here. It will be illegal to have telephone intercepts once the Act is proclaimed. People will also be unable to introduce tapes of telephone intercepts as evidence. But, in the interim, we need to cover existing prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. During Question Time the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in referring to the taxation policy of the Liberal Party of Australia at the last election-he specifically identified me with that policy-made the quite inaccurate statement that that policy represented an exercise in supply side economics. This is a claim that the Treasurer has falsely made on a number of occasions and I take this opportunity to reject that claim. In support of that I point out that commonly understood supply side economics state that if one cuts tax the additional economic activity generated by the incentive effects of that cut in tax is enough to pay for the tax cut.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never embraced a policy based upon supply side economics. We did not do so in the last election and we would not do so in the future. I point out that in the costing of our taxation policy less than one-seventh of the total costing was to be paid for from incentive effects. That figure was judged by the Institute of Policy Studies at the Monash University to have been on the conservative side. Our tax package was to be paid for by spending cuts, not by an exercise in supply side voodooism. To the extent that the Treasurer-or indeed anybody else-because his notions have received some support in some sections of the Press, has said it, he is yet again wrong and the Australian Labor Party myth machine about the nature of coalition economic policies once again is working overtime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled-The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.

Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to: Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experimentations on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Ian Robinson and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners respectfully sheweth.

That the introduction of an Identity Card, to be called the Australia Card, and a National Identification Numbering System, is not in keeping with the established rights, privileges and customs of the Australian people.

We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Macphee and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating tax evasion, illegal immigration or in social security fraud;

that we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax evasion and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
that we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Porter and Mr White.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities. They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that The House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
About the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should not be considered any further, and in the event of it coming again before parliament it should be rejected because:

PETITION.TITLE: Treatment of Sun Damaged Skin and Warts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBOs) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and a war base.
Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communication facilities for CIA activity in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other country's governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap. These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Industrial Relations Bill will increase industrial disputation, bankrupt companies, and give the union movement total and absolute power over the Australian community.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The increased vulnerability of the Australian economy as a consequence of the continuing high risk economic strategies of the Government.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A reading of newspapers today, international as well as our own, leads Australians inescapably to the view that the Opposition has been putting for months. The headline on one page of the Australian Financial Review reads, `Wall St Journal finds Australia most vulnerable'. That article in the Wall Street Journal commenced:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a booby prize for stock markets in the current tumult, Australia is a strong contender to win it.
Going on to discuss that, Mr Brian Minton, chief economist with Merrill Lynch (Australia) Pty Ltd, said:
Australia is wearing the thinnest economic veneer.

Lest it be thought that this was a mere passing comment, one of our older established banks, the ANZ Bank Ltd, is quoted in a headline in the Australian as warning that the worst is yet to come. Those headlines and articles which I have just quoted briefly and succinctly sum up in part what the Opposition has been putting prior to, during and after the Budget brought down last September. Yet, in the face of mounting criticism, this Government does nothing. Claiming credit for previous stock market rises, it ducks when the market dives, claiming that the world is responsible, that the fall in world commodity prices has placed Australia in a vulnerable position. That is the height of hypocrisy. The reverse of that theory was reached in this House yesterday when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) claimed credit, on behalf of the Government, for the rising price of wool. It has long been an arrogant government but, like most of that type, it is also craven under pressure. It is craven and irresponsible and it blames all but itself. It can be summed up by saying that Labor's approach is craven and irresponsible. It refuses to take responsibility for the current economic malaise in Australia. It is the Government that is responsible, not for the stock market crash, but for the malaise, for its 4 1/2 years of wasted opportunity. We described the Budget that was brought down as a wasted opportunity and is not the proof of that being seen now?

The Government has had five Budgets, three mini-Budgets and two summits, and our economy is in a mess. When it took over government, Labor ran two massive Budget deficits. The first Budget deficit of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was almost double the last deficit of the Fraser Government. The Treasurer boosted Government spending under the misapprehension of giving the economy `a kick start'. A kick start indeed! All the Government's policies did was bring about a binge of private and public consumption expenditure. Labor's Budget deficit swallowed Australia's savings and ran up a huge foreign debt. As I have said in this House before, this Government has presided over a quadrupling of our foreign debt. It has presided over the downgrading of our international AAA credit rating for the first time in the nation's history. It has put our economy, as others are now saying in concert with us, in an extremely vulnerable position.

It is no wonder that the Government has asked whether Australia can cope with a downturn in world economic activity or a slump in commodity prices. It is the Government that is responsible for our current vulnerable position. That is what the Opposition has been saying and we are being joined, week by week, by more commentators including, today, articles in the Wall Street Journal-the journal that only last week, the Treasurer told us, was probably the most widely read journal today. At every opportunity this Government and, in particular, the Treasurer ramble on about what has happened over the last four years. Not a concerted bit of evidence as to what future action would be taken was given by the Treasurer today.

If one wanted to see the ultimate fall from grace it is this petrified creature occupying the Treasury position seeing the chance of grabbing the prime ministership evaporating-frozen. The arrogance is still there, but to use the phrase of an old colleague of mine, `I'd hate to buy him at his price and sell him at mine'. It would not be too good today. In he comes, day after day, exuding arrogance, but he has no blueprints, schedules or proposals for what many are accurately describing as the most vulnerable economy in the world. Time after time, day after day, we are subjected to the most nauseating drivel on how this Treasurer has brought the Budget into balance, how he has reduced the net public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR). He has not done so. The balanced Budget was a facade. The Budget had an underlying deficit of $2.5 billion. Honourable members have heard enough of our comments on the PSBR.

It is now time to hear what the Government is going to do. We are well aware of its past failures in fiscal and wages policy. We are well aware that the Government has brought about a fundamental fiscal imbalance with huge deficits and that it has eroded our competitiveness with increases in wages of about 6 1/2 per cent per annum, with little or no increase in productivity since it was elected. In the Budget the Government-it is not just what we or outside commentators are saying; its own Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said it-did not have the `political courage' to cut government expenditure. That, in blunter terms, is what we have been saying for months. The Government did not have the political courage to force the pace of adjustment of domestic policies in the face of our external imbalance. It missed an opportunity. It brought down a Budget with an underlying deficit of $2.5 billion. Now, the Government is putting out the story-one can read it here and there in the fine print of the commentaries-that it does not want to `drive the economy through the floor'. The Government is trying to provide some explanation as to why it is sitting pat. That is the Treasurer's latest contribution to economic theory, following his earlier `kick start' contribution.

Let us look at how the Treasurer grasps at straws to support the Government's economic strategy. On Monday, in answer to a question in the House, the Treasurer dug up some anecdotal evidence-chitchat with a few people-that the old investment situation might be all right. Again last week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer hailed the September consumer price index (CPI) figure as a welcome result and confirmation that the Government's economic strategy was on track. Well the confidential report to the Treasurer prepared by Dr Norton, the head of the financial markets section of the Reserve Bank of Australia, seemed to take a slightly different view, stating that the September quarter CPI figure was at the top of the market range of expectations, and as a consequence the currency fell. It then steadied, only because of the further intervention of the Reserve Bank by engaging in large sales of foreign currency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they had floated the currency?
—Floated the currency? The way the currency is floating at the moment it would not even rise against the Matabele gumbo bead.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the Government's economic strategy is out of kilter with the real world. The Reserve Bank has had to intervene on a huge scale to prevent the currency from falling even further against what is a very weak United States dollar. Cuts in government spending release resources, do they not, for use in the private sector? Cuts in government spending fund tax cuts and a reduction in the Government's underlying deficit. So on two scores alone such cuts would strengthen the fundamental position of the economy, and of course that is what we are advocating. A cut in taxes increases the incentive to work, it increases the incentive to invest. A reduction in government borrowing tends to reduce interest rates. Both these measures would provide some hope for an improvement in investment. That is why it is imperative that the Government get on with the job of reducing government expenditure, for further delays will simply make the problem worse. The economy will fail to adjust and Australia will continue to accumulate foreign debt at an undoubtedly unsustainable rate. Failure to act imposes extremely large social costs on our country, quite apart from the economic burden. The continued high levels of government spending tie down resources in the non-tradable government sector or, to state the problem another way, our pace of adjustment in the production of exports and import substitutes is delayed.

Perhaps the greatest testimony to the Government's craven irresponsibility is its wages policy. Year in, year out, nominal wages in this country have increased by some 6 1/2 per cent. Our rate of wage and price inflation is amongst the highest in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. As a consequence, our currency has been devalued repeatedly under this Government. In 1987-88 a wage package in the neighbourhood of 6 1/2 per cent will be negotiated, with little increase in productivity. The Government failed to oppose the current across the board wage increase; it has failed, therefore, to give the signal that Australia is serious about getting on top of wage and price inflation. It has behaved in an incredibly craven and irresponsible manner. Again let us look at what the Government is going to do. Do we know what it is going to do tomorrow?

TALK.START.PARA: —Zero.

—No, not zero on this occasion. The Treasurer and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will consult with the government in exile, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, concerning next year's wages policy. So the nation has to sit around and wait-we all have to sit around and wait-while the Government gets permission to adopt a new wages policy. The Government does not have any policies of its own; it has no guts to take on the trade union movement and say what any other duly elected government would say: `We had an election a few months ago, we won and we are running the country; not you, the trade union officials'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's action is a cop out, and it is symptomatic of the cop out in other areas of its conduct of economic policy today. We need forthright, tough and decisive action so that wages can be set not just according to the demands of the trade union leaders. They are not the ones who will lose their jobs, it is the men and women in the work force who may lose their jobs. It does not affect these officials that the Government kowtows to. Wages have to be set not according to their demands but according to productivity. It happens yet again that the Opposition has the right policy. We have the right wages policy, for we will decentralise the labour market, we will break the control of the trade union leadership, we will break the control of the Creans and the Keltys and we will reform industrial relations so that working men and women can negotiate at the enterprise level.

Foreign investors are beginning to see through the Government, to lose faith in its ability, and tragically in Australia's ability, to weather the impending disruptions to world economic activity. The Government has been warned often enough, and by an increasing number of people in the international community. We started warning the Government at the time of the Budget, well before the collapse of the stock market. Undoubtedly this Labor Government has to take responsibility for this current mess; it has to take responsibility for any further depressed conditions that lie ahead. Labor has failed this nation, and an increasing number of people recognise that. It has failed miserably to provide our country with a balanced fiscal policy or with a wages policy based on productivity, and consequently with a strong external sector.

In short, as so many are joining the Opposition in saying, the fundamentals are weak. The Government has failed to strengthen the underlying position of our economy, and it has failed because it has been craven and it has been irresponsible. As Senator Walsh has said, we are moving further down the Argentinean road. Our most pressing issues are our high current account deficit, our high external debt, our extremely low investment in plant and equipment, our high wage and price inflation and our low productivity. Yet Labor does nothing. Labor cringes; Labor hides. It should produce the blueprint the nation requires.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with some of the propositions put by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. We have heard it all before. The answer, he says, is very simple: it is to cut taxes, and to cut public spending. We heard that during the election campaign, but did we ever hear during that campaign, and do we hear now, where the Opposition proposes to cut public spending?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Not from this Opposition and not from the honourable member opposite. The reality is, and it is a matter now of public knowledge, that when the honourable gentleman became Deputy Leader and shadow Treasurer he indicated-I believe with some integrity and with some foresight-that it was necessary to overhaul totally the economic policies of the Opposition, and he was going to take the Opposition in a new direction, as well he should have. SPEECH.PARA: So we have heard from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition today essentially the same old arguments. Let us put those arguments into three contexts. It is a nonsense to suggest that there is no coherent economic strategy.
