The Opposition cannot blame this Government for the collapse in share prices, but equally it would be irresponsible for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) not to have regard to that. He said in an address last week to the World Economic Outlook Seminar:
But any judgment about what response we should make must be made against the background that the Government has firmly in place an effective economic strategy for the long haul.
As in the past, we will adjust the specific policy settings within that ongoing strategy whenever that is warranted by changed circumstances.
As in the past, any such changes will not be knee jerk reactions but designed to fit within that strategy and sustain it over the long haul.

Of course there will be periods of considerable uncertainty regarding the recent decline in share prices and of course the Government and the Treasurer are monitoring every aspect of that very closely. We will not go in for irresponsible scaremongering. If there is any group in Australian society praying for a recession, it is honourable gentlemen opposite-because they believe that with such a disastrous economic downturn, in the absence of any kind of coherent economic philosophy, their political time would have come. So what we are getting from the Opposition week after week is a restatement of the same old things it said during the elections-more unfunded tax cuts and more arguments about cuts in public expenditure. But never on any occasion does the Opposition say where the cuts should be. Should they be in education or social welfare spending? Where does the Opposition suggest these cuts be made? How is it that when it comes to identifying the cuts there is nothing but silence?

A week or two ago the shadow Treasurer was talking about the need for a mini-Budget: that was the fashion at that stage. The Government's response to this fall in share prices will depend upon a wide range of factors including, as the Treasurer has stressed, the response of the United States Government in addressing its Budget and current account deficits. Although undoubtedly some of those people who were involved in maximising their profits when share prices were up were adversely hit when the run stopped and were caught with a share decline. These declines need to be seen against the background of five years during which share prices increased substantially. In this context it could be argued that share prices have come back more into line with underlying earnings potential.

That said, reduced private sector wealth and increased uncertainty about the economic outlook are likely to result in a slowing in the growth of private consumption expenditure and growth in private consumption is now likely to be slightly below the Budget estimate. In the case of business investment, reduced share prices will make it more difficult for businessmen to raise equity funds. Investment may also be restrained by the increased uncertainty about economic prospects generally. However, it should be noted that following the Budget there had been indications of an improvement in the outlook for investment. Hence, any reduction in business investment plans will be from a firm base, especially in the tradable sectors. Overall growth in domestic demand may now be slightly below the Budget time forecast of 1 3/4 per cent. The prospects for the Australian economy in 1987-88 are not substantially changed from the assessment in the 1987-88 Budget Papers. As such, the Government's policy framework remains appropriate. Of course, one has to watch all aspects of what is a sensitive economic situation. But we will adjust policies within that broad framework just as we have done it in the past when confronted with changed external circumstances.

As I said, what we had from the shadow Treasurer today was simply a repeat of the attempt to buy votes in the last election, an attempt that was cynical in the extreme and an attempt which was rejected by the Australian people. But there was one further aspect of the honourable gentleman's case today which does not come as any surprise. Under the Government of which he was a member, the real growth in the Australian economy took place amongst those who were rorting the system-the tax dodgers. The greatest expansion in our economy was amongst those who, under the honourable gentlemen opposite, could choose whether or not they met their taxation obligations, and the rest of Australia was made to pay for it.

Of course, there are those who made considerable profits out of the stock market boom and there are those who are now suffering for it. But who are we told by the honourable gentlemen opposite have now to pay the measure of some of the problems that arise from the fall in stock market prices? Do they suggest the tax dodgers? Do they suggest those who were not producing anything but who were simply exchanging pieces of paper and making considerable fortunes? No. Who is going to bear the burden of the economic rantings of the honourable gentlemen opposite? The Australian wage and salary earner who never had the option of tax dodging, who had tax taken out of his pay packet every week.

The only thing that can be said about the speech of the shadow Treasurer is that there was a certain logical consistency. What can one expect from men and women opposite who have consistently opposed wage increases to the ordinary Australian time after time? Is it any accident that while the tax dodging mates of the honourable gentlemen opposite were ripping off the system, as a matter of deep political and economic philosophy they were able to oppose 19 out of the 21 national wage cases. Think about that. When the trade union movement had to go into the court to argue for increases, on 19 out of the 21 occasions the men who did nothing about the scandals of tax evasion and tax dodging were there to say that it was inappropriate that the wage and salary earners had any increase. Of course, with the stock market collapse who is again to bear the brunt? Who are we going to blame? Not the mates of the honourable gentlemen opposite; it again will be the wage and salary earner.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his mates?

—The honourable member knows the reality. Average Australian workers are not enemies because they are trade unionists; they are decent hardworking Australians. They were entitled to their wage and salary increases and they had to prove it. But when it came to measuring up to the economic crisis which confronted Australia and which was a product of the lean years of the Fraser Government, it was the accord reached by the trade union movement and the Australian Council of Trade Union (ACTU) which provided a secure basis for our economic recovery. The trade union movement and the ACTU were prepared to say to their members, `You cannot expect to get the full measure of wage and salary increases'. Which Australian company said to its middle-management, `You'll have to forgo some of your wage and salary increases.'? Which one of those people said, `Well, perhaps given the nature of what is occurring in Australian society and our economic problems, we ought to pay our full measure of tax, or perhaps we should see that some of the profits will be forgone and used to bolster manufacturing industry and other sections that are so desperately in need in this society'. SPEECH.PARA: Honourable gentlemen opposite lack anything that looks like a coherent economic policy. They are still using the old mumbo-jumbo that they used during the last election. They are saying, `We need more tax cuts. Don't ask how we will pay for them, but we need more tax cuts'. They mean tax cuts for their friends and no wage increases for the working people of Australia. They want more tax cuts and cuts in the public sector. They say, `Don't ask us where we will make those cuts. Don't ask us whether we will hit the pensioners in the community or those relying on social welfare benefits. Don't ask us whether we will cut the heart out of our education institutions or out of our defence forces. Don't ask us where we will make cuts, just trust us'. Members of the Opposition are not worthy of trust because they had an opportunity and they failed. They created an economic crisis and this Government had to spend many years turning it around. We have turned it around. We will not respond to the economic mumbo-jumbo of honourable gentlemen opposite.

Nothing new has been said in this debate over the last three weeks. All that honourable members opposite are doing is hoping and praying for an economic recession so that they can say, `We told you so' and hope the Australian people will be gullible enough to allow them to slip into office on the basis of a recession which, deep in their hearts, they want. They have absolutely no kind of economic philosophy and, what is worse, no kind of economic integrity, to enable them to make any positive contribution to the solution of these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was listening to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), I was reminded of a recent incident on an international flight. After the plane had taken off, the pilot said over the intercom, `While there is some bad news, I have some good news. The bad news, of course, is that our navigation system has gone out. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member mentioned a speech made last week by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at a conference in Melbourne in which he outlined some of the details of this assessment of the world scene, the stock market crash and our policy response. In that speech he made quite a lot of the point that, if the United States does not adjust, that adjustment will be forced on it; that financial markets will vote with their feet, as they are; the dollar will collapse; and, ultimately, the needed policy adjustments will be made. It is interesting that the honourable member and the Treasurer seem to have learnt virtually nothing from their past experience. Remember in 1985, on two occasions, and in 1986, when they were dragged screaming to the recognition that something was fundamentally wrong, as our dollar fell by about 30 per cent? I suggest that they look at the Reuters screed that the Treasurer referred to today and see what has happened in the last couple of weeks. As our dollar has again fallen by 10 per cent on a trade weighted basis, financial markets are again voting with their feet. Financial markets are making the very same points to us that they are making to others. We in this country have not put our house in order. The interesting thing is that the Government seems very much to be a victim of its own propaganda. It believes a lot of the rhetoric and hogwash that it has been pushing around the place. It is now sitting back complacently while our economic situation is deteriorating so dramatically.

The Treasurer made the very interesting suggestion in the House today that we on this side of the House are very much economic simpletons. We do not understand what is happening. We do not understand the fact that, now that we have a floating currency, financial markets will not be able to exercise their judgment and capital will not be able to flow out. It is indeed a very interesting suggestion on the part of the Treasurer. Of course, if it were true that we had a freely floating exchange rate, he could probably get somewhere with his argument. But the fact is that we in this country do not have anything like a floating exchange rate. We have one of the dirtiest floats in the Western world.

If one looks at what the Reserve Bank of Australia has been doing in recent days in financial markets, one will get the very clear idea that it has been cushioning the fall of the currency. As a result, our reserves have already fallen quite significantly, probably by about $1 billion in the last few weeks, in an attempt to forestall the vote of the financial markets. Of course, even the Reserve Bank is a little more sophisticated these days. It is intervening in the forward exchange market as well. The suggestion that we have a floating currency, that capital outflow is not significant and that the financial markets are not making judgments about us is obviously quite misplaced. All international portfolio managers and others are assessing the current situation. What should one expect them to do in the current circumstances? Surely they will take a long, hard look at us and say, `There's a commodity exporting country. There's a country that hasn't made the necessary policy adjustments, despite all the rhetoric of the Government. There's a country that basically has an exotic currency'. In current circumstances what else would they do but take their money and run. Most of those international portfolio managers were overexposed, in their term, to the Australian dollar, and they are now in the process of making significant adjustments to those exposures and moving out.

The honourable member for Melbourne Ports read selectively from the speech made by the Treasurer last week at an Australian conference, but he stopped short of reading the rest of the page he was reading from and beyond, when the Treasurer went on to tell what he had done in regard to the crisis. Firstly, he said he had increased the liquidity in the economy, which makes a heck of a lot of sense does it not, in a country where the inflation rate is already double that of our trading partners and is unlikely to decline anywhere near as fast as the Treasurer suggested in the Budget-and particularly so now, given that we have had another 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar since the Budget. Is it a very sensible policy to pay an additional wage increase at the time when all our trading partners are pulling in their horns? We have already had wage increases in this country, according to the Treasurer's Budget assumptions, that were double that of our trading partners, but we see the Treasurer paying yet another wage increase.

Thirdly-he does not say this but he should have-he has in part engineered the fall in the currency as much as there has been a judgment of financial markets. Why does the Treasurer have a vested interest in a devaluation in this country? To be cynical, it is because of the way the book of the Reserve Bank is managed. The Reserve Bank will make additional profits as a result of devaluation. The Treasurer will then visit the Governor sometime near the middle of next year and try to extract even more than $2.6 billion already built into this year's magic and illusionary Budget.

I would not want him to miss out; so I shall do it for him. I suggest to the Treasurer that if that 10 per cent devaluation is sustained-and the probability is that it will be even more-it will probably add about one per cent to the CPI this year. It will probably add about $1 billion to the invisible item, our balance of payments. It will probably worsen our trade imbalance to the tune of about $300m to $500m as we get another adverse J-curve effect.

On the basis of what has happened in the past few weeks there is little way that the Treasurer's Budget forecasts can stand. This morning on the steps of Parliament House the Treasurer tried to dispense with the suggestion that maybe we are under downward pressure. TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) is using anecdotes, perhaps the next one should be, `We'll all be rooned, said Hanrahan' which is quite appropriate for the Opposition. SPEECH.PARA: The Australian economy in 1987 is far better placed than it has been at any time in the past 30 years to withstand external economic pressures. Naturally, the Government does not pretend to say that overseas economic events will not have an impact on our economy. What we do say is that with the right macroeconomic mix we can limit the impact on the Australian economy. Our vulnerability stems from 30 years of policy failure under conservative governments. We have had an overreliance on a narrow export base in commodities-commodities that have collapsed in price in the past two years. When we came to office, Australia was a nation virtually without a competitive secondary industry structure. The Howard induced recession of 1982 almost totally destroyed Australian manufacturing industry. With an overvalued dollar and an overregulated financial system, Australian business had no opportunity to compete in a world market. Jobs were lost, businesses closed and Australia faced prolonged economic decline.

This Government took up the challenge and set about introducing a policy mix aimed at creating employment whilst at the same time reducing inflation. The co-operation of the trade union movement in bringing about economic change has been unprecedented in this country's history. In Australia our response to the massive collapse in the terms of trade has been $7 billion out of our current budgetary outlays between August 1986 and September 1987. If our friend and trading partner the United States of America had exercised the same fiscal responsibility it would have been the equivalent of cutting $175 billion in the United States deficit. In other words adjustment of an equivalent scale as has happened in Australia would have virtually balanced the United States Budget.

The structural changes made to the Australian economy will mean that over the coming financial year we have eliminated the Commonwealth's demand on financial markets. These changes are important because we are not looking just to reducing the current account deficit or just to stabilising our external debt. Rather, we are seeking sustainable adjustment in these areas so that our living standards in future will be less vulnerable to external shocks of the kind we have experienced in recent years and more particularly in recent weeks.

We have to make our industries and our economy much more efficient and attuned to world markets. The Government has done much in this regard and will continue on its path of reform. The health of the economy can not be determined by simple Government decisions. We need a work force that is better trained so that it can make its contribution to more efficient, more flexible, less vulnerable world competitive Australian industries. This Government has continued to show that it is sufficiently flexible to meet any new challenge that may present itself. What the Opposition needs to do is to articulate in a much clearer way than the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has what policy changes it would make in the current circumstances.

In the election campaign in July this year the Opposition promised a tax bribe to the Australian people which would have brought about a collapse in the confidence in the Australian economy. The lastest Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was well received both domestically and internationally. The structural changes that this Government has made will have a long term impact on the future prosperity of this country. The changes that have been brought about after deep and careful consideration have laid the groundwork for a competitive prosperous Australian economy for generations to come. Economic strategies alone are not sufficient to bring about a healthy Australian economy. What is needed is a range of policies across portfolios that are geared to dragging Australia out of its economic malaise. It is my contention that this Government has such a range of policies, particularly in the area of industry policy. We have seen the implementation of the steel industry plan, the car industry plan, the textile, clothing and footwear plan, plus many more innovative packages that are aimed at mixing and matching the Australian economy into a more competitive world player.

Following the election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his ministerial reorganisation gave high emphasis to the areas of trade, manufacturing and skills development. These are the areas that Australia must concentrate on to rebuild its economy. One would think that after five years of opposition honourable members opposite would be able to make a more constructive contribution to a debate than has been made here today. It is apparent that honourable members opposite have no understanding or realisation of the changes that this Government has already brought about. We are now in a position where Australia can face the challenges of the world economy because of the economic strategies of this Government. The major economic debate on the Opposition's side of the House appears to be whether it was the previous Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, or the previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who held up the economic changes that were so obviously necessary from the late 1970s.

The latest contribution from the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, is to run around talking about a capital flight from this country because of the downward movement of the Australian dollar. It is ironic that at the very time he was giving his Press conference on the front steps of Parliament House this morning the dollar rose. Does this mean that, in the terminology of the Leader of the Opposition, there was a sudden inflow of capital? This is total nonsense. The world markets know and appreciate that this Government is making the structural changes necessary to meet the economic challenge. It is because of this confidence that I encourage the Treasurer to maintain the current economic policies he has successfully implemented over the past five years and to maintain his high degree of flexibility as circumstances change. DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the States Grants (Nurses Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985. The major purpose of this Bill is to introduce new variable capital funding arrangements for hostels and to improve the legislative base for the management of the new nursing home recurrent funding system introduced on 1 July 1987. The Bill also introduces improved new arrangements for conditions of capital and recurrent subsidies for hostels. These measures will enable better targeting of Commonwealth funding to hostel accommodation and care for disadvantaged groups and will achieve greater efficiency in Commonwealth funding of nursing homes.

In April 1986, a review of nursing homes and hostels reported on a future strategy for the development of residential care programs for the aged. The Government endorsed the broad thrust of the review's recommendations and in the 1986-87 Budget commenced a staged program of reform of residential care services for aged people. This reform program has the primary objective of responding to community needs by encouraging the further development of hostels and community care services, and of increasing the quality of care and life of aged people.

Implementation of the first two stages of the reform strategy is proceeding with the establishment of new needs-based planning arrangements, the development of co-ordinated assessment services for the elderly, the expansion of hostel and home and community care services, the development of a special services program, the phasing in of new recurrent funding arrangements for non-government nursing homes from 1 July 1987 and the introduction of quality of care standards for nursing homes. The new variable capital funding arrangements for hostels, given effect to by this Bill, introduce the third stage of the program for reform of residential care services for the aged.

In adopting a staged reform strategy the Government has recognised the importance of effecting gradual change in the aged care industry to minimise disruption in the lives of the 110,000 frail aged people in various forms of residential care presently receiving Commonwealth funding. In developing the overall program the Government recognised that the co-operation of service providers and the community would be necessary to fully achieve its objectives and to this end the Government has undertaken an extensive round of consultations with service providers, consumer and welfare organisations, and State governments on the proposed funding arrangements for hostels.

Briefly, the proposed amendments under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 will enable the Commonwealth to target its capital funding for hostels to achieve equitable access to hostels of people with limited means and all other people requiring and choosing hostel accommodation and care. This will be achieved by variation in the level of Commonwealth capital subsidy based, among other things, on the proportion of financially disadvantaged residents to be accommodated and the capacity of future residents to contribute towards the construction of the hostel.

In 1954 the Commonwealth introduced a capital subsidy program to stimulate the provision of suitable accommodation for aged people. Administrative arrangements of successive governments have meant that capital subsidies are provided on a two for one basis up to a maximum subsidy limit per place. In practice, however, the maximum subsidy arrangements result in a subsidy closer to one for one. A similar per place payment is provided for most projects, irrespective of the means of future residents or the financial capacity of the organisation receiving the subsidy.

Furthermore, current legislative provisions prevent refundable entry contributions paid by residents from being considered as part of an organisation's available funds in determining the amount of a Commonwealth capital subsidy, even though the practice of requesting entry contributions is widespread in the hostel sector. This creates two major problems. First, residents are uncertain of their rights attached to these payments, and many do not have any protection in relation to refunds of their entry contributions. Second, it increases the financial burden on organisations by necessitating that they find other sources of funds which can be considered as part of their matching funds for Commonwealth capital grants. In addition, no formal link exists between capital and recurrent funding provisions and in the past this has led to the Commonwealth providing capital funds for many `motel-like' hostels which do not receive recurrent subsidies for care services as the residents are well able to look after themselves. Consequently, the existing capital and recurrent funding arrangements do not target Commonwealth funds to organisations providing accommodation and care for disadvantaged groups or provide incentives for organisations to maximise the use of their own funds or of residents' entry contributions. As I have mentioned, this Bill includes a number of amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 designed to address these difficulties and to provide greater protection for residents.

The Bill enables the Minister to determine guidelines for the assessment of the amount of a capital grant to be paid for the establishment of a hostel. The guidelines will be gazetted, tabled and subject to possible disallowance. The guidelines will have regard to, among other things, any contribution to the capital cost of the hostel which could be made by residents and the organisation, borrowing of moneys by the organisation, class or classes of persons to be accommodated, and the maximum amount of the grant. Other amendments provided for in this Bill will remove restrictions on moneys to be taken into account in determining Commonwealth capital grants. The Bill will enable borrowed moneys which can be repaid by resident contributions or from payments made by the State or the Commonwealth-other than under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954-to be taken into account in determining Commonwealth capital grants.

The Bill also provides the Minister with the discretionary power to enable Commonwealth or State Government organisations, or organisations which conduct public hospitals, to be treated as eligible organisations for the purposes of the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. This will enable some joint hostel ventures to proceed. This Bill also introduces new conditions for capital and recurrent funding and changes the existing arrangements for determining conditions of recurrent funding. The new arrangements and additional conditions clarify up front the requirements of Commonwealth capital and recurrent funding. The Bill will enable the Minister to specify conditions of a capital grant for a hostel and organisations will be required to enter into an agreement in relation to these conditions.

The conditions of agreements for capital funding set out in the Bill must be met by an eligible organisation and include provision for compliance by that organisation with conditions of grant, the repayment of financial assistance and the recovery of amounts taken as representing the Commonwealth's interest. The conditions will also include that an organisation shall comply with the conditions of recurrent funding. This introduces a link between existing capital and recurrent funding provisions and ensures that Commonwealth capital funding is targeted to the provision of hostel accommodation for the frail aged. In addition, capital grants will be subject to the provision of accommodation and care of a determined number of financially disadvantaged people to further target government funding to this group.

Similarly, this Bill will enable hostel recurrent subsidies to be subject to gazetted conditions which will be tabled and subject to possible disallowance. As well as the current conditions enforced through the existing hostel recurrent subsidies agreement, additional conditions relating to residents' rights and obligations, including provision of refunds for entry contributions, accountability of organisations to residents and specified outcome standards to be achieved, will be included. Non-compliance with conditions may mean suspension or cancellation of Commonwealth recurrent subsidies.

I should stress that the details of those provisions which are to be gazetted, tabled and subject to disallowance will not be finalised until the Government has completed national consultations and discussions with service provider and consumer organisations.

The Bill also includes amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 which will simplify the administration of the capital subsidy program. These amendments change the formula for determining the capital cost of a home by enabling the cost of equipment to be taken into account in determining the capital cost of a home.

The amendments in this Bill to the National Health Act 1953 will facilitate the administration of the new nursing home recurrent funding arrangements introduced on 1 July 1987 and will introduce measures to assist fraud controls in relation to current administrative procedures. The successful implementation of the new standard grant funding arrangements depends to some extent on the financial data obtained from nursing home proprietors. In accordance with the new nursing homes financial arrangements principles, at the end of each financial year a reconciliation between estimated nursing and personal care costs and actual costs is to be undertaken. Under current legislative provisions, it is not clear that details of nursing and personal care costs are required to be kept by proprietors. This Bill therefore provides that particulars in relation to nursing and personal care costs should be submitted by proprietors in a form approved by the secretary at such times, and in respect of such periods, as are determined by the secretary. These determinations will be gazetted, tabled and subject to possible disallowance. This amendment will allow prospective fees determinations to be calculated more quickly and efficiently.

Consistent with the Government's acceptance of the recommendations of the recent review of systems dealing with fraud, a number of measures in this Bill will assist in reducing the potential for fraudulent practices by nursing home proprietors. The Bill extends the current provisions relating to inspections of nursing home records to enable an officer authorised by the Minister to inspect documents or records that relate to the operation of a nursing home, wherever these records are kept. The Bill also provides that the manner in which nursing home records are to be kept may be prescribed. This will overcome current problems where some proprietors keep their records on accounting documents which reflect more that one business operation, making it difficult to verify during end of year reconciliations whether expenditure has in fact been incurred. The Bill also provides for extended evidence collecting powers and amends penalty provisions under Parts V, VA and VC of the National Health Act 1953 to bring these provisions into line with penalty provisions in other Commonwealth legislation.

The Bill also amends the National Health Act 1953 to remove the Minister's discretion to depart from the new nursing homes financial arrangements principles in reviewing fees determinations decisions. These principles are an integral part of the new funding arrangements and were designed to minimise discretions. If the transition to a standard grant funding system for nursing homes is to succeed, the principles must be applied in all cases of review of fees determinations decisions. The Bill also clarifies ministerial review powers by enabling all fees determinations decisions to be subject to review.

As foreshadowed by the former Minister for Community Services, Chris Hurford, in his second reading speech on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 in the autumn sittings 1987, a new mechanism for approving the transfer of nursing home beds from one location to another is also provided for in this Bill. In addition, another amendment to the National Health Act 1953 in this Bill gives effect to an undertaking given by Senator Susan Ryan on behalf of the then Minister for Community Services during the Senate debate on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and prevents any action being taken against a nursing home under the new non-compliance with standards powers until a standards review panel has been established in the State or Territory in which the home is situated.

The Bill amends secrecy provisions of the National Health Act 1953 to bring them into line with similar provisions under the Health Insurance Act 1973. Currently, the information which may be released to prescribed persons or authorities is not specified. This Bill will permit only information of a kind prescribed by regulation to be made available to a person or authority. This enhances the protection of personal privacy under the National Health Act 1953. The Bill also provides for a minor amendment to the Health Insurance Act 1973 to remove, in the interests of protecting privacy of patients, the requirement for the tabling of instruments determining patients as needing acute care.

Finally, a minor amendment to the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 is also provided for in this Bill. The Commonwealth has provided funds to the States and the Northern Territory under the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act since 1985 to assist with the transfer of basic training courses for nurses from hospitals to colleges of advanced education. The number of places being partially funded by the Commonwealth is increasing year by year so that by the end of 1993, the hospital-based training courses will be completely phased out. By authorising funding for the next transmission, this Bill amends the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 to allow the transfer of nurse education to continue at an orderly rate.

The new funding arrangements for hostels under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 are expected to result in savings in $7m in each of the years 1987-88, 1988-89 and 1989-90. The amendments to the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 will authorise, subject to appropriation, expenditure to assist in the transfer of nurse education from hospitals to colleges of advanced education of $14m in the calendar year 1988, $21m in the calendar year 1989, and $28m in each of the years 1990 to 1993. The other measures in the Bill have no readily quantifiable financial impact, although it is expected that they may result in some small savings in administrative costs.
I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. The amendments are set out in the schedule to this Bill. The Murray-Darling Basin comprises about one-seventh of Australia. It produces about one-third of Australia's total output from natural resource-based industries. It supports 25 per cent of the nation's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and crop land, and almost 75 per cent of its irrigated land. Production derived is valued at some $10 billion annually. It is Australia's agricultural heartland.

We have been historically successful in our approach to harvesting the waters of the basin to ensure reliable supplies for irrigation, urban and industrial use. This success, however, has to be measured against the cost of deteriorating water and land quality and diminished environmental amenity. Inadequate attention to the need for an environmentally and economically integrated approach to natural resource management in the basin has, however, in some instances already set in train resource degradation processes that threaten resource viability. Indeed, it is hard to escape the conclusion that, in many ways, past land, water and environmental management practices have been largely exploitive and not conducive to sustainable use of the resources of the basin.

Historically, debate has focused on the security and use of the priceless waters of the River Murray, a not insignificant factor in accelerating the advent of Federation. The first River Murray Waters Agreement, to resolve developing conflicts in the use of River Murray waters, was signed in 1914, legislation came into effect in 1915 and the River Murray Commission was established in 1917. As a result of the first major review of the Agreement in 1983, the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission were extended to include water quality matters but an holistic approach to basin resource management remained elusive. Not that this should be surprising to anyone.

Management of the land, water and environmental resources of the basin involves three State governments-four if you include Queensland-and the Commonwealth, as well as a multiplicity of local government and regional agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —If! Put it in.

—When the River Murray flows into Queensland, it will be appropriate. It requires the reconciliation of the disparate interests and aspirations of a diverse population of over two million people within boundaries encompassing in excess of one million square kilometres. This reconciliation, while necessarily predicated on sound technical analyses, must inevitably involve hard political and economic choices between competing objectives and measures. The breakthrough came in November 1985 when Ministers of the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia with responsibility for natural resources met to specifically discuss strategies to improve natural resources management in the basin. In a genuinely historic initiative, the four governments decided to shelve parochial interests and adopt a strong, co-operative approach to better management of the basin. The most immediately visible outcome of the meeting was the agreement to establish a Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council on an ongoing basis.
—Where was Queensland?

—The same place it has always been. Ministers also initiated a wide ranging work program to develop institutional and technical options for improved basin management. Council met in August 1986 and in March 1987. In the light of its deliberations and the substantial body of advice provided by its advisory committees, all four governments have now agreed to revise substantially the institutional arrangements for managing the basin. The Bill currently before the House complements similar legislation before the parliaments of the other three signatories and aims to have in place by 1 January 1988 an institutional framework at inter-governmental level that will facilitate and support State based initiatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement will give a clear legislative base to the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council. The Council will provide a focus for consideration of planning and management issues for the sustainable use of the natural resources of the basin. It will be responsible for the development of policies and strategies for their efficient, equitable and co-ordinated management. Composed of those Ministers representing the portfolios of water, land and environment from the four governments, the Council will be in a position to make informed political judgments and balanced trade-off decisions. It will be able to take a holistic, overview stance on management issues. It is this that distinguishes the current initiative from past endeavours which have been State-based or, in the case of the River Murray Waters Agreement, confined to the regulation of a particular resource or aspects of it.

The amendments before the House also propose the establishment of a new Murray-Darling Basin Commission to replace the River Murray Commission. This new Commission will assume the River Murray Commission's regulatory responsibilities under the River Murray Waters Agreement, and will also have a broader advisory responsibility to the Ministerial Council on land, environment and water matters not covered in the Agreement. Another important element in the proposed legislation is the provision for a direct line of communication between Council and the basin community.

From the very outset, Ministers have been mindful of the crucial role that the community will play in the development of improved management practices in the basin. Accordingly, the proposed legislation includes express provision for a community advisory committee to provide a focus for community input. The formation of a community forum will allow the great variety of local interests the opportunity for consultation on the management of the basin's natural resources. Such a body will perform the vital role of eliciting and synthesising-as far as is possible-the diversity of community views on particular management issues, and will provide an avenue for two-way communication between the Council and the people of the basin. Consultation must, of course, involve more than drawing community concerns to Council's attention. Consultation must also carry responsibilities, and private aspirations may well need to be modified in the light of the larger public benefit. It will be essential to the success of the basin initiative that the community accept both the opportunities and the responsibilities of involvement provided for under this legislation.

The Government is confident that the legislation currently before the House will provide an institutional framework commensurate with the task to be done. Ultimate success will depend upon a close, responsible and responsive partnership between all the governments involved and between governments and the people of the basin. The Council will need to move with cautious speed. Success will not be achieved easily or overnight, and a long term commitment is required. But the basin community and the nation will benefit from our efforts to secure the long term integrity of the natural resources of the basin. That is a goal very much worth striving for. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Dairy Produce Act 1986 prescribes criminal penalties for the export of dairy produce in breach of International Dairy Arrangement (IDA) price minima. The purpose of this Bill is to substitute economic penalties for such breaches. The principal Act, inter alia, establishes the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) and provides it with export control powers. It recognises the Australian commitment to the IDA established under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and provides the basis for fulfilling the Government's commitment to the minimum prices which are set under the arrangement. The main objective of the arrangement is to expand and to liberalise world trade in dairy products under as stable market conditions as possible, on the basis of mutual benefit to exporting and importing countries.

Australia as a signatory to the arrangement is committed to ensuring that its obligations are fulfilled. However, there are concerns that the measures embodied in the Dairy Produce Act for ensuring compliance with the international price minima are inappropriate in practice and should be more comparable with the measures adopted by other major exporter members of the IDA. The IDA requires countries participating in the arrangement to take the steps necessary to ensure that export prices of dairy products are not less than the IDA prescribed minima. However, mechanisms for ensuring observance are left to individual participants to develop; they are not prescribed in the International Dairy Agreement.

The European Community (EC) uses its export refund system to meet its obligations for observance of IDA minimum prices. We have had repeated assurances from the EC Commission that the refunds are set at levels that would make it impossible for EC traders to export dairy products at less than IDA minimum prices and still make a profit on each sale. Nevertheless the Commission does concede that its refund system does not impose an effective price discipline and that it is technically possible for its traders to enter into loss contracts or manipulate products and currencies in order to trade below IDA minima.

In New Zealand, another major IDA participant and exporter, the sole exporter of dairy products is the New Zealand Dairy Board. The legislation governing the operations of the Board provides for it to comply with the general trade policy of the Government. This in turn requires that the Board's performance be consistent with the provisions of the International Dairy Agreement. By comparison Australia's current method of observance seems inappropriate and somewhat out of touch with commercial realities. Under the Dairy Produce Act a trader exporting in breach of IDA minimum prices is liable not only to a fine but also to a term of imprisonment of up to two years, in addition to suspension or cancellation of his or her export licence. However, criminal prosecution is a difficult course and is not a practical way of pursuing breaches of IDA minimum prices where they may come to notice. There have been no prosecutions under the legislation.

In the current competitive international environment an economic approach to observing the IDA is considered more appropriate than an observance mechanism based on criminal penalties which are difficult to enforce. The provisions of the Bill which I will now elaborate are designed to bring about this change.

Under the new arrangements it will continue to be a condition of licence that exporters comply with IDA minimum prices. The Australian Dairy Corporation will, in the event of a detected breach of an IDA price minimum, require the exporter to pay the difference between the actual sale price and the appropriate IDA price minimum to the Corporation. Payments by exporters are to be credited to the market support fund of the Corporation which is used to support the prices of manufactured dairy products. In the event that an exporter is detected to be in breach of a minimum price and fails to pay the Corporation the difference between the minimum and the actual sale price, the Corporation may suspend or cancel the exporter's licence.

Where a breach is an unavoidable breach or where the exporter did not knowingly export dairy produce below the appropriate IDA price minimum, clause 3 of the Bill, sub-section 51a (5), provides the Corporation with the power to determine if a breach of IDA minimum price resulted from `exceptional circumstances'. If a determination is made by the ADC that such circumstances exist, the exporter will not be required to pay the difference between the IDA minimum and the actual sale price. I will be stressing to the ADC that this provision is not to be used to try to justify sales below the IDA minimum prices that do not accord with the circumstances I have already outlined covering unavoidable or unknown breaches.

The Bill also incorporates appropriate review and appeal provisions. Section 118 of the Dairy Produce Act dealing with reconsideration and review of decisions of the Australian Dairy Corporation will be amended to include decisions made under section 51a dealing with the payment of the difference between the selling price and IDA minimum prices and determinations of `exceptional circumstances', and those under sub-section 59 (4) dealing with suspension and cancellation of export licences. These changes will enable exporters to appeal against decisions made under these sections with such decisions to be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Another important change that the Bill provides is the automatic adjustment of GATT-IDA minimum prices in the regulations made under the Act relating to exports. At present when the International Dairy Products Council, the governing body of the IDA, agrees to changes in the minimum prices for dairy products there is an inevitable lag between the new minimum prices being adopted and the incorporation of these new prices in the relevant regulations. Clause 3 of the Bill, sub-section 51a (9), provides for the automatic incorporation of changes in IDA minimum prices in the regulations. This will ensure that the regulations reflect changes in minimum prices as and when they occur and will eliminate current lags in their implementation. The Corporation will continue to provide all licensed exporters with details of IDA minimum price changes as they occur, to ensure that exporters are fully aware of their minimum price obligations.

The ADC's role in the proposed observance measures I have just outlined will not be greatly changed from its existing role; the approach is a logical extension of the Corporation's existing responsibilities to ensure IDA compliance through its export control powers. The Corporation will be required to maintain close scrutiny of export price movements and to ensure that exporters are meeting their obligations under the Act. Moreover, the Corporation will be required to make determinations under sub-section 51a (5) should the need arise.

Since the ADC can export dairy products, the Corporation and its subsidiaries are required to comply with IDA minimum prices, just as are other exporters. Sub-sections 51a (6) and (7) deal with situations where Australia's trade in dairy products could be severely disadvantaged by the actions of others on the world market. In such circumstances the Bill provides for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to authorise the Corporation to trade at prices below the IDA minima. I envisage such an exemption being granted with the concurrence of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) after a review of all aspects of the situation.

The Australian Government as a signatory to the IDA accepts fully the responsibilities that membership of the arrangement entails. The changed observance mechanism embodied in the Bill in no way reduces the Government's commitment and intent to ensure observance of IDA price minima by Australian dairy product exporters. Rather, the amendment has the objective of aligning the nature of Australia's observance mechanism more closely with that of other major participants. It is completely consistent with the rights and responsibilities of signatories of the IDA to determine and adopt appropriate national measures to ensure that export prices are not less than IDA prescribed minima. The Bill removes the unnecessarily restrictive penalty structures which are not suited to a commercial environment and substitutes measures that still ensure the preservation of integrity of the industry and Government. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.
