DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to debate the Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, which is before the House, I remind the House that the purpose of the management investment companies (MIC) program is to favour and to assist in the direction of funds towards the cutting edge of Australia's attempts to restructure its industry. As the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: To 30 September 1987 the MICs have invested and committed almost $140m in 129 businesses across a range of industries, including computer hardware and software, medical equipment and products, scientific and technical services and industrial products and machinery.

This expenditure has been generated by the 100 per cent tax deductibility which the MIC program has build in to encourage investors to place capital in these projects. But it is not only at the cutting edge of high technology in which MICs have encouraged investment; the program has also focused investment in areas of export arrangements. In that regard there have been some very interesting projects to which I will draw the House's attention. For example, MICs have assisted in funding the establishment of a major abalone project in Tasmania. That five-year project has created a world-leading export market potential for abalone. It is a high value, low volume production. MIC has also helped a tool and dye-making business move away from traditional practices into robotics and has committed over $1m to fund that move.

This Bill addresses the future of MICs. The ultimate aim of the MIC project is to develop self-starting businesses ready to stand on their own feet. A number of MICs have been quite spectacularly successful in demonstrating a capacity to do that. The Bill contains provisions which enable MICs to draw capital from the market so they can go into MIC-type developments freely, without constraint, in an ordinary commercial way. The Bill also contains provisions whereby MICs, once they are commercially viable, can lift themselves out of the protective MIC umbrella without attracting the tax clawback arrangements which are designed to prevent taxation abuses. The Bill is focused on the undoubted success at this stage of a number of MICs and in evidence that the program has been very successful in encouraging sunrise industries to begin development in Australia.

However, some clouds do exist on the horizon. Some of those clouds were referred to earlier in this debate by my colleague the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin). He drew attention to the problems that will exist in funding MICs due to the downturn in the stock markets. I draw the attention of the House to a very interesting, and I believe quite persuasive, article which appeared in yesterday's Australian Financial Review under the pen of Jane Ford. The article pointed out that, although MICs have been very successful in attracting venture capital, and indeed the second board has been very successful in attracting funds to hi-tech companies which have not even had the benefit of MIC tax advantages, that this is no longer the case in the wash-up of the decline in stock market values. It appears that hi-tech companies will be very hard hit in the wash-up. It appears that MIC funds will be drawn upon in a greater than expected way to support new sunrise companies which previously had expected to be able to float issues on the second board or to gain funds from the open market sector.

That places in some doubt the conclusions of the report of the Bureau of Industry Economics which recommended the ultimate phasing out of the MIC sector. The Bureau of Industry Economics argues that the MIC program should be regarded as essentially a seeding program, designed to establish a self-sufficient hi-tech sector in the market which is able to stand up for itself. The Bureau stated in its report that it believed the sunrise sector of the economy was now in that position.

There must now be some doubt about the Bureau's projections. It projected a very substantial increase in equity funds flowing into hi-tech companies from everyday market transactions which have no taxation advantages conferred on them. The Bureau predicted that the funds that would flow into the non-MIC sector would out- strip MIC funds in the financial year 1988. I think that most commentators would now regard that as an unlikely scenario. The projections can be found in tables 4.1 and 4.2 in the program evaluation report.

My view, for what it is worth, is that, although the Government has undertaken to continue MICs until at least the end of 1989, they ought to be continued on a perpetual basis as a form of counter-cyclical insurance, so that when the market is doing well and funds are flowing easily and readily into venture capital sources the role of the MICs need not be emphasised-the Government need not be called upon to inject any substantial capital into the existing MICs-but so that the MIC sector remains and stands ready to perform a very important role when there is a downturn in the market, when it is difficult to attract venture capital into the riskier start-up venture end of sunrise capital. It remains very important for our country to be increasingly competitive. It remains important that Australia can continue to move into industry restructuring, even in periods of economic downturn. The MIC scheme can, I think, be regarded as a very appropriate form of counter-cyclical insurance existing on a perpetual basis, not merely as a project which can be wound down once it has served an initial seeding purpose.

I commend the Government for the legislation. The legislation has vision. It has been part of the process of making sure Australia has a part to play at the cutting edge of technology and that government is directing appropriate expenditures into areas of export. It is a move which I believe all honourable members would applaud. I have drawn attention to the clouds that exist on the horizon and I commend to the attention of the Minister the remarks I have made about the possibility of MICs being regarded as perpetual parts of the investment climate to ensure that, even in times of economic downturn, there remains the capacity for the economy to respond aggressively at the cutting edge so that we remain able to adjust and grow as an economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the amendments before the House in the Management and Investment Companies Amendment Bill 1987. As the record will show, we have offered enthusiastic support for this form of government assistance since its inception in the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983. What concerns me, however, is that, as in so much of its handling of economic matters, the Government's treatment of Australia's infant venture capital market has been insensitive to the fragile nature of that market and has, unfortunately, created uncertainties which could both distort and retard its future growth. Furthermore, the events of recent weeks in Australia's stock markets will not only aggravate that uncertainty but also reinforce the urgent need for continuing government assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be clear about the purpose of this legislation. Its primary purpose is to encourage the establishment of a venture capital market to support high risk entrepreneurial activity to young innovative export-oriented businesses with the potential for rapid growth.

The need for government incentives to assist the development of a venture capital market was recommended in a number of official reports in the years immediately before 1983. The Espie High Technology and Financing Committee, in particular, found that Australia was failing to generate a sufficient number of growth oriented firms to replace those being lost in the older sections of manufacturing. More seriously, the Committee found that Australia was failing to grasp the opportunities offered by high technological industries for wealth creation and employment growth. It was in that context that the Government and the Opposition gave their support to a Government-sponsored management and investment companies (MIC) program. It is fair to say that the scheme has been enormously successful over its first three years of operation and it was largely due to the growth of the non-MIC component of the venture capital market in conjunction with strong MIC growth that the Government appeared in 1986 to be considering the termination of the MIC program. That this is so is reflected in the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) report of September 1987 entitled Improving Australia's competitiveness through Industrial Research and Development, where it states at page five:
Termination is certainly a considered option by the Government.

As well, the terms of reference to a Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) survey of the MIC program in 1987 also included the option of ceasing the program as at 30 June 1988. It is worth reflecting that despite a recommendation from both ASTEC and BIE, that the scheme be terminated at June 1988, the Government has decided on an extension to 30 June 1989 subject to further review. I believe the extension is commendable and very necessary, but in my view the target of 1989 is now totally inappropriate. I was interested in the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who seems to support that point of view. An Australian venture capital market did become established over the period 1983-86 but it is now plainly evident that the strength of that growth was very largely due to the very nature of the risk component in a bull stock exchange market, and that it lacks the maturity to withstand the stock market winds of change which are now blowing so vigorously.

It is worth reflecting at this point on overseas experience. The Americans established a similar government-sponsored investment company program in 1958 and while the proportion of venture capital raised by that program has fallen from 24 per cent of total capital raised in 1977 to 10 per cent in 1984, the American Government still supports that program some 20 years after its establishment; and it does so in the clear belief that even at 10 per cent of the venture capital market, the program offers worthwhile opportunities for the creation of successful enterprises which might otherwise be left undeveloped. The United Kingdom (UK) is similarly placed. With the Government scheme established in 1981, and still operating today. There is a contribution to the total capital raising of venture companies of a little under 20 per cent. France, Japan and Sweden also have officially supported programs.

The point I am making, and stressing, is that some of the most industrialised and developed countries in the world deem it wise to continue giving support to venture companies. Compare that to Australia's circumstances. Our MIC program has been in operation only three years and the venture capital funds of those companies was a hefty 43.5 per cent of total venture funds as at March 1987-and that in a period of a highly excited capital market. So we can compare three years and 43 per cent with 20 years and 10 per cent in the United States of America (USA), and six years and 10 per cent in the UK. The figures speak for themselves and I find myself very genuinely puzzled as to how some of Australia's most respected academics and research bureaucrats have been so ready to dismiss those overseas experiences and believe that we have been able to achieve what has not been achieved in any other country.

Given the nature of that stock market today I believe the extension of the scheme only to 1989 is equally unsound. The well publicised option to terminate the scheme has created a most unfortunate uncertainty in the venture capital market itself, affecting the management and entrepreneurial skills which are so necessary to its ongoing success. I can see no justification for even contemplating such an option. Again the overseas experience is that the immediate tax concession cost of the scheme is more than compensated in the longer term by income generated by successful investment companies. So if the Government was hesitating over the scheme because of its apparent cost, its judgment was certainly misplaced. Equally, I feel a real concern about the role of ASTEC and the Bureau of Industry Economics in this matter. Both organisations are devoted to creating future growth opportunities for Australian industry and I find that objective hard to reconcile with their hasty willingness to suggest the premature termination of the MIC program.

Turning from some of the worrying comments and attitudes evident in the reports of both ASTEC and the BIE, I commend the Management and Investment Licensing Board-the body responsible for the management of the Government's program-for both its professionalism and the quality of its management, as indicated in successive annual reports and in its evidence to the BIE's 1987 survey of MICs. Three particular comments made by the Licensing Board deserve to be highlighted. The first is the clearest possible statement in its 1985-86 annual report that with the support of government a venture capital market was now emerging-I emphasise that; it is now emerging-as a material element of the Australian financial markets. It should be noted that it is not firmly established; it is not at a level of maturity where it could stand on its own feet, but it is an emerging market which has the potential to play a vital role in encouraging entrepreneurial investment.

The Board's second noteworthy observation is that overseas experience shows that in a mature market the highly successful investments may take up to five to seven years to be realised. In the light of those observations it is interesting to note that the BIE stated that MIC shareholders will not be adversely affected by the recently introduced capital gains tax. The Board, on the other hand, has stated that the capital gains tax will seriously retard the growth of the venture capital market, and it goes on to observe that the relative treatment of venture capitalists in the USA, the UK and Canada will continue to make those countries preferred locations for most mobile venture investments. If the Licensing Board is accurate with these several observations, I express the hope that the Government will give the Board's advice greater weight than appears to have been the case in the past.

All of us who support a government role in encouraging the establishment of a venture capital market in Australia must be concerned at the effect that the present dramatic downturn in the world's financial markets could have on the availability of venture capital for start-up risk investments and on the success of well established venture enterprises. I acknowledge that this situation has developed after the BIE's report, the Government's consideration of that report and the drafting of the amending legislation now before the House. However, now that it has occurred, and in view of its likely adverse impact on Australian investment companies, I believe it is no longer appropriate for the Government to be considering the termination of this program in 1989 or 1990, but rather it should give its unqualified support to venture companies by indicating in this debate that the program will not be terminated before 1993-the tenth anniversary of its establishment.

Furthermore, in view of the uncertainty in the financial markets I would also suggest that there is an equally urgent need to reassess the suitability of existing concessions as well as those to be granted by this Bill. They may no longer be appropriate or sufficient if we are truly in the business of creating a mature, long term venture capital market in this country. The Government is giving some indication that it is inclined towards policies which could well create an adolescent market which will be brought to its knees in periods of economic difficulty and prosper only in those counter periods of prosperity.

The concessions to be extended to the program in this Bill appear to be commendable, but I do suggest that one of the most serious remaining limitations is the ceiling of $20m on approved capital, a level which is clearly insufficient to give continuing support to well established and mature investments, let alone giving encouragement to those emerging companies and the hundreds of proposals which are placed before the board for approval for start-up support. There would also appear to be a need for the Government to reconsider the guidelines imposed on MICs as many entrepreneurs see it as unnecessarily restrictive to impose the present limitation on the type of activity in which an MIC might invest. I am certain that the Licensing Board would be able to offer a number of other worthwhile suggestions to the Government as to the type of concessions best suited to take Australia's emerging venture capital market through the next few years of difficulty and into a mature status capable of standing alone in the financial markets. It is enormously important that the Government give urgent consideration to these suggestions, and I hope that we have a positive response from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) at the conclusion of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure in support of the Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 which, as other speakers have said, amends both the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The amendments will enable management investment companies (MICs) to raise non-tax concessional capital in conjunction with tax concessional capital as well as allowing the existing older MICs to surrender their licences and leave the program without triggering the current tax clawback arrangements provided the shareholders retain their holdings for the agreed four year term. Also, the amendments guarantee the survival of the MIC program until 30 June 1989. They have come about following a review, as other speakers have mentioned, of the program by the Bureau of Industry Economics.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments to the highly successful MIC scheme are to be warmly welcomed. They are further evidence of the Labor Government's determination to provide a secure financial base and sound managerial support for innovative high technology industry in Australia. It is essential that we do this. As the Australian Manufacturing Council has argued in its report Future Directions for Australian Manufacturing Industry, which came out this year, skill and technology intensive activities could transform the Australian economy by creating new job opportunities and providing a more secure foundation for continued economic prosperity. With our exports of primary production facing increased competition from often highly subsidised overseas producers who have greater resources-deeper pockets-to do that than we do, the need to adopt a strategy such as this is pressing. We simply must increase the width of our export base if we are to maintain national incomes and living standards at current levels. Therefore, it is imperative that we increase the international competitiveness of manufacturing industry. Developing viable, high technology manufacturing industry is the way in which to do this. Not to do so would be to ignore what the Economic Planning Advisory Committee (EPAC) has identified as `one of the fastest growing areas in world trade' in its report High Technology Industries in Australia which came out this year.

Ignoring those areas is what our conservative opponents, at least until recent times, would have had us do; that is, to ignore the potential of high technology industries to provide a sound economic future for Australia and to shun innovation. Instead of supporting a constructive response to international economic reality, Opposition members merely criticised and carped. They have continually bemoaned the fact that the sheep's back is not as comfortable as it once was. Such complacency typified their time in government. It is a national disgrace that during the Fraser years those who now sit opposite, those great advocates of incentive and enterprise, did nothing to encourage Australians with ideas-Australians who write 2 per cent of the world's scientific papers and who make 0.7 per cent of the world's patent applications despite Australians making up only 0.3 per cent of the world's population. Rather than nurturing such talent for the benefit of our economy, Opposition members drove it overseas, to the unending gratitude of our competitors-and to their economic benefit.

Because our conservative opponents were content to preside over what was one of our worst taxation systems in the world, tax cheats flourished and the incentive to invest productively was destroyed, starving innovators of much-needed funds and decimating manufacturing industry. Thanks to the complacency of those opposite, the share of Australia's gross domestic product being invested in industrial research and development fell to a mere one per cent in 1981-82, compared with research and development investment averaging two and a half times this level in the United States, the United Kingdom, West Germany and Japan. Even worse is the fact that those economic policies made productive investment so unattractive that business research and development spending made up only 22 per cent of an already dismal total.

Fortunately, this Government's record stands in stark contrast to that of our opponents and we have been able to repair at least some of the damage their policies caused. As EPAC concluded in its report High Technology Industries in Australia, to which I have already referred, policies such as the industry offsets program, investment allowances for research and development and the MIC scheme have `improved the country's capacity to innovate'. Indeed, the General Manager of the Queensland Innovation Centre, Dr Ron Sampson, argued at a recent seminar that the Hawke Government's technology programs are amongst the best in the world. He said:

Innovation networks here, without a doubt, are state of the art. They have been able to build on . . . experience . . . overseas, avoiding the pitfalls that others have hit. I am sure that in time Australian innovation networks will be considered an important step in ensuring Australian prosperity for the future.

Together with the deregulation of financial markets to allow second board listings, the MIC scheme has provided Australian innovators with managerial advice and venture capital previously unavailable to them. These amendments will increase our capacity to do this, enabling more companies to commercialise their innovations and inventions. Whilst in June 1983 only about $2m in venture capital was available for high risk, high technology companies, by March of this year the amount available had increased to $310m and it is expected to rise to $570m by March 1988-a staggering increase. As of September this year, MICs had provided $140m of this venture capital figure, supporting 129 businesses across a range of industries. Hence, we are now able to turn the table on our overseas competitors, with MICs meeting applications for venture capital at nearly twice the rate accepted by similar schemes in the United Kingdom and the United States. This is according to data in Rydges magazine of March 1987.

It is a particular pleasure for me to support these amendments because I come from South Australia. I want to talk for a moment about the South Australian connection. Already institutional support for companies under the MIC scheme is producing real economic benefits for Australia which far outweigh the scheme's cost to the taxpayer. At the end of June last year, for example, the companies invested in had a turnover of $150m, export income of $50m, they employed 2,000 people and, by a rough calculation, they generated between $18m and $20m in tax revenue, thus virtually paying for themselves. Many of them, such as the South Australian firm Laserex Pty Ltd, now have the financial resources to go it alone and are seeking listing as second board companies. As a South Australian, I am happy to note that much of this has occurred in Adelaide thanks to the far-sighted policies of the Bannon Government, whose support of high technology extends even beyond the confines of companies licensed under the MIC scheme.

Thanks to the Bannon Government's efforts, Adelaide has been recognised by the Australian Financial Review, among others, as the high tech centre of Australia. This is in no small measure due to the creation of Technology Park, Adelaide, which has been so successful that it is now growing at a rate 10 times that of similar centres in North America. I thoroughly recommend that any member of this House who has not seen Technology Park should go to see it. Already the park has attracted 35 tenants, 32 of which have located their head offices there. That, of course, is a very important step for a company to take. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, in some of the smaller States we are sick of seeing decisions taken by head offices in other States or indeed overseas which bear little relation to the benefit of our home State. The firms which have located their head office in Technology Park include very significant companies such as the Australasian division of British Aerospace and Duntech International, a communications manufacturer which previously had its headquarters in the United States. A very significant firm located in Technology Park is Austek Microsystems, which has produced the very large scale integrated chip. The development of that breakthrough-I think it is clear that that firm is state of the art; it is certainly exporting to Silicon Valley, rather than importing from it-was aided by the location nearby of the Adelaide Innovation Centre and the Adelaide Microelectronics Centre.

Such innovators are not confined to Technology Park in South Australia. Elsewhere in the State a forestry firm has developed a method of using saplings for structural timber that has been acclaimed internationally. I would like to point to a couple of examples in my electorate. The firm Sola Optical, which is the largest employer in the electorate of Kingston, is a vivid example of the benefits of encouraging technological innovation and export oriented manufacturing. Sola Optical enjoys major export success. It is a very large player on the international scene with regard to plastic spectacle lenses because it has been innovative and willing to spend real money in support of a research and development effort. It does the high value added, high technology work at its plant in Lonsdale in Adelaide and has subsidiaries overseas in a number of countries which do what we have been accustomed to believe was our role-that is, the low technology, low value added work. It has reversed the process. If more firms took the attitude that it has taken, our difficulties would be over much sooner than otherwise.

At the other end of the scale I have in my electorate a number of firms which are developing orchid exports. Many people may ask what on earth that has to do with high technology or, indeed, with this Bill. The fact is that nowadays development of orchids for export involves a considerable investment in tissue culturing, cloning and very smart technology which, I am pleased to say, is state of the art in my electorate. I believe that firms such as Adelaide Orchids Pty Ltd and Valley Orchids are now exporting to tough markets such as Japan and the United States, and are doing extremely well. The future of Australia depends on such large and small firms. Amendments like these will yield more firms by guaranteeing a stable venture capital market for other Australian innovators, which will ease their transition from MIC support to true financial independence. No longer are Australian innovators denied venture capital from institutional investors under the provisions of this Bill. No longer are they forced to live on overdrafts or to mortgage their homes in altogether too typical pattern, as we have seen in the past, or to move overseas. With the MIC scheme, they are getting the backing they need to develop their ideas in Australia, for Australians and for the future of this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, for Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and minor amendments to several other Acts to implement decisions announced in the May economic statement and the 1987-88 Budget Speech. This Bill provides for the introduction of the family package which was announced earlier this year as a Labor Government election commitment. The family package is the centrepiece of this Government's attack on child poverty, not only for families where parents depend on social security because they are sick or unemployed, but for working families who have carried the burden of economic adjustment over the past few years.

The family package is based on the basic principle that every Australian child has the right to an adequate standard of living. It is also based on the solid Labor tradition of help for people in need of support. It was the Lang Labor Government which introduced the world's first child endowment-to recognise the extra costs of families with children. The Curtin Labor Government gave child endowment a new priority by increasing payments and extending them to Aboriginal communities and to people with the custody of orphans. The Whitlam Labor Government introduced the handicapped child's allowance to provide extra support to families with handicapped children.

The Hawke Government's family package will build on this record to deliver substantial increases in public support for children. It includes the family allowance supplement-a new payment which aims to help families on low wages meet the day to day expenses of bringing up children. Subject to an income test, a family allowance supplement of $22 a week will be paid for each child under the age of 13, and $28 a week will be paid for 13-, 14- and 15-year-olds in recognition of the extra costs associated with teenage children. The family allowance supplement replaces the family income supplement which paid $17 a week for each child in working families according to a more stringent income test.

In order to make the family allowance supplement an enduring reform, the Government is committed to increase the payment in real terms over the next two years. We will index the payment in the same way we index pensions. In this financial year we estimate that around one million children will enjoy a better standard of living from the tax free benefits of this package-440,000 children in working families and another 740,000 children from out of work families. Child payments for families which depend on income support from social security will be increased automatically in December from $17 a week to the new levels under the family package.

This Labor Government has been steadily increasing payments for children in the social security system. In fact, the family allowance supplement will be the fifth pay increase for the poorest children in our community since 1983. The rate of increase in this Bill is by far the most significant to date. In total, there has been a 120 per cent increase in additional pensions and benefits-the child payments for families on social security-for children aged under 13, and a massive 180 per cent increase for young teenagers over the rates payable under the Fraser Government.

There are two additional parts to the family package. The family package will extend rent assistance of up to $15 a week for low income working families in privately rented homes. This is the first time that rental assistance has been offered to help working families with their housing costs. Families on unemployment and sickness benefit will no longer have to serve a separate waiting period for rent assistance, and will get their help for housing from their first benefit payment. The package also contains more money for disabled children-with the introduction of the new child disability allowance, paid at $112 a month per child to all families with disabled children. The child disability allowance will be income-test free and up to 10,000 additional children are expected to qualify for the payment. The 27,000 severely disabled children currently getting the handicapped child's allowance will be transferred automatically to the new payment-and their allowance will be increased from $92 to $112 a month.

Another 5,000 marginally less disabled children will have the income test on their payments removed and will also receive more money under the family package. The Department of Social Security is to start a major consultation on eligibility criteria for the child disability allowance to make sure that the right children get the right money at the right time. The measures outlined in this Bill demonstrate this Government's firm commitment to ensure that no Australian child need live in poverty by 1990. The package takes the first step towards constructing a new system of public support for children which stresses the need for adequate payments-targeted at those families which need help the most.

This Bill represents substantial gains for our most disadvantaged families which have suffered from the impact of sickness or unemployment. It also highlights the need to support working families bringing up children on low incomes. The family allowance supplement is designed to allow income to increase by 25 per cent over any four week period without affecting payments. This is to accommodate pay fluctuations such as overtime. The structure of this historically important payment aims to encourage people to stay in the work force, where there is potential for them to build a decent standard of living on the basis of an independent wage. The family package will increase the disposable incomes of working families, making them much better off than comparable families living on unemployment benefit.

This emphasis on labour market participation in the structure of social security benefits is reflected by changes contained in this Bill in the area of income support for young people. The job search allowance will replace unemployment benefit for 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds in January-it will make it very clear that income support is closely tied to the need for young people to be better prepared for the work force. The Commonwealth Employment Service will maintain close contact with young people on the job search allowance. Where those young people need extra help to find a job, they can be enrolled in vocational training courses, or instructed in job searching skills. We cannot let our young people waste their potential. The job search allowance aims to give them a helping hand in constructive ways. Job search allowance, sickness benefit and special benefit for people under 18 years will, in most cases, be subject to a parental income test similar to the one which applies to Austudy payments. Job search allowance will be paid at $50 a week, subject to a parental income test-but this test will not reduce the payment below $25 a week. Job search allowance will, of course, be subject to an income test on the young person's own income.

An assets test is being introduced on the payment of unemployment, sickness and special benefits to people who are aged 25 and over. Under the assets test, benefit will generally not be paid to people whose assets exceed a specified amount. These amounts are the same as those used for the pension assets test. The Government expects to save some $24.5m in 1988-89 through the introduction of this initiative. The age of 25 years for the benefits assets test has been included because available information indicates that very few young people below that age would be disqualified by the assets test. Not to include that age threshold would add greatly to administrative costs and effort for very little return. People in financial hardship and not eligible to apply for other forms of Commonwealth income support may receive benefit under the hardship provisions. Under the hardship provisions of the assets test, certain assets can be disregarded. However, income which could reasonably be generated by those disregarded assets is taken into account when calculating the rate of pension payable under the hardship provisions.

Recent interpretations of these provisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have undermined its purpose and effect, so this Bill contains a measure to clarify the Government's intention. Pension calculated under the financial hardship test will be reduced by the greater of 2.5 per cent per annum of the property disregarded under the test; or the income which could reasonably be expected to be obtained from commercial use of the property disregarded under the test. The assets test will also be amended to ensure that the deprivation provisions will apply in situations where the person ceases work and disposes of property at the same time. This is to reverse the effect of a recent Federal Court decision.

The Bill before us also contains measures to clarify the treatment of income from investments and to ensure that people with deferred income, including income from friendly society bonds, are not advantaged over pensioners and beneficiaries with more straightforward forms of income such as that deriving from bank deposits. Depending on the type of investment involved, income will be assessed either on a regular basis throughout the term or, as in the case of market-linked investments, be averaged out over the 12 months after the person realises a profit on the investment. The income from deferred income investments which were obtained before 1 January 1988 will continue to be assessed when it is realised. The double orphans' pension of $60 per month will be extended to children who have one deceased parent and whose surviving parent is a nursing home patient for an indefinite period. The Government considers that the guardians of these children are as deserving of financial assistance as those of children whose surviving parent is receiving treatment in a mental hospital for an indefinite period.

Several changes which will assist pensioners are being introduced in this Bill. The pensioner earnings credit arrangement will encourage pensioners and supporting parents to obtain short term work without reduction in pension. It will help pensioners, particularly sole parents, make the transition between relying on social security payments and being financially independent through employment. Eligibility for carer's pension will be extended to people who are caring for an age or invalid pensioner at home but who are not close relatives. This is a compassionate measure to assist friends to provide care in a home environment for those who are unable to look after themselves. The fringe benefits rules are being changed so that persons whose incomes go above the income limits can retain entitlement to fringe benefits for up to 3 months, provided their incomes do not go over 125 per cent of their limit. This measure will be of particular assistance to pensioners who obtain part time employment or receive other income which is indexed by consumer price index changes and to those receiving overseas payments who have in the past sometimes lost fringe because their income has been affected by fluctuations in exchange rates.

The Bill before us graphically demonstrates this Government's continuing concern for those in our society most in need of support. It provides for significant additional payments to families on modest incomes and for increases in additional payments for children made to pensioners and beneficiaries. The Bill contains measures, such as the assets test on benefits and the parental income test for job search allowance, which will reduce expenditure currently being paid to those who are able to provide for themselves and their families and enable resources to be directed to those in greatest need.

The Bill will also make a number of amendments to the veterans' entitlement legislation. Some of these amendments reflect those which I have already outlined for social security legislation. This will ensure consistency in the treatment of service pensioners and social security pensioners in the following areas, namely, modification of the definition of `income' that is used for the purpose of assessing the rate of service pension payable; amendments to the assets test provisions; easing of the application of the fringe benefits test; and enabling service pensioners to take advantage of earnings credit arrangements.

The Bill also gives legislative effect to the Government's major decision not to allow the adverse interpretations given in three recent Federal Court decisions to the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act relating to eligibility for the totally and permanently incapacitated rate (TPI) and intermediate rate of pension to stand. The Federal Court took the view that the eligibility criteria must be met by a veteran on a continuing basis and that such a pension was not payable after attaining normal retirement age or indefinitely. In order to overcome this interpretation, the Bill provides two related changes. The first will ensure that initial eligibility for the grant of TPI or intermediate rate pension is not to be determined on a continuing basis. Eligibility is to be determined by reference to whether a veteran meets the requirements of section 23 or 24 on the date of lodgment of a pension claim or application.

The amendment will prevent account being taken of alterations in the veteran's circumstances, subsequent to lodging the claim or application, which might adversely affect eligibility. This will avoid the possibility of a grant of TPI or intermediate rate pension that is made being limited by the determining body to a specified period, up to say retirement age, as was adverted to by the Federal Court in the McGuire case.

The second change is to insert a new section 24A in the Veterans' Entitlements Act. This will ensure that persons who are eligible to receive and are receiving a TPI or intermediate rate pension will not ordinarily lose payment of the pension at such a rate in their lifetime. The only exceptions are where the grant of pension would not have been made but for a false statement or misrepresentation or, where the veteran's war-caused incapacity improves to the extent that he or she is undertaking, or becomes capable of undertaking, remunerative work for periods greater than specified in the existing law.

The amendments to be made in respect of TPI and intermediate rate pension do not other- wise affect the changes to eligibility for these pensions made by Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act 1985 and carried through in the Veterans' Entitlements Act and the interpretations given to the relevant provisions by the courts; nor do the amendments affect the powers of the Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review whether the initial grant of TPI or intermediate rate pension was made properly.

Another important change is that, in accordance with the Government's electoral undertaking, the Bill will extend eligibility for full hospital and medical treatment to returned ex-service women of World War II. This recognises the valuable contribution made by such women in the defence of this nation during that war.

Other amendments proposed to be made to veterans affairs legislation provide for increases in the rates of the minor benefits available to eligible persons and increases in the rates of clothing allowance, attendant allowance and recreation transport allowance. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House makes a number of changes to the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act to take account of changes to the Social Security Act introduced in the Budget and the May economic statement. Two of the three changes in this Bill are amendments to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. All three changes relate to the operation of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The first change inserts in the Health Insurance Act a set amount of allowable income in respect of each eligible dependent child to be included in the income test for the health care card for disadvantaged families. This obviates the need to refer to the Social Security Act to determine the appropriate amount.

The second change will enable persons receiving a job search allowance to receive free or concessional pharmaceutical benefit items. The third change will temporarily restore eligibility for free pharmaceutical benefit items to certain former class A widow pensioners and supporting parent beneficiaries who lost their pension or benefit as a result of recent changes to social security legislation.

The Health Insurance Act specifies the income test for the health care card, which allows disadvantaged persons to qualify for concessional pharmaceutical benefits. To be declared as disadvantaged a person's allowable income must be less than an amount determined under the income test provisions of the Act. In determining this amount the Health Insurance Act currently refers to the level of additional benefit payable for each dependent child. With the implementation of the Government's family package there will be different rates of additional benefit for dependent children, depending on their age. A technical amendment is therefore required to make it clear that existing entitlements to the health care card will be retained.

The Bill would therefore amend the Health Insurance Act to substitute a dollar amount of $34 per week for each dependent child in lieu of the current formula based on the additional benefit for children. The amount has been chosen to maintain the current level of additional income for children under the income test for the health care card. The Bill allows for subsequent increases in this amount by regulation. There are considerable advantages, in terms of administrative efficiency and ease of understanding, in retaining an income test based on a single amount allowable per child, rather than introduce an income test defined on the basis of differential amounts according to the age of dependent children.

Clause 8 of the Bill in part relates to the job search allowance for 16- to 17-year-olds. The allowance, to come into effect from 1 January 1988, necessitates amending the National Health Act to include those persons in its definition of pensioner and concessional beneficiary. The amendment enables recipients of a job search allowance to receive prescription pharmaceuticals at the concessional rate of $2.50 while medically fit to search for work and at no charge when the recipient is sick and unable to seek work. These provisions would effectively leave unchanged the pharmaceutical entitlements available to people aged 16 and 17 years who currently qualify for unemployment or sickness benefits. A further amendment to the National Health Act will restore, until the end of 1988, eligibility for pensioner health benefit cards and thus free pharmaceutical benefits for those persons whose entitlement to class A widows pension or supporting parents benefit ceased between 1 September 1987 and 31 December 1987 as a result of changes announced in the May Economic Statement restricting such payments to those with children under 16. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1987, the purpose of which is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act of 1979 and to fix charge rates for overseas students for the 1988 academic year. Students entering courses for the first time at universities, institutes, colleges of advanced education or technical and further education colleges will pay 55 per cent of the full average cost of their courses as a fee which is up from the 45 per cent paid in 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of an earlier Opposition initiative forced on the Government in the Senate some time ago, students who entered courses in earlier years remain at the lower recovery level at which they entered their courses. We believed that it was only fair that if students had come to Australia with a particular understanding of a course cost they should not suffer any more than an adjustment for inflation and so on over the period of their course. It would be unfair for them to pay an additional percentage of the full recovery in succeeding years. There is also an increase in the charge for secondary students coming from overseas, in line with the increase in the consumer price index, from $300 a year to $328 a year.

As a result of these changes, the charges that will be made by the institutions are, for higher places, about $5,000 or $6,000, so they are quite considerable, but nonetheless we have attracted quite a number of overseas students. There is an element of subsidy in the charge that is set, and the Government sets a quota on the number of overseas students allowed in under the subsidised scheme. For 1988 a new quota is being set at 3,500 people as new entrants in all categories, so the total next year of overseas students subject to subsidised places is 3,400 secondary students and 13,300 tertiary students, of which 800 will attend technical and further education colleges. There are 16,700 subsidised places overall and of these, the Commonwealth meets fees for 1,000. They are sponsored students under our overseas aid schemes, plus another 1,700 subsidised students from Papua New Guinea, China and the South Pacific on another regional program. That leaves 14,000 students liable for the overseas students charge. The Budget Papers say 14,500 as a total, but I could not understand where the 500 came from.

The receipts for 1987-88 from this charge are $64.8m, up $15m over 1986-87. Outside the quotas, the institutions may offer places to overseas students on a full fee basis, that is, full recovery of costs. They may retain the fees but there is a cutback in the funds available to them in capital grants over the years ahead as a partial offset.

For students from developing countries, and that is 95 per cent of them, the balance of the cost to the Commonwealth over and above the charge recovered through this program is contributed by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), and that is part of our overseas aid program. The AIDAB contribution to the education budget is $85.1m in 1987-88, which is down $2.8m from the previous year. The Opposition supports the concept of aid to students from surrounding developing countries. It is something that coalition governments have pursued over a very long period. The Colombo Plan was set up under the Menzies Government, and I think it may even have been established by Sir Percy Spender as Minister for External Affairs, as he was called in those days.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly was.
—It is nice to see present his son, the honourable member for North Sydney, participating in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: This support for overseas students coming to Australia has a long and honoured history in our coalition parties, and we certainly support the Government's continuation of similar programs. We are concerned that the amount that has gone through on this is down by $2.8m on the previous year. We support the subsidisation of overseas students here because we believe that we are making a contribution to the development in those countries, but also we get a lot out of it. There is an important cultural enrichment on our campuses. I can certainly remember from 30 years ago, when I was on the campus of Sydney University, meeting, for the first time, a number of students from surrounding countries, and that gave me my first understanding of their life-styles and cultures, and something about them. I have made firm friends from that period, whom I still have.

The admission of overseas students over this period has assisted, very much, tolerance and understanding in the Australian community. There has been some friction, and the friction on campuses is always highlighted by the Press searching for some sort of sensational story. My understanding, certainly from my experience and that of my children at university these days, is that the overall effect of the presence of these students is to enrich the campuses and to provide a basis of understanding between students from Australia and those from surrounding countries. Therefore, it is of considerable importance to Australia, not just in the sense that we are trying to contribute to the development of the countries of origin.

In addition to the foreign aid subsidy of students, the Opposition supports the attraction of fee paying overseas students, but we do not support the arbitrary and unnecessary restrictions on institutions governing the enrolment of fee paying students. Therefore, I would like to move on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to the motion as follows:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) its arbitrary and unnecessary restrictions on the rights of tertiary institutions to attract fee paying students from overseas; and
(2) refusing admission into tertiary education to Australian students who are not awarded a free place but who are prepared to pay a fee for admission on the same basis as overseas students'.

That second point is a very important one because, unfortunately, the Government has got itself into a terrible hang-up over this charging of fees. Universities and colleges of advanced education are allowed by the Government to admit overseas students prepared to pay fees, but not Australian students. As a result of this absurd policy, some 20,000 qualified students were denied entry to universities and colleges this year, when many would have been prepared to pay a fee to gain entry. This really amounts to gross discrimination against Australian students. This farcical situation has arisen basically because of the hang-ups of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) on tertiary fees. Although the ALP platform is against tertiary fees, the Government has been prepared to charge a disguised fee in the form of an administration charge and next year is introducing fees for higher degree courses. It also seems permissible in the Government's eyes to charge overseas students a tuition fee. But when it comes to opening up additional places above and beyond the free places provided by the taxpayer for Australian school leavers, the Government is paralysed by its internal political squabbles. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) should admit that the Government's fee policy is already a farce and act to open up our universities and colleges to all qualified applicants for the 1988 academic year.

If one follows ALP politics, one will know that this is a very emotional subject within that Party. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his policy speech on 23 June 1987, said, `We are opposed to tertiary tuition fees'. The word `tuition' is carefully chosen. This is a careful subterfuge on the part of the Prime Minister to try to make out that the Government has not already imposed fees for tertiary students in the form of the so-called higher education administration charge. A fee is a fee is a fee as far as the Opposition and students are concerned, and this fee was introduced at $250 for the current year and will go up to $263 for the next year. To call it an administration charge to try to make the Prime Minister's promise in the election and in the ALP platform seem to mean something, we believe is typical of the kind of misrepresentation that the Government indulges in all the time.

The real difficulty goes back to the ALP platform. I have here an extract from the 1986 platform and clause 26 says unequivocally: `Maintain the provision of free tertiary education'. As far as I am concerned, any reading of that would preclude the Government from imposing the higher administration--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair interrupts the honourable member. The honourable member for Lilley will desist. If she seeks to speak with the advisers she should do so from the other side. From where she is, she technically admits them to chamber and they become strangers in the chamber and subject to the consequence of that action.
—To go back to the ALP platform, paragraph 20 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Maintain the provision of free tertiary education.

That paragraph is clearly breached by the higher education administration charge. There is no question about that. If the Prime Minister, having used in his policy speech the words `We are opposed to tertiary tuition fees', believes that he can follow the platform by the use of the word `tuition' and adding `administration charge', he is talking through his hat. Paragraph 24 in the ALP platform states:
Ensure that overseas marketing of education does not undermine free access by Australians to tertiary institutions, or the quality of the education provided.

It is quite clear that the drafters of the program wanted to pin the Government down on this issue of fees; in other words, they say that there should not be any fees at all. The Opposition's position on this matter is quite clear; we made it clear before the last election. We say that there should be made available the number of free places that the taxpayer has been accustomed to supporting. That is increased year by year in line with budgetary arrangements and what is available from revenues from taxpayers. In addition to that we say that the institution should be free to admit Australian or overseas students on such terms and conditions as they wish to decide. Over and above that there is the subsidy for overseas student places provided through the foreign aid programs of the Government.

Let us get it quite clear what the Opposition is in favour of. We are wholly in favour of the free places currently available to students at tertiary education institutions being maintained and changed each year in accordance with our budgetary capacity. We are fully in favour of foreign aid subsidy to overseas students, certainly those from developing countries, in line with our past practice and for the reasons I gave earlier in my speech. We believe also that the institutions should have the flexibility over and above that to be able to admit students on terms and conditions mutually acceptable to the institutions and the students. That would remove this absurd restriction which would require, in the present case, the institutions to charge on a full recovery basis. If the institutions wish to expand the numbers of students they have on a marginal costing basis, that is fine. They can admit more Australian students-this would be a very important benefit of our policy-from amongst those 20,000 students who were qualified to enter higher education this year but were not able to get in because of the lack of places in the institutions under current funding arrangements.

The question of fees is developing very strongly. It is quite clear that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, for a very long time has been in favour of the concept of imposing tertiary fees much more generally than they are now imposed. That is quite clear from his speeches. He has argued for that in the Cabinet over a long period and it was resisted tooth and nail by the previous Minister for Education, Senator Ryan. She lost the battle on the administration charge-or that particular fee which had to be dressed up as a so-called administration charge. It is quite clear to me from the statement on higher education made by the current Minister but also from remarks he has made to a number of people in recent times that he agrees with Senator Walsh and he believes that fees ought to be charged.

Our purpose in allowing institutions to charge fees over and above the free places is twofold. Firstly, we want to provide some avenue for at least some of the 20,000 or more students who are qualified to enter universities but cannot, to get in by paying a fee. If the fee is charged on a marginal basis for some courses by those institutions, it may be quite a modest one, and that would be a valuable addition to the numbers of students able to take advantage of tertiary education. The other important reason why we believe it should be pursued is that we want to give the institutions more flexibility in managing their own resources. There is a very important debate developing on higher education in Australia today. It is really a clash between the Minister and us. I believe it is building up resistance on the part of the institutions to the general thrust of the Minister's policy.

I think we all agree that we want more resources to go into higher education; there is no question about that. Our comparisons internationally are not good. We all believe that our education system should be providing more people who are better skilled, better trained and better educated both for the work force and for the enrichment of our cultural life. We all want that. Taxpayers' funds are limited and so we all want to expand tertiary education at the minimum cost to the taxpayer. The Minister and I would certainly agree on that.

We also want to improve the performance of the institutions, but where the gap is opening up is in the belief on the part of the Minister that this can best be done by putting the sources of advice to the Minister into a single pot-that is, the new National Board of Employment, Education and Training-and by bringing about change by central direction from the Government. Change in the institutions has been proceeding at too slow a pace within the highly regulated environment in which they work. Whilst the institutions have had historical rigidities, they have had superimposed on those rigidities a number of other rigidities by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and by the rules laid down by the central Government.

The present Minister clearly believes that the pace of adaptation of these institutions and their flexibility can be speeded up by central direction. He has lectured them on their shortcomings and he is obviously taking more power into his own hands in an attempt to change the structure, nature, management and courses of the institutions. I believe that approach will be counter-productive. The Opposition has a very firm view that we will achieve a better result if, on the one hand, we make the institutions more responsive to consumer demands and if, on the other hand, we give them more control over their own resources. We believe that the more we delegate authority in this system, the more we free up the institutions to respond to needs. The more power we give to the consumers to make a choice between individual courses and institutions through the higher education scholarships, which we propose in our policy, the more we devolve the whole problem and the better result we get.

I do not have a great deal of faith in central government departments being able to decide what is best in the national interest. They can certainly indicate from time to time any feelings the Government might have about the direction of national interest at any particular time-I do not object to that-but for them to try to force on the institutions their single views, often based on advice from permanent public servants here in Canberra, of what is the national interest now and over the next 20 or 30 years is a grave mistake. I have much greater faith--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the honourable gentleman, whilst offering to the House words of undoubted value, is fairly testing relevance. I invite him to come back to this rather restricted Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will just relate that to this fee question because it is an integral part of that question. If you will allow me one more paragraph on this, I will relate it to the fees.
—The honourable member has the Chair's indulgence.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will make it clear what the link is. The institutions will make their own myriad of decisions in the education market-place in meeting the needs of their customers-that is, the students-and in meeting the needs of their teaching staff and their researchers. They will be making these decisions all over the place. It is a pluralistic system. I have more faith in the overall outcome of all those hundreds of thousands of individual decisions being right for Australia in the medium to long term than I have in the capacity of a group of people in Canberra to say that this is what is needed in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you may well ask how this relates to fees. The flexibility of the resources of these institutions is a key part of this. Whilst those institutions rely virtually wholly on the taxpayer for their funding, that taxpayer funding will be accompanied by close regulation and it will also be limited by the capacity of the taxpayer to pay. The more that money is provided through private sources-through fees, sponsorship from industry, or whatever means-the more that those people are able to adapt in the market-place and make their individual decisions, some of which will be quite different from others. But, overall, they are more likely to reflect the national interest in the longer term than bureaucratic impositions. That really is the link between this overall debate on the future of higher education and this important issue of fees.

To summarise, we are not denying the Bill a passage. We have moved an amendment to draw attention to the fact that there is too much regulation on the institutions in their capacity to charge fees for overseas students. At the same time, whilst they are allowed currently to charge fees to overseas students and admit those students to places in Australian universities, over and above the free Australian quota, they are not allowed to accept qualified Australian students able to pay a fee on the same basis as overseas students. Whilst there are 20,000 qualified students wanting to get places in 1987 which are simply not available, it makes no sense at all to us to restrict the universities and colleges in this way. We believe that they should be free to admit Australian students on at least the same basis as they admit overseas students.

We would go further than that. We would allow the institutions to admit either overseas or Australian students over and above the Government's subsidised ones in whatever way they chose and, in so doing, at the same time we would be freeing up those institutions to be more adaptable, to be more flexible, and to be able to manage themselves more effectively and, we believe, meet the national interest far more effectively than would be the case if decisions were imposed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on the advice of the Public Service in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.
