TALK.START.PARA: —The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, which is before the House, amends section 6 of the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the overseas students charge rates for the 1988 academic year. This follows the statement made by the then Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, in May of this year, when she announced that the overseas students charge for new students enrolling in the triennium 1988-90 for all higher education courses would be set at 55 per cent of full average cost. For these students the actual charge in 1988 will be of the order of $6,313, or $7,153, depending on whether the student is entering a high or low cost course and depending on the full average cost of higher education places for subsidised overseas students. As indicated by Senator Ryan at that time, the 55 per cent rate of charge will be held constant throughout the period of the 1988-90 triennium for all those entering during that period. No students enrolled in the 1988-90 triennium will face the prospect of paying an increased proportion of full average costs in that period.

SPEECH.PARA: For university and advanced education courses enrolled in and commenced before 1 January 1986, $4,456 has been allocated for medicine, veterinary science and dentistry, and $3,663 has been allocated for all other courses. For courses enrolled in and commenced from 1 January 1986 to 31 December 1987, $5,999 has been allocated for medicine, veterinary science or dentistry, and $5,159 has been allocated for all other courses. For courses enrolled in and commenced on or after 1 January 1988, $7,153 has been allocated for medicine, veterinary science or dentistry, and $6,313 has been allocated for all other courses. The amount of the overseas students charge for university and advanced education courses will be reduced by $263-the amount of the higher education administration charge payable to institutions by all higher education students in respect of the enrolment.

For students in technical and further education (TAFE) courses who commenced before 1987, the overseas students charge in 1988 will be $593; it will be $833 for students who commenced in 1987, and $1,018 for new students in 1988. The charge has, in this way, been held at a fixed percentage of costs for TAFE students also. For all post-secondary students in the subsidised program, therefore, the only increase in the overseas students charge each year will be to reflect price movements. In fixing the rate of charge as a percentage of full average cost for the forthcoming triennium, the Government has strived to give students and their parents the degree of certainty and predictability they need to be able to plan in advance to meet the cost of studying in Australia. The overseas students charge for overseas secondary students will continue at the current level of $300, adjusted only for movements in the consumer price index. For 1988 this means a charge of the order of $328.

I understand the plight of people in underdeveloped nations who look for assistance to developed nations such as Australia. It is the duty of developed nations such as Australia to assist but we must do so in a cost-effective manner. It helps no one-the students least of all-to be irrational or to overlook certain realities. One aspect we should consider is the ability and desire of the families of some overseas students to pay. Families of many foreign students are ready and obviously able to pay for a quality education and should be allowed to do so. South East Asian countries spend $2,000m a year on education-most of it in the United States of America and Europe-and the figure is growing rapidly. Malaysia alone has 65,000 students overseas. At the end of June there were more than 9,000 full fee paying foreign students in Australia. According to George Tarjan, Manager of the Trade and Service Branch of the Australian Trade Commission, those students pay an estimated $24m in fees alone. Mr Tarjan has gone on record as saying that that figure could quickly increase to more than $100m as more Australian facilities open their doors to Asian students. This increase has been building up since the Federal Government decided two years ago to allow foreign students to attend any institution with room for them, as long as they paid all their own costs and did not displace Australians.

There are students who want our education and want to pay for it. In fact, Sue-Anne MacKnay who helps market private education services through the Western Australian Government's trading arm has pointed out that Australian education is much cheaper than that offered by other Western countries. Ms MacKnay notes that students who are travelling to the United States or Europe could easily be educated in Australia. We can offer a high standard of education cheater and closer to home. This is why guidelines were released in 1985 when the Government announced its new policy on overseas students under which universities and colleges of advanced education are able to offer full fee courses for overseas students. Of course, many potential students are not in this position. The Australian Government is very aware of and sensitive to this fact. The report entitled Mutual Advantage of the Committee of Review of Private Overseas Students Policy of March 1984 indicated quite clearly that over 50 per cent of students are not affluent by Australian standards and, in fact, are lagging. It has been estimated that there will be 3,400 subsidised places for overseas secondary students and 13,300 subsidised places for overseas tertiary students, including 800 TAFE students, in 1988. We believe that that is important.

The estimated number of students liable for the overseas student charge in 1987-88 will be approximately 14,500. This figure does not include some 1,000 sponsored students and some 1,700 subsidised students from Papua New Guinea, China and South Pacific Islands whose liability is met from Australia's aid program. The Government is to continue to pay charges for subsidised private students from Papua New Guinea and South Pacific Island countries, for some students from China and for students sponsored by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), at a total cost of about $8.8m in 1987-88. These funds are to be appropriated through AIDAB and form part of Australia's overseas aid program. To reflect the fact that charges paid by overseas students, or on their behalf, do not cover full costs, further funds are to be appropriated through AIDAB.

Of course, a contribution towards the education of students is also made by developing countries. That should be recognised. The overseas student charge paid by, or on behalf of, overseas students in Australian institutions is estimated to cover between 32 per cent and 55 per cent of the Commonwealth contribution towards the cost of providing places for those students. For students from developing countries, the balance of the cost to the Commonwealth is identified as the contribution to the education budget by AIDAB. Some 95 per cent of overseas students are from developing countries which, in general, derive substantial economic and other benefits from the education of their citizens in Australia. This is as it should be.

It has been difficult in the past to be able to determine the full socio-economic and ethnic background of overseas students, but the report entitled Mutual Advantage, to which I referred earlier, gives some indication of major sources for students. At the secondary and tertiary level, 50 per cent are from Malaysia; 13 per cent from Hong Kong; 7 per cent from Indonesia; 5 per cent from Singapore and 4 per cent from Fiji. It is interesting to look at the ethnic make up of people from different countries. Taking Malaysia, which is the largest country of origin for overseas students in Australia, in 1984 the breakup was 71 per cent of Chinese origin, 10 per cent Malay and 4 per cent Indian. For Fiji, 56 per cent were Indian, 13 per cent Chinese and 11 per cent Fijian.

While it is true that to study in Australia is not a cheap undertaking and that a very large number of overseas students are ethnic Chinese, as I have just demonstrated, on the whole they are not, by Australian standards, rich. For most of them their experience of Australia is not easy financially but it is generally found worth while. They form part of a diverse community which makes a contribution to Australia as well as receiving benefits from it. For years the Australian Government has acknowledged this two-way benefit-the process of communication between overseas and Australian students.

Australia is held in high regard by nations such as Sri Lanka for our training and expertise in agriculture and other areas. The continuing transfer of this technology is desirable and, in fact, should be increased as conditions allow. I mention that to put in context the overall spectrum of the ways in which developed nations such as Australia can assist underdeveloped countries and strengthen bonds between ourselves and our neighbours. Sri Lanka still regards Australia with affection, not only because of recent strong ties but also, as the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) pointed out, because of the introduction of the Colombo Plan in the 1950s and the involvement of Sir Percy Spender. The Colombo Plan and action at that time focused official attention in Australia on overseas students. When I visited Sri Lanka at the end of last year as leader of an Australian delegation, I became aware of the very warm feelings on the part of the Sri Lankan people towards the Australian Government and Sir Percy Spender. There is a tie between Australia and Sri Lanka which has strengthened, and the student intake is part of that.

Development assistance became the principal objective for both the sponsored student program, which grew out of the Colombo Plan, and the private student program which had been developing slowly but steadily. This pattern continued throughout the 1960s and into the early 1970s. In 1973 a review of the overseas student program developed a policy with three major features: one was that development assistance ceased to be the major objective, allowing overseas students to enter Australia to undertake a much broader range of studies. Secondly, a ceiling of 10,000 was placed on the total number of private overseas students. Thirdly, because of the more liberal possibilities offered by the new program, overseas students had to convince authorities that they were bona fide students, and they would be required to leave Australia on completion of their studies.

However, pressures grew both domestically and internationally. In 1980-81, Britain introduced a full cost policy for overseas students and by 1983 many of the students in our region, who otherwise would have gone to the United Kingdom, were seeing the advantages of an Australian education. The number of private overseas students in tertiary education in Australia grew from 6,700 in 1979, compared with 6,300 in 1973, to 10,600 in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many from Malaysia.

—Certainly, as the honour- able member for Farrer points out. Over the same period, the number of overseas secondary students grew from 1,400 to more than 5,000, and a very high percentage of those secondary students would have gone on to tertiary studies. There continue to be fully sponsored students, which is most essential, selected on the basis of development assistance needs by their own governments and funded entirely by the Australian Government through AIDAB.

SPEECH.PARA: This does not mean that our effort stops here. It does not mean that, in future times as the financial situation allows, there should not be further development generally in the area of aid, particularly in the case of those people who are having a very hard time of it. Currently, the bulk of overseas students continue to be privately subsidised students. This legislation, in fixing overseas student charge rates for 1988, forms part of Australia's threefold approach to overseas student development; that is, sponsored students to meet specific development assistance aims; subsidised students to take account of broader educational, cultural and goodwill consideration; and full fee students. I have great pleasure in recommending this legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1987, in which the Government proposes to set the charges for the 1988 academic year in relation to those students from overseas. It seems quite extraordinary that on a Bill which sets the charges for overseas students the Opposition is discussing the merits of having Australians paying full fees in universities. Good heavens! Surely the Opposition remembers that in 1972 the Whitlam Government dispensed with fees for tertiary education and thereby implanted within our Australian education system the notion of equity. That is what we as a Government stand for-education for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this amendment is not about education for Australians; it is simply the way in which the Australian Government proposes to look after those students who study in Australia who happen to come from overseas and the way in which we approach that program. The full fee program, as it is now called, has a twofold purpose. Firstly, it provides more opportunities for overseas students to study in Australia, without displacing Australian students, at no cost to the Australian Government. Secondly, it provides a source of foreign exchange as part of the Government's drive to improve export earnings in the services sector generally. Historically, we have had overseas students in Australia since 1904; that is, students from within our own region have come to Australia to seek and to gain from what they believe to be a high quality education process. We acknowledge the work that Sir Percy Spender did in the 1950s in developing the Colombo Plan which set out to provide assistance in the form of education for those countries in our region specifically as part of the development aid program.

I, too, was a student at university in the 1960s and made friends with a large number of students who came from Asia. It was at that time, of course, the beginning of our acknowledgment that we were geographically part of Asia, that our future lay within acknowledging such and also that we as a country could make a very real contribution to those areas in our region which were developing and seeking our expertise. It was decided that education of people from those countries would enable them then to go back to their own country and make a contribution to the economy, to employment and, of course, to export earnings. Indeed, I can refer to two personal friends who, having studied agriculture here, now run very large plantations within the islands not far from here and who make a very great contribution to their country's employment situation and export earnings. That is one aspect of students having studied here in Australia, as was the object of the Colombo Plan.

However, the situation has changed. Those students who came to Australia in the 1960s recognised and acknowledged that they would need to go home, that they were being helped and that Australia was offering assistance. With the discarding of the white Australia policy in 1973 and the decision to abolish tertiary fees within our education institutions, our overseas student program took on a very different meaning. It meant that many Asian students here would be able to stay and take advantage of migration policies. It also meant that they would be able not only to participate as people to whom we were giving assistance but to participate within the Australian economy and within the Australian system in general. That process continued and developed until the 1980s, when the United Kingdom introduced full tertiary fees for all of its overseas students. As the honour- able member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has said, we saw many Asian students wishing to come to Australia to pursue their education because it was closer and because through those Colombo Plan students who had returned to their home- land our Asian neighbours had developed an affinity with Australia.

The discarding of the white Australia policy also meant that within Asia Australia was seen as a country of integrity. It was no longer seen as being paternalistic in its approach to its Asian neighbours; nor was the thrust seen to be simply one of development and assistance. While we acknowledge that our overseas student programs come under our foreign aid umbrella, we must also acknowledge that they contribute in a very real sense to our export earnings. We acknowledge that students who come here to work and live spend money on accommodation and transport. Of course, the figure was close to $70m in the last financial year. That means that overseas students are making a very real financial contribution to the Australian economy. Of course, we acknowledge their contribution on a cultural level. Members of both the Government and the Opposition have said that the cultural benefits to the Australian community cannot be measured. In terms of tolerance, cultural exchange, generosity of spirit and, of course, very real education, the contribution which overseas students have made to the Australian education scene is very high. We would, of course, wish that to continue.

However, we must acknowledge that we live in a time of financial restraint. We must balance the kind of aid which we can give to students who are most deserving and who come from the very poorest countries with that given to students who can afford to pay and who seek the kind of quality education which the Australian institutions offer; hence, the overseas student charges attempt to address that second group. The charges are not large. In fact, as Senator Ryan promised when she brought down the rules, the fees will not change for a whole triennium. They do not cover the full cost to the Government and/or to the institutions. Over 13,000 students are enjoying an Australian education under such a program. Indeed, Madam Deputy Speaker, as you will be aware, in 1983 the report of the Goldring Committee of Review of Private Overseas Students Policy quantified for the first time the notion of the hidden subsidy. As I have already said, it was in the region of $70m. So while we acknowledge that overseas students make a contribution in a cultural sense to our community, we are now also able to recognise in a quantitative way the contribution that overseas students make to our economy.

We as a Government must not look only at that matter. We have made a commitment-which, as I said, goes back to 1904-that overseas students may participate and study in Australia. It is imperative that we continue to honour that, and not at the expense of places for our own youth, but in a spirit of generosity and of sharing, as part of the Asian region in which we all live. To suggest, as the Opposition has, that tertiary education for Australians will now be the prerogative of the fee payers is anathema to Government members.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I can only recommend to you the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. I look forward to it being put in place and to many overseas students participating fully in what is acknowledged as one of the very best and most equitable education systems in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first occasion on which I have had the opportunity of following the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford). I compliment her on an excellent address. She indicated that she was born in a glorious part of Australia called Toowoomba. She received part of her education there, and also attended the same school in Brisbane as my wife and daughter. She displayed a little bit of the milk of human kindness that is appropriate from a Queenslander. The kindly and thoughtful reference that she made to Sir Percy Spender prevented her from criticising the previous speaker from this side of the House, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). Maybe like her, I had some difficulty in understanding the relevance of the points that he made, on account of the type of legislation that we are debating.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that a pious amendment to the motion for the second reading has been moved. Occasionally one may question whether it is really an example of piety to move a pious motion. One is either for a piece of legislation or against it. I believe that this is a good piece of legislation. In the quietness of my mind, I cannot advance an argument as to why there should be free tuition for overseas students in Australia. After all, as the previous speaker said, other countries such as the United Kingdom introduced fees for overseas students some years ago. It is a world-wide trend.

This type of legislation gives us the opportunity to establish and weigh up the benefits against the costs of the present system. Australia simply cannot afford to isolate itself from student mobility. It is a very mobile society. I was interested to read the statistics which show that there are an estimated one million students studying at higher educational levels in countries other than their own. The major receiving countries are the United States of America which takes about 32 per cent; France, 13 per cent; and the United Kingdom, 4.5 per cent, down from 7 per cent in 1978. I wonder why that United Kingdom figure is so. I would like to investigate that in some future debate. Canada takes 3 per cent and Australia about 1.2 per cent, not a very high percentage. There seems to be an enthusiasm in Australia, not only by governments, to encourage people to come here to obtain a university education. I would have thought that colleges of advanced education and our technical and further education (TAFE) system also offer equal qualifications, depending on what end product is required. We need to make sure that we are not just emphasising universities and forgetting about colleges of advanced education and TAFE.

Four categories of students come to Australia under the private overseas students quota controlled program, and they number about 14,500. This is obviously an excellent system. It gives the opportunity to people who do not have the wherewithal for an education in their own country to obtain one here. I fully subscribe to the proposition that education should be available to all people, irrespective of the means of their parents or those who look after them. That is an excellent concept. Higher education is not, and must not, be the prerogative of the rich. For heaven's sake we got rid of that 20 years ago and we will not go back to that. I will not support that type of approach. Let us educate all children, and give them all that opportunity.

The reservoir of wisdom does not happen to reside automatically with the sons and daughters of the rich. Other kids also have ability if they are given the opportunity. This is a marvellous program based on assistance to people on a means basis and not on a wealth basis. It provides an opportunity for people who have the wherewithal to come out here. I am not going to discourage them; that is their good luck. They are catered for, but we must give assistance to those who do not have the opportunity. I support that fully. Perhaps I should like to see it increased.

I understand from the remarks of the honourable member for Forde that we are in difficult economic times. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau program caters for about 1,500 students. I should like to see that increased. I can understand how that is not possible but that is how I should like to see taxpayers' funds being spent, rather than in providing facilities for the rich.

The point I am particularly keen about, and the main reason why I sought to participate in the debate, is that I believe there is a need to examine off-shore education-the provision of education in the native country by Australian institutions. I applaud the initiative of the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education for what it is doing for people in Hong Kong, Malaysia and Thailand. Some 600 students are involved in programs at the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education. Most of them are interested in business or computer studies.

In a final analysis-and I hope that education authorities in Australia will consider this-perhaps we would do better to export education to the students in their home countries because more students would have the opportunity to participate, instead of forcing them to leave their cultural backgrounds and come out here. Maybe what we need is a mix-an increase in the export of education and a continuation of the present system. Education is a highly marketable commodity and we need to be sure we get the best value for the taxpayers' dollar.

The final point I want to make is that we need to monitor the program continually to ensure that the people who come out here for access to higher education get the skills they seek. I do not think we have achieved anything at all with an overseas education program if the end result is that a considerable percentage of the students who come here remain here. Surely the whole concept is to improve the well-being, the health, the economic and social conditions or whatever of the people of the poorer countries-particularly those countries in South East Asia for whom we have a special responsibility. I do not and will not support those people coming out here and staying here because it happens to be perhaps a better place to live. They can do much better by returning to their own countries and making an attack on poverty.

These are just a few points I wanted to make to indicate my total support and commitment for providing educational opportunities to poor people. The Australian taxpayer should be aware that education is a mobile commodity and that we have responsibilities in the south-east Pacific. we must make sure that qualifications earned in Australia are recognised in the home countries and, finally, that people who come out here should, wherever possible, consistent with needs as they arise, go back to help the people who made the sacrifices to send them here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 by fixing the overseas students charge rates for the 1988 academic year. The charge rates for overseas students will be increased to 55 per cent of the full average cost to the Commonwealth of places for new students who will commence university, advanced education and technical and further education courses on or after 1 January 1988. Charges will continue at the current percentage for courses commenced before January 1988. Details of the charge rates are indicated in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The overseas student charge was introduced in January 1987 for overseas post-graduate students enrolling in courses on or after that date. It applies to Government sponsored and institutionally sponsored students but it does not apply to post-graduate students from New Zealand or to students undertaking ad hoc or special courses or to students enrolling in courses prior to January 1987. The decision to introduce the overseas students charge for post-graduate students was motivated by the difficult Budget situation confronting Australia and the need to offset some of the cost to the Australian taxpayer of maintaining the overseas student program. The decision to introduce the overseas students charge for post-graduate students did have an impact on the opportunities for James Cook University to encourage more post-graduate students to study at that excellent university.

The effect in 1987 on Government sponsored post-graduate scholarships and award programs for developed countries was offset by supplementary funding. In 1988 and subsequent years, however, the overseas students charge will have to be met from program funds. It is expected that this will cause about a 15 per cent reduction in the number of Government awards and scholarships available. There have been allegations that the high overseas student charge is causing unnecessary hardship. These claims have not been substantiated. This year, of the approximately 17,300 overseas students liable for the charge, only 107-less than one per cent-had not paid by the end of September. Of these, none had made a case of hardship to the Government.

Although the charge now represents a significant contribution on the part of the families concerned, it is undeniable that, as Australians contribute to the cost of their education through the taxation system, overseas students should also contribute directly to the costs involved. This is accepted explicitly by all overseas students as a condition of entry at the time of their admission to Australia. Overseas students can meet the cost of the overseas students charge by working-they are allowed to work up to 20 hours per week-or, in the case of Malaysians, by resort to the Malaysian Government revolving loan fund. Tertiary students who commenced study before 1988 will continue to pay at the rate of 45 per cent of full average cost-or 32 per cent if they began in 1985 or before. As I said earlier, students commencing in 1988 will be required to pay 55 per cent of the full average cost. These charges continue to compare favourably with those for comparable quality courses in other major host countries such as the United States of America and Canada.

The opportunities to market successfully educational services to foreign students has been acknowledged by Australian Governments for a long time. Indeed, Australia has a long and distinguished history of supply of educational services in, particularly, the Pacific, South East Asia and South Asian regions. Over many years Australia has developed an excellent reputation for the quality of its higher education sector. This excellent reputation has led to a consistently high level demand from overseas students for places in Australian higher education institutions. It has been responsible for a tremendous fund of good will. It has allowed Australian academics to become involved in the academic life of our region and in turn, this has led to Australian higher education institutions providing increasingly advanced support and investigation of a whole range of issues for the development of the region. The James Cook University of North Queensland is participating very actively in this role. Marine science, tropical veterinary science and engineering are three areas in which James Cook University has been most successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great university.

—Indeed, a great university. The university has been most successful not only in providing educational services but also has been successfully engaged in investigation and support services on behalf of a number of governments in the region which have taken advantage of the wide range of expertise provided by the university. In July 1985 the then Minister for Trade, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), announced that two education trade survey missions aimed at developing exports of Australian educational services would visit South East Asia and Hong Kong. This initiative was a recognition by the Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government, that tertiary education was a key service area which offered significant potential for the development of an export activity. Members of these missions on their return suggested that Australia could earn $100m a year by 1988 by marketing educational services to foreign students. The mission's final report recommended to the Federal Government that educational institutions, government bodies and private corporations be allowed to market educational services to overseas students. The mission identified a strong regional market for such services, particularly in Indonesia and Malaysia. It also found demand in Hong Kong and Thailand and the prospect of marketing services to the Philippines and Singapore.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government responded positively to the mission's report. The then Minister for Trade immediately encouraged the universities and colleges to develop their own courses and services in South East Asia. They were encouraged to offer undergraduate courses in Australia or overseas, short courses of up to six months in Australia or overseas, post-graduate courses and occasional and technical training. The then Minister said that the Government would set up educational universities in South East Asian and other Asian countries to help develop the market. By February 1987 the educational services were a new, bright spot in Australia's export trade. There had been a massive increase in the number of courses offered to full fee paying overseas students by Australia's universities and colleges. At the beginning of this year 370 courses were offered compared with only 16 in 1986-the first year of the full fee program, which had been introduced in 1985. Even the number of overseas secondary students buying Australia's educational services has tripled since 1986 from 250 to nearly 800 students in 1987. Ten secondary schools, three technical and further education colleges, 17 colleges of advanced education and 13 universities are now offering full cost courses. By July 1987 Australia's new export trade in tertiary education services was undergoing a boom in South East Asia. Approximately 2,000 new students from South East Asia are expected to buy an education in Australia this year-more than three times the number of students for 1986 when full fee enrolments began. There are indications that this is only a small fraction of the market.

It is convincing proof that Australia can profitably market education services to foreign students and can do so in a way which will maximise long term benefits for Australia. The extraordinary interest being shown in this program is clear evidence of a firm demand within our region, and possibly elsewhere, for well marketed and well targeted Australian educational services. Its success will bring enormous benefits. that is, Australia's-
high quality, government-backed education system. Most-
Indonesians-

will shy away from the issue of private universities being established in Queensland and Western Australia, saying that it is `too early to tell' what will be the effect of these or flatly `no comment'.

This is an area in which this country must involve itself. It must involve itself in the export of educational services. TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of those medical and health care practitioners who have recently formed the Australian Society of Environmental Medicine. Small in number, they represent a growing field of established medicine which is deeply concerned with the relationship between the increasing complexity of our environment and its possible influence on our health. There is a growing perception in our community that many of the illnesses we are now suffering can be traced to what we eat, the air we breathe, what we touch and what touches us. Every day there are reports of environmental issues which have health implications. Recently we have been told that asthma deaths have more than doubled in Australia in the past 10 years, but we do not know why; that unacceptably high levels of pesticides have been found in Australian beef; that PVC piping may poison the water supply; that there is evidence linking antibiotics in animal feed with illnesses in humans; that excessive levels of cadmium have been found in 21 per cent of sheep kidneys tested in a recent national survey and that the toxic chemical dioxin has been found in a range of paper products. The list is endless.

SPEECH.PARA: All this is bringing home forcefully to the Australian public that the apparent advantages flowing from the manipulation and control of our environment can, all too easily, bring with it unforseen and serious disadvantages. What is frequently not recognised is that there are really three separate issues involved. The first is the impact which certain chemicals and substances have on those people with specific allergies or sensitivities. Second, there is the potential danger to humans from direct exposure to poisons and highly toxic substances. Third, and this is my real concern, there is evidence that increasing intake of and exposure to chemicals is having long term cumulative and adverse effects on the reproductive, higher brain functions and immune systems of a wide spectrum of the population.

People who have a conventional medical condition are well served by present medical services. Poorly served, though, are those who have a condition possibly involving maladaption to an increasingly complex environment. Few facilities are provided and few practitioners are interested in, or able to investigate, whether these conditions are caused by, or vary with, exposure to factors such as allergens, chemicals, nutritional and immunological status, fatigue, hormonal changes and/or psychological stress. It could be that many of those who are opting for alternative medicine are people with these complex problems.

As well as other non-medical practitioners, some individual nutritional pharmacologists and orthomolecular psychiatrists are attempting to address these matters from the perspective of their particular speciality. Though some aspects of their work certainly lack scientific documentation of effectiveness and cost efficiency, patients and practitioners are adamant that their approaches are helpful and often so in situations where most or all other approaches have failed.

I wish to make three observations and to make a plea for the Government to take an active and responsible interest in environmental medicine. First, rapid post-war changes in our urbanised society, its environment and our eating habits, have brought with them an increase in our exposure to, and consumption of, chemicals and non-food substances. Second, there appears to be an increasing public perception that a number of health-related disorders and allergies can be traced to the changes in, and complexity of, that environment. Unless orthodox medicine responds appropriately to people with such problems, the present drift to alternative medicine will continue and escalate. Third, while environmental medicine is very much in its infancy in Australia, its work and success in this field is such that it warrants more respect than appears to be the case, and almost certainly greater support and encouragement.

The proposal I wish to place before the Australian medical profession, our health administrators and the Government is that scepticism towards environmental medicine should be converted into a healthy willingness to put more resources into well-supervised, well-designed, clinically-based research programs, to study the impact on humans of a rapidly changing environment and the increasing use of additives in our food industries. The first essential step in this direction is for the Government to establish an environmental medicine task force to advise it on how that study would best be conducted and the resources that might be required. Above all, that task force must be multi-disciplinary in composition as an acknowledgment that future research on environmental medicine must be a co-ordination of a large number and diversity of branches of medical research.

In fact, on the previous 13 occasions in which a vacancy has occurred since the constitutional amendment of 1977 the vacancy has been filled without incident. State governments of all political persuasions have abided by the will of the people as it was reflected in the spirit of the 1977 referendum.

In the situation in Tasmania in April of this year there was a fairly simple equation. There was one Senate vacancy to be filled by an Australian Labor Party nominee. The Australian Labor Party had one nomination to fill the one vacancy-John Devereux, the properly preselected candidate. It was such a simple equation that even the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) understood it. He said on the public record that the ALP nomination, Mr Devereux, should have filled the Senate vacancy. In this House on 12 April this year he made his view quite clear when he said:
I believe that persons appointed to fill casual vacancies of the kind created by Senator Grime's departure ought to be filled by the person nominated by the retiring senator's political party.

But what we need to remember is that the Tasmanian Liberal Premier learnt his trade from the Queensland Premier, for whom simple equations are remarkably complex. Let us recall that during the last Queensland State election the Premier stunned a public gathering. When talking of electoral representation, he made the revelation:
. . . It doesn't add up-you can't make one and one mean two . . .

The actions of the Tasmanian Premier were those of a desperate man. Was his attempt at constitutional vandalism in this instance a diversion, a cynical attempt at petty point scoring intended to distract attention of the nation from the real issues, such as the ineptitude of his State Administration?

In 1977 the Australian people expressed a firm view on the issue of Senate vacancies. They did so on the information provided to them by the political figures of the day. Let there be no doubt that the Australian people believed that the 1977 amendment constituted a fair, reasonable and final resolution to the issue of Senate vacancies. We have no less an authority on this matter than the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser-not the flavour of month in the Liberal Party at the moment. In a Press statement of 4 May 1977 the then Prime Minister stated:

The . . . proposal concerns the Senator you actually elect. Should he die or resign during his period of office, we believe that he ought to be replaced by somebody from the same political party and that the replacement Senator should serve out the remainder of this term. That means that the party balance determined at one election will be maintained until the next.

He further stated that this was fair, reasonable, just and would make the Constitution work better. Introducing the Constitution Alteration (Senate Casual Vacancies) Bill in early 1977, the then Liberal Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, informed the Parliament and the Australian people:

The Government has concluded that the appropriate course is to invite the people of Australia to write provisions into the Constitution which will make clear and certain the manner in which Senate casual vacancies are to be filled. The effect of the amendments proposed is that a Senate casual vacancy will have to be filled by a person chosen from the same political party as the person he is to replace.
Nothing can be clearer than that. Of this recent sad and sorry exercise in Tasmania the commentator Cassius, writing in the Daily Commercial News of Tuesday, 12 May 1987, had this to say:
The constitutional fracas which has been provoked by Tasmanian Liberal Premier, Mr Gray, over the appointment to fill a casual vacancy in the Senate should never have arisen.
That it has is solely the responsibility of those who drafted the Constitutional amendment which was endorsed by the people at the 1977 referendum.
The commentary went on to add:
Now it seems this was not achieved simply because those who drafted the amendment, presumably lawyers, were careless with the actual wording.
There is no doubt as to the intent of the amendment . . .
Put crudely this meant that the State Parliament was simply to be a rubber stamp for the name forwarded by the Party.
Though not wishing to be flippant, I can only agree with the conclusion of the article from Cassius.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October this year an article in the Sydney Morning Herald commenced with the following rhetorical question and answer:

SPEECH.PARA: Unhappy with your unborn baby's sex? Then have an abortion.

The article was reporting on a study at Sydney's Royal Prince Alfred Hospital which found that women were having abortions because they felt their baby's sex was inappropriate. It had found that most of the aborted foetuses were female. One of the study's authors, Dr Tom Boogert, was reported as saying of these women:

They find themselves pregnant, and having had the test done, proving to be normal, and having been given the sex of the baby, decide they have got three or four of that sex anyway and don't feel it's worthwhile to continue under those circumstances.
Obviously I'm not happy about people terminating pregnancies but largely it's up to the patient.

Most Australians will have seen the statistics for abortion in this country. It seems, however, that the simple statistical tale of the tens of thousands of human lives being arbitrarily terminated each year has either been unbelievable or simply overwhelming for most people. This publication of the study has succeeded where the statistics have failed. It has made ordinary citizens face the moral dimension of abortion on demand. Realising that the sex-related abortion story has reopened the abortion debate, some have sought to head off the debate by focusing on the question of whether a mother should be told the sex of her foetus. But as Dr Paul Shekleton is reported to have said, it is inconsistent that doctors could not accept the termination of pregnancy on the grounds of `wrong' sex when they otherwise did abortions on demand.

That is the real point at issue once again-abortion on demand. Suddenly people realise that our laws are allowing the destruction of human life for any reason at all; indeed, for no reason at all. Suddenly people are feeling, legitimately, guilty as members of a society which has allowed the situation to get to this point. We have turned a blind eye to people who have decided to destroy human life simply to maintain a certain lifestyle or simply because they already had two of that type. We have been a party to other abortions because we have been unwilling to provide the social and financial support a mother with a disabled child would require, having proceeded with her pregnancy. We have even allowed the truth to be distorted by the manipulation of language. Abortion involves the termination, the destruction, of life-human life. But we do not talk about that; we talk about birth control and individual choice. We face in Australia today the systematic desacralisation of life. The ease with which persons can decide to terminate a pregnancy simply because they would prefer the other sex is simply the shocking evidence of that fact.

There is an urgent need for this country to consider anew the availability of abortion on demand. We need to consider as well our own obligation to support women who face difficulties because of their pregnancy. We cannot stand in judgment on women or couples who abort a potentially handicapped baby or who shrink from the task of parenthood when we will not take up our own obligation to that unborn child and its mother. Albert Schweitzer is quoted as saying that if a person loses reverence for any part of life he will lose his reverence for all of life. He wrote:

Someone who affirms life accepts as being good: to preserve life, to promote life, to raise to its highest value life which is capable of development; and as being evil; to destroy life, to injure life, to repress life which is capable of development.

This country is collectively involved in the arbitrary, massive destruction of human life on a daily basis. We have been forced to face up to this reality by the publicity the abortion due to sex findings have received. We must ask ourselves simply, `Do we as a community revere human life? Do we want to be a life-affirming community?' If we do, we will stop abortion on demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask both State and Federal governments to recognise the value and advice of the people best trained to look after Australia's forests-foresters. There is mounting evidence that government foresters are not being properly heeded by their own governments. Failure to listen to foresters will lead to the economic decay of important communities in the timber areas of Australia-communities like Bombala, Nimmitabel, Delegate and Eden. As their Federal member I have worked with people in those districts; I have come to know them. In recent months I have seen very real fear, even terror, as people wrestle with the possibility of losing their capital investments, their family security and even family stability. There is no doubt that unless governments listen to the sensible, balanced views of foresters the fears of some of these people will be realised.

SPEECH.PARA: Foresters have told the New South Wales Government that the Eden-Bombala forests can sustain viable sawlog hardwood industries in partnership with a woodchip industry which takes waste and timber not useable for sawlogs. I would be interested to know how much regard the New South Wales Government is giving to that advice. I would also be interested to know how much regard the Federal Government gave to the counsel of its Forests and Land Management Branch in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy before it made decisions on the forests in southern Tasmania and northern Queensland. My impression is that there is an increasing tendency by governments to listen to unqualified people when they make decisions on forests. Medical practitioners, non-specialist botanists, teachers and farmers are all able to speak with knowledge about forests, but not to the extent that foresters can. Even environmentalists know less about forests than foresters. Foresters have graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Forestry qualification after four years at the Australian National University or Melbourne University. A large number go on to post-graduate studies and foresters have in-house training to keep them skilled in their profession and craft. Fire schools, managerial training and technical training continue after graduation. Subjects dealt with in their courses include: wildlife, fire ecology, silviculture, hydrology, soils and nutrition, pathology and entomology. They liaise closely with, and have representation on, organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and universities. It is not surprising that foresters are interested in sustainable forests and in protecting catchments and sensitive parts of the forests.

If no action is taken to increase reserves in the Eden-Bombala forests, 45 per cent of the total crown forest area will not be logged. Thirty-five per cent of State forests will not be logged. Of the areas to be logged, the rate is low enough to protect large areas from the process. Where logging takes place there is no clear felling. Trees are retained. All growing trees are retained. Added to that are a minimum of five trees per hectare kept for seed and five trees per 15 hectares for wildlife, three to five trees around the perimeter of each log dump and monkey gums kept with nesting hollows. Under the foresters, 10 per cent or more of the canopy generally remains, plus 20 to 40 metre wide filter strips of forest per 40 hectares and over catchment. Foresters ensure that only trees which are marked can be removed and it is their job to see that only waste and timber unsuitable for logging goes to the chip mill. Foresters prescribe how logging takes place to keep down erosion and to take special precautions-for example, with wildlife and in wet weather and on slopes.

The foresters say that we can have viable sawlog and chip industries and sustain our forests. Not to accept their word would bring some towns close to ruin. To argue that hardwood mills can divert to softwood is to ignore the fact that all softwood in the region is taken up by Softwood Holdings, a firm in Bombala. Taking every available pine log would increase employment there by no more than three or four people a year and would not employ the workers at Bombala, Nimmitabel, Bega and Eden saw mills. I welcome the recent announcement by Bob Ware, the Australian Labor Party candidate for Bega, that he wants a viable timber industry. He knows, as I do, that to close up thousands of hectares more of forest would be to throw people on to the jobs scrap-heap. It would also be ignoring the true forest specialists. I ask both State and Federal governments to heed the words of their forest experts.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the 1985-86 annual report of the Trade Union Training Authority show that while the number of courses increased by 3.4% over the previous year and the number of participants by 8.6%, course costs increased by 80.4%.

(2) What is the explanation for the increase in course costs and would it be reasonable to expect the Authority to include an appropriate explanation in the report in circumstances where unusually large cost increases occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1985-86 annual report of the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) does show a 3.4% increase in the number of courses run by TUTA and an increase of 8.6% in the number of participants.

It is assumed that the part of the Question relating to course costs refers to the figures reported as expenditure on this item in the Statement of Activity for the year ended 30 June 1986 at page 18 of the Trade Union Training Authority's 1985-86 Annual Report.

That expenditure includes, for the year ended 1985-86, costs additional to those reported under this item in respect of the year ended 1984-85. For this reason, the two figures cannot be compared and, consequently, it is not correct to suggest that there had been an increase of 80.4% in course costs during 1985-86.
A footnote at the bottom of page 18 of the annual report refers the reader to accompanying notes.

(2) The 1985-86 annual report of TUTA provides very detailed explanations of revenue and expenditure statements at pages 24-27 in the section entitled ``Notes to and Forming Part of the Financial Statements''. The reader is informed that the notes form an integral part of each of the Financial Statements. The appropriate explanation of course costs appears at page 26, paragraph 13 under the heading, ``Administration Expenses Changes''. Paragraph 13 (c) indicates that the components of the course costs expenditure item were changed in 1985-86 to include catering costs. Thus the suggested increase of 80.4% is derived from a comparison of unlike data. Paragraph 13 of the notes also includes a statement in which expenditure item figures are adjusted to facilitate a proper comparison of Administration expenses over the two years in question. These adjusted figures indicate an increase of 17.9% in course costs over the two financial years.
The 17.9% increase in course costs reflects the stated increases in training activity, that is, courses up by 3.4% and participants up by 8.6%, as well as the increased cost of course materials.

A more useful measure of the cost of delivering courses is expressed in terms of Student Training Days. This is an efficiency indicator adopted by TUTA under program budgeting. The annual report at page 15 shows that in the reporting year, 1985-86, TUTA reduced the average real cost of its training from $151.06 per Student Training Day to $142.20 per Student Training Day.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the average waiting time for the issue of a visa to visit Australia in (a) London and (b) Hong Kong and what is the reason for any discrepancy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Australian High Commission in London provides a same day or ``while you wait'' visa service to people who apply in person. Some applicants choose to leave their passports for collection at a later stage. This applies to couriers who pick up and deliver on behalf of, say, travel agents. Visas are issued on the spot, or within the time requested by the applicant, where urgency is indicated. Applications lodged by mail are processed and passports returned to the applicants within four working days of receipt within the High Commission.

(b) The Australian Consulate-General in Hong Kong provides a 72 hour visa service for all visitor applicants. Visa applications are usually lodged by mail, by courier or personally through a drop-box arrangement at the Consulate-General. Clients using the drop-box return for collection within a specified period (not more than 72 hours) or, if required, receive their passport by mail. On the spot visa issue is available where urgency is indicated.

The slightly different approaches to processing visitor visa applications reflect differences in the caseload, and client preferences. In London 70% of applications are lodged by mail whereas in Hong Kong 80% of applications are lodged personally, or by agents.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia declare, when it ratified the 1965 Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination on 30 September 1975, that it would seek from Parliament at the first suitable moment legislation specifically implementing the terms of Article 4 (a) making dissemination of racist ideas and incitement to racial discrimination punishable by law.
